(1)  Where the developer can show that a provision of these regulations would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and/or where, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site, and/or where, in the opinion of the planning commission a departure may be made without otherwise nullifying the manufactured home regulations and the intent of these regulations, the planning commission may authorize a variance. Any variance thus authorized shall be noted on the approved plans. 
(2)  If the requested variance involves property located only in the unincorporated area of Floyd County and not in the City of Rome, and if the variance is denied by the planning commission, the developer and/or applicant may appeal the decision of the planning commission denying the variance directly to the board of county commissioners. The board shall have the authority to either accept the recommendation of the planning commission denying said variance or to, in fact, grant the variance. 
(b)  Amendments: The board of commissioners may amend these regulations on their own motion or on recommendation of the planning commission, but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall first have been submitted to the planning commission for review and recommendations. Before enacting an amendment to these regulations, the county commission shall give public notice and hold a public hearing thereon, as required. Legal notice of the public hearing shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation within the county in which are carried legal advertisements of the county by advertising the date, time and place of the public hearing at least fifteen (15) days prior to the public hearing. 
(Ord. of 6-12-90, § 8.A, B; Ord. of 6-10-97, § 1) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted June 10, 1997, set out provisions intended for use as subsection 2-6-67(a)(1). At the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as subsection 2-6-67(a)(2) in order to group the existing provisions of subsection 2-6-67(a) as subsection 2-6-67(a)(1). 
Secs. 2-6-68—2-6-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Mar. 26, 1991, not specifically amendatory of this Code, has been codified as Art. V, Divs. 1—3, §§ 2-6-81—2-6-89, 2-6-101—2-6-104, and 2-6-116—2-6-119, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— County utilities and services, Ch. 2-7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-6-81. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to protect, maintain and enhance the public health, safety and general welfare in the county by establishing minimum requirements and procedures to control the adverse impacts associated with stormwater runoff, enhance broader social and economic objectives and protect, conserve and promote the orderly development of land and water resources. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 1)) 
Sec. 2-6-82. - Conflicting provisions. 
The provisions of this article shall be deemed as additional requirements to standards required by other ordinances of the county. In case of conflicting requirements, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 2)) 
Sec. 2-6-83. - Separability. 
The provisions and sections of this article shall be deemed separable, and the validity of any portion of this article shall not affect the validity of the remainder. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 3)) 
Sec. 2-6-84. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the following definitions describe the meanings of the terms used in this article: 
Agricultural land management practices means those methods and procedures used in the cultivation of land in order to further crop and livestock production and conservation of related soil and water resources. 
Applicant means any person, firm or governmental agency who executes the necessary forms to procure official approval of a project or a permit to carry out construction of a project. 
Clearing means the removal of trees and brush from the land but shall not include the ordinary mowing of grass. 
Detention facility means a permanent structure for the temporary storage of runoff and its subsequent gradual discharge. 
Develop land means to alter the characteristics of a parcel of land in conjunction with residential, commercial, industrial or institutional construction or modification. 
Developer means any person owning and proposing to develop or construct on a piece of property. 
Development review committee means the committee whose members are the county manager, director of the water division, superintendent of public works, and the director of community development division. 
Drainage area means that area contributing runoff to a single point measured in a horizontal plane, which is enclosed by a ridge line. 
Drainage structures means any storm drains, collection basins, inlets, berms or other physical construction or provision for the storage or conveyance of stormwater runoff. 
Easement means a grant or reservation by the owner of land for the use of such land by others for a specific purpose or purposes, and which must be included in the conveyance of land affected by such easement. 
Exemption means those land development activities that are not subject to the stormwater management requirements contained in this article. 
Grading means any act by which soil is cleared, stripped, stockpiled, excavated, scarified, filled or any combination thereof. 
Off-site stormwater management means the design and construction of a facility necessary to control stormwater from more than one (1) development. 
On-site stormwater management means the design and construction of systems necessary to control stormwater within an immediate development. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Retention structure means a permanent structure that provides for the storage of runoff by means of a pool of water. 
Site means any tract, lot or parcel of land or combination of tracts, lots or parcels of land which are in one (1) ownership, or are contiguous and in diverse ownership where development is to be performed as part of a unit, subdivision or project. 
Stormwater management means: 
(1)  For quantitative control, a system of vegetative and structural measures that control the increase in volume and rate of surface runoff caused by man-made changes to the land; and 
(2)  For qualitative control, a system of vegetative, structural and other measures that reduce or eliminate pollutants that might otherwise be carried by surface runoff. 
Stormwater management plan means a set of drawings and supplementary documentation submitted by a person as a prerequisite to obtaining a stormwater management approval, which contains all of the information and specifications pertaining to stormwater management. 
Stripping means any activity which removes the vegetative surface cover, including tree removal, clearing, grubbing and storage or removal of topsoil. 
Variance means the modification of the minimum stormwater management requirements for the specific circumstances when strict adherence to the requirements would result in unnecessary hardship and not fulfill the intent of this article. 
Waiver means the relinquishment from stormwater management requirements by the board of adjustments and appeals for a specific development. 
Watershed means the total drainage area contributing runoff to a single point. 
(b)  Terms not herein specifically defined shall be construed in the manner commonly accepted, and the interpretation of the same will be furnished by the superintendent of public works upon application. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 4)) 
Sec. 2-6-85. - Applicability and exemptions. 
(a)  All persons proposing development or construction in the county shall prepare a stormwater management plan. No final subdivision plat shall be approved and no building permit shall be issued until and unless the stormwater management plan has been reviewed and approved by the superintendent of public works, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  The following development activities are exempt from the provisions of this article and the requirement of providing a stormwater management plan: 
(1)  Agricultural land management; 
(2)  Additions or modifications to existing single-family, detached residential structures; 
(3)  Developments with a total land area of four-tenths (0.4) acre, or less; 
(4)  Construction of single-family housing for a personal residence. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 5)) 
Sec. 2-6-86. - Variance and waiver procedure. 
(a)  The board of adjustments and appeals, as established by the county through its adoption of the Standard Building Code as provided in section 2-6-3 of this Code, shall hear and decide appeals and requests for variances, or waiver from the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The board of adjustments and appeals shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged there is an error in any requirement, decision or determination made by the public works department in the enforcement or administration of this article. 
(c)  Variances may be issued for the reconstruction, rehabilitation or restoration of structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the State Inventory of Historic Places without regard to the procedures set forth in the remainder of this section. 
(d)  The application for variance or waiver shall be filed by the developer or his agent with the public works department, which shall refer it to the board of adjustments and appeals for decision. 
(1)  The application for variance shall state the specific variances sought and reasons for their granting. 
(2)  The application for a waiver of the requirements provided in the remainder of this article shall so state and reasons for granting the waiver. 
(3)  It shall be the applicant's responsibility to provide sufficient justification for granting the variance or waiver. 
(e)  The public works department shall prepare an evaluation statement concerning each application for variance. The evaluation shall consider the circumstances and supporting documentation supplied by the applicant and other generally available technical information pertaining to the variance requested. The evaluation statement may include recommendations of the disposition to the board of adjustments and appeals. 
(f)  In passing upon such applications, the board of adjustments and appeals shall consider all technical evaluations and relevant factors presented and standards specified in other sections of this article. 
(g)  Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this article, the board of adjustments and appeals may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purpose of this article. 
(h)  Variances and waivers may be granted under the following conditions: 
(1)  Variances shall be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the adverse impacts of stormwater runoff. 
(2)  Variances and waivers shall only be issued upon: 
a.  A showing of good and sufficient cause; and 
b.  A determination that failure to grant the variance or waiver would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant; and 
c.  A determination that the granting of a variance or waiver will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(i)  The public works department shall maintain the records of all board actions. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. A, § 6)) 
Sec. 2-6-87. - Violations and penalties—Bond forfeitures. 
(a)  In the event that the developer continues in noncompliance with the stormwater management plan following the issuance of a stop-work order, the county manager shall substantiate that the developer is in noncompliance and nonresponsive. 
(b)  If the county manager concludes that the issuance of additional correction notices would be futile, then the performance bond posted shall be forfeited. The proceeds of such security shall be used for completion of the stormwater management plan as approved or to return the site to pre-development conditions. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. D, § 1)) 
Sec. 2-6-88. - Same—To constitute misdemeanor. 
Any violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 2-1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. D, § 2)) 
Sec. 2-6-89. - Same—Prosecution by county. 
Whenever it shall come to the attention of the county that any provision of this article has been or is being violated within its jurisdiction, the county may immediately institute suit for injunction. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. D, § 3)) 
Secs. 2-6-90—2-6-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PLAN; CRITERIA 

Sec. 2-6-101. - Review and approval authority. 
(a)  A stormwater management plan or an application for a variance or waiver shall be submitted to the public works department by the developer for review and approval for any proposed development, unless otherwise exempted. The stormwater management plan shall contain supporting computations, drawings, and sufficient information describing the manner, location and type of measures which will be employed to conduct stormwater runoff from the site. The public works department will review the plan to determine the compliance with the requirements of this article prior to approval. The plan shall serve as the basis for all subsequent construction and maintenance activities. 
(b)  Notification of approval or reasons for the disapproval or modification shall be issued within five (5) regular business days after submission of the completed stormwater plan. The stormwater management plan shall not be considered approved without the inclusion of the signature and date of signature of the superintendent of public works on the plan. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. B, § 1)) 
Sec. 2-6-102. - Stormwater management plan—Minimum requirements. 
The stormwater management plan shall be prepared under the supervision of, and certified by, a professional engineer or land surveyor registered in the state. The plan shall include sufficient information to evaluate the environmental characteristics of the affected areas, the potential impacts of the proposed development on water resources, and the effectiveness and acceptability of measures proposed for managing stormwater runoff. The developer shall certify on the drawings that all clearing, grading, drainage, construction and development shall be conducted in strict accordance with the plan. The minimum information submitted for support of a stormwater management plan or application for a variance shall be as follows: 
(1)  Provide a site plan drawn to a scale of not less than one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet with the following characteristics and information: 
a.  Graphic scale, north arrow and date. North arrow shall be identified as magnetic, true or grid north. 
b.  Vicinity map showing the site location relative to surrounding landmarks, highway intersections, rivers and streams. 
c.  Topography showing existing and proposed elevations in accordance with the following: 
1.  For sites smaller than one (1) acre in size, show the direction of drainage and spot elevations at all breaks in grade and along drainage channels or swales at selected points not more than one hundred (100) feet apart. 
2.  For sites one (1) acre and larger with slopes less than approximately two (2) percent, show contours at intervals of not more than two (2) feet and spot elevations at all breaks in grade along drainage channels or swales at selected points not more than one hundred (100) feet apart. 
3.  For sites one (1) acre and larger with slopes more than approximately two (2) percent, show contours with an interval of not more than five (5) feet. 
4.  Elevations shall be based on the datum plane established by the U.S. Coastal and Geodetic Survey. 
d.  Delineation of property lines and deed record names of adjacent property owners. 
e.  Location of existing structures. 
f.  Location and right-of-way of streets, roads, railroads and utility lines, either on or adjacent to the property to be developed. Specify whether utility lines are in easements or rights-of-way and show location of towers and poles. 
g.  Size and location of existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract or within the right-of-way of streets or roads adjoining the tract. Grades and invert elevations of sewers shall be shown. 
h.  Proposed conditions: 
1.  Layout of streets, roads, alleys, drives and paved areas, public crosswalks, with widths, road names or designations. 
2.  Location of structures. 
3.  Preliminary plans of storm sewer system with grade, pipe size and location of outlet. 
4.  Certification by a registered land surveyor or professional engineer attesting that the site plan has been prepared in conformity with the minimum standards of this article. 
(2)  Provide computations and supporting documentation of hydrologic and hydraulic analyses. 
a.  Except as noted in b below, analyses shall be performed in accordance with the publication entitled "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia," which is on file in the offices of the public works department. The "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia," published by the State Soil and Water Conservation Committee of Georgia, is incorporated by reference in this article. 
b.  Analyses for sites twenty (20) acres and less in size may be performed using the rational method. 
(3)  The stormwater management plan shall provide the following information for pre-development and post-development conditions: 
a.  The composite runoff curve number or runoff coefficient for the site; 
b.  The peak runoff rate at the point, or points, of discharge for the ten-year, twenty-four-hour storm; and 
c.  The capacity of storm sewers, ditches and other hydraulic structures. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. B, § 2)) 
Sec. 2-6-103. - Same—Completed plan. 
In addition to the minimum requirements described in section 2-6-102, the stormwater management plan must conform to the following: 
(1)  Provide detailed design drawings and specifications for all facilities, temporary and permanent, required by the stormwater management plan. 
(2)  Provide a construction schedule for both temporary and permanent facilities. Reference the schedule to other development activities such as clearing, rough grading, construction, final grading, and vegetation establishment. 
(3)  Provide a plan for maintenance of the stormwater facilities. Describe specific actions and a recommended schedule of maintenance required to maintain the facilities at a satisfactory level of service. 
(4)  Provide a cost estimate for construction of the stormwater management facilities. Provide a separate estimate of the annual cost for maintenance of the proposed facilities. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. B, § 3)) 
Sec. 2-6-104. - Minimum design criteria. 
(a)  The design of temporary and permanent facilities shall be based on the criteria established herein and the procedures, materials and methods of construction found in the publications "Rome and Floyd County Standard Design Specifications", "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia", and the "Georgia Stormwater Management Manual", which are on file in the office of the public works department. The "Rome and Floyd County Standard Design Specifications" and the "Georgia Stormwater Management Manual" are incorporated by reference in this article. In case of a conflict, the more restrictive basis of design shall apply unless deemed otherwise by the superintendent of public works. 
(b)  Rainfall intensities used in hydrologic analyses shall not be less than those shown by applicable rainfall curves published by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for the Rome and Floyd County area. These curves are on file and available for inspection in the public works department offices. 
(c)  The controlled release of stormwater runoff shall be required for all developments or construction in order to prevent an increase in the pre-development rate of runoff in excess of ten (10) percent, or one (1) cubic foot per second for a ten-year frequency storm for all durations, whichever is greater. 
(d)  Where the controlled release is required by subsection (c) above, such release shall prevent any increase in the pre-development rate of runoff for less frequent storms up to and including the fifty-year storm. 
(e)  Storm drainage systems, including piping and detention facilities, shall be provided in conjunction with subsection (c) above to handle the runoff of a fifty-year, twenty-four-hour storm. Detention facilities and other drainage structures shall be located and designed to ensure the protection of adjacent public and private property. 
(f)  Upon written request by the developer, the superintendent of public works shall determine if the development and construction projects in an area are small enough, or that engineering and economic factors make off-site retention or other drainage facilities more practical, and may authorize the joint construction of these facilities to serve two (2) or more properties by two (2) or more developers. This authorization shall be granted by the development review committee upon application for approval being submitted through the superintendent of public works. Where off-site stormwater facilities serving two (2) or more properties are approved for construction, no use of land or occupancy of buildings within the properties served by these facilities shall be permitted until completion of the retention and drainage structures, except upon approval of the committee. 
(g)  The following requirements shall apply to the installation, development and maintenance of all detention facilities designed for temporary storage of stormwater runoff: 
(1)  Permanent fencing at least four (4) feet in height shall be required around all facilities having a maximum water or undercut depth of more than four (4) feet or a bank slope greater than 1.5:1 (horizontal to vertical). This fencing shall be designed, installed and maintained to allow the free flow of runoff and sediment into the facility. The fence shall include a gate of sufficient size to permit entrance of equipment necessary to allow periodic maintenance activities. Fencing may be waived by the superintendent of public works in other than areas zoned residential and where the pond is more than five hundred (500) feet from a residential district. 
(2)  Facilities shall be located on tracts of land, designated for this use on the recorded plat, with sufficient area around the perimeter to provide access for maintenance purposes and shall be immediately adjacent to, or be provided with an access easement to, a public street. The access easement shall provide at least ten (10) feet of width clearance from aboveground obstructions including trees, headwalls, weirs or other structures. 
(3)  Easements shall be provided for detention facilities serving single-family residential subdivisions and subject to county maintenance as provided in section 2-6-119. Such easement shall be of sufficient width to permit access to and maintenance of the facility. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. B, § 4); Ord. No. 2014-002A, § 1, 7-22-14) 
Secs. 2-6-105—2-6-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERFORMANCE BOND; ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 2-6-116. - Performance bond. 
(a)  Upon approval of the stormwater management plan, but before the issuance of a building permit or subdivision plat approval, the applicant shall be required to post a performance bond, cash escrow, certified check or other acceptable form of performance security. 
(b)  The amount of the security shall not be less than the total estimated construction cost of the facilities required by the stormwater management plan. 
(c)  The performance bond or other securities shall not be released until the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The county engineer shall perform a final inspection of the facilities and determine that they have been constructed in compliance with the stormwater management plan; and 
(2)  Shall determine that all provisions of the stormwater management plan have been faithfully executed. 
(d)  A provision may be made for partial release of the amount of the bond pro rata upon completion and acceptance of various stages of development as specifically delineated, described and scheduled in the stormwater management plan. The applicant shall notify the county engineer upon completion of each stage that is ready for inspection. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. C, § 1)) 
Sec. 2-6-117. - Inspection. 
(a)  The superintendent of public works shall be responsible for determining whether development is proceeding in accordance with the approved stormwater management plan. Periodic inspection of the development site shall be made by the county engineer to ensure that the stormwater management plan is properly implemented. 
(b)  The county engineer and other duly authorized employees bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation and management in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. C, § 2)) 
Sec. 2-6-118. - Enforcement. 
(a)  In the event that work performed does not conform to the provisions of the approved stormwater management plan and inspection, a written notice to comply shall be served upon the owner. Such notice shall set forth the nature of the correction required and the time within which corrections shall be made. 
(b)  Failure to comply with such notice shall result in the issuance of a stop-work order applicable to all construction activity except that necessary for correction of the violation. Upon correction of the violation, the stop-work order shall be voided and construction may resume. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. C, § 3)) 
Sec. 2-6-119. - Maintenance responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the developer to maintain all facilities required by the stormwater management plan during construction. The developer shall be responsible for removing temporary structures or facilities on the completion of construction. The developer and all subsequent owners shall also be responsible for maintaining the permanent facilities identified by the stormwater management plan to remain after construction is complete. 
(b)  Should an owner fail to maintain the stormwater management facilities in a state of service intended by the stormwater management plan, then the superintendent of public works shall notify the owner in writing of such deficiencies and specific minimum maintenance requirements to remedy such deficiencies. 
(c)  If the owner fails to perform the required maintenance work within a reasonable period of time (thirty (30) days maximum), then the owner shall be in violation of the provisions of this section and shall be punished as prescribed in section 2-1-8 of this Code. 
(d)  In the case of single-family residential subdivisions approved after March 26, 1991, the county shall assume responsibility for the functional maintenance of facilities one (1) year after the release of the performance bond required by this article. At the end of the developer's maintenance period, all retention structures shall have a positive slope to the outlet in order to facilitate complete drainage. 
(e)  Retention facilities in single-family residential subdivisions constructed prior to March 26, 1991, will not be accepted for county maintenance as provided in subsection (d), unless individually approved by and at the discretion of the county commission and unless suitable access easements are provided. 
(Ord. of 3-26-91 (Art. C, § 4)) 
ARTICLE VI. - PERSONAL WIRELESS COMMUNICATION FACILITIES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-003A, § 1, adopted Aug. 26, 2014, deleted Art. VI, §§ 2-6-120—2-6-136 entitled "Personal Wireless Communication Facilities", which derived from Ord. No. 2011-002A, § 1, adopted Mar. 22, 2011. 
Editor's note— At the direction of the county, § 2-6-128 was added to the Code, per Ord. 2015-004A, subsequently the title of previously deleted art. VI, was added back. 

Secs. 2-6-120—2-6-127. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-6-128. - Telecommunications permit application requirements. 
(a)  General. The person, company or organization that will own, operate, rebuild or extend the height of a telecommunications facility shall make application for a telecommunications permit for any communication tower and/or antenna to the building official. Applications shall be made on such special forms, if any, as may be required by the building official or the building official's agent and shall contain such additional information as the building official may reasonably require. Applications for a telecommunications permit shall be signed on behalf of the applicant by the person preparing same and with knowledge of the contents and representations made therein and attesting to the truth and completeness of the information. The landowner, if different than the applicant, shall also sign the application. At the discretion of the county building official, any false or misleading statement on the application may subject the applicant to denial of the application without further consideration or opportunity for correction. An application will not be considered until it is complete. The holder of a telecommunications permit shall notify the building official of any intended rebuilding or extension in height of a telecommunications facility and shall apply with the county through the building official to relocate, rebuild or extend the height of a telecommunications facility. When an application is complete, it shall be processed upon payment of a one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) application fee to the governing body and shall be either granted or denied within sixty (60) days by the building official and/or agent. There will be no delay from the sixty (60) days time limit unless special circumstances exist that justify an extension of time not to exceed sixty (60) additional days for a decision to be made, if reasonably possible. A telecommunications permit shall be required for each telecommunications facility to be installed. Any and all representations made by the applicant to the building official or his designee on the record during the application process, whether written or verbal, shall be deemed a part of the application and may be relied upon in good faith by the governing body. 
(b)  No telecommunications facility shall be installed or constructed until the application is reviewed and approved by the building official and the telecommunications permit has been issued. 
(c)  The application shall include a statement in writing: 
(1)  That the applicant's proposed telecommunications facility shall be maintained in a safe manner, and in compliance with all conditions of the telecommunications permit, without exception, unless specifically granted relief by the county building official in writing, as well as all applicable and permissible local codes, ordinances and regulations, including any and all applicable county, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(2)  That the construction of the telecommunications facility is legally permissible, including, but not limited to, the fact that the property is properly zoned for a telecommunications facility. 
(d)  An application for the construction or installation of a new, relocated, rebuilt or extended in height telecommunications facility shall contain the information hereinafter set forth. When a certification is called for in this section or article, such certification shall bear the signature of a professional engineer licensed in this state. The application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, mail address, telephone number, facsimile number and electronic mail address, if applicable, of the applicant, property owner and/or person preparing the report. 
(2)  The type of personal wireless service to be provided by the communications facility. 
(3)  Site plan or plans specifying the location of communications facilities, transmission building and/or other accessory uses, access, parking, fences and adjacent land uses, as well as the size of the property both in square feet and lot line dimensions showing compliance with required setbacks. 
(4)  Identification of the geographic service area for the subject installation, including a map showing the site and the nearest or associated telecommunications facility sites within the network, as well as all other suitable existing telecommunications facility within five (5) miles of the location of any proposed new telecommunications facility, unless the applicant can show that some other suitable distance is more reasonable and demonstrate conclusively why any existing telecommunications facility or other suitable structure cannot be used. A description of the distance between the telecommunications facility sites. A description of how this service area fits into and is necessary for the service network. 
(5)  A full description of the adjacent properties and the location, including any residential structures and districts, listed or eligible structures and sites on the National Register of Historic Places, floodplain, wetlands, listed threatened or endangered species or critical habitats, wildlife management areas, protected river corridors and state waters. 
(6)  The location of the nearest residential structure and the name and address of all landowners whose property is located within one thousand (1,000) feet of any property line of the lot or parcel on which the new telecommunications facility is proposed to be located. 
(7)  The location, size and height of all structures on the property which is the subject of the application. 
(8)  A description of anticipated maintenance needs for the communications facility, including frequency of service, personal needs, equipment needs and traffic, noise or safety impacts of such maintenance. 
(9)  Report from a qualified independent professional engineer licensed in the State of Georgia that documents the following: 
a.  Telecommunications facility height and design, including technical engineering, economic and other pertinent factors governing selection of the proposed design; 
b.  Total anticipated capacity of the telecommunications facility, including number and types of antennas which can be accommodated; 
C.  Evidence of structural integrity of the telecommunications tower structure; 
d.  Structural failure characteristics of the telecommunications facility; 
e.  The location, size and height of all proposed and existing antennas and all appurtenant structures; 
f.  Certification that the proposed antennas will not cause interference with other telecommunications devices with specific reference to the Floyd County Public Safety Communications System; 
g.  The type, locations and dimensions of all proposed and existing landscaping and fencing; 
h.  The number, type and design of the tower(s) and antenna(s) proposed and the basis for the calculations of the tower's capacity to accommodate multiple users; 
i.  The make, model and manufacturer of the tower(s) and antenna(s); 
j.  A description of the proposed tower(s) and antenna(s) and all related fixtures, structures, appurtenances and apparatus, including height above pre-existing grade, materials, color and lighting; and 
k.  A copy of the FCC license applicable for the intended use of the telecommunication facility. 
(10)  The applicant shall submit a written report demonstrating the applicant's review of colocation and the locations in order of priority as shown in section 2-6-126, demonstrating the technological reason for the site selection. If appropriate, based on selecting a site of lower priority, a detailed written explanation as to why sites of higher priority were not selected shall be included with the application. 
(11)  Notarized statement that the applicant and owner shall allow other future personal wireless service companies, including public and quasi-public agencies, using functionally equivalent personal wireless technology to co-locate antennas, equipment and facilities on a telecommunications facility unless specific technical constraints prohibit said co-location. 
(12)  The applicant must provide any other information that may be requested by the building official to fully evaluate and review the application and the potential impact of a proposed telecommunications facility. 
(13)  The decision of the county building official approving the application shall be final if the application is granted. If the application is not granted and the applicant takes issue with any part of the application process or the decision by the county building official, the applicant may appeal directly to the Floyd County Board of Commissioners within thirty (30) days of the decision by the local county building official denying the application. The hearing thereon shall be open to the public and evidence may be presented by the applicant and the county building official as to the appeal. 
(e)  There shall be a pre-application meeting. The purpose of this pre-application meeting will be to address issues that will help to expedite the review and permitting process. A pre-application meeting shall also include a site visit if there has not been a prior site visit for the requested site. Costs of the county's consultants, if needed, to prepare for and attend the pre-application meeting will be borne by the applicant. 
(f)  The holder of a telecommunications permit shall notify the building official of any intended relocation, rebuilding or extension in height of a telecommunications facility and shall apply with the county for a new telecommunications permit through the building official to relocate, rebuild or extend in height a telecommunications facility. 
(g)  The applicant will provide a written copy of an analysis, completed by a qualified individual or organization, to determine if the telecommunications facility or exiting structure intended to suppolt wireless facilities requires lighting under Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Regulation Part 77 or any other subsequent FAA requirement. This requirement shall be for any new telecommunications facility or for an existing structure or building where the application increases the height of the structure or building. If this analysis determines that the FAA must be contacted, then all filings with the FAA, all responses from the FAA and any related correspondence shall be provided in a timely manner. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004A, 11-24-15) 
Secs. 2-6-129—2-6-150. - Reserved. 
Chapter 2-7 - COUNTY UTILITIES AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Water and sewer department created, § 2-2-22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-7-1. - Regulation of privately owned fire, burglary and/or robbery alarm systems. 
(a)  Purpose: It is the purpose of this section to establish requirements for the monitoring and/or receiving of fire and burglar alarm signals, and fire equipment trouble alarms at the 911 Center. 
(b)  Definitions: Unless the context demands otherwise, the words and terms used in this section shall have the following definitions: 
(1)  False alarm is a fire alarm signal or police signal from a privately owned fire or police signal device or system that is caused or created by anything other than an actual fire or burglary/robbery, respectively, in the premises where the device or system is located. 
(2)  False alarm penalty is an administrative fee imposed by the county to defray the expense to the county for responding to false alarms. The amount of the fees shall be as set out in the fee schedule as provided in subsection (i) of this section. 
(3)  Fire alarm signal is a signal indicating an emergency requiring immediate action of the fire department, including but not limited to an alarm from a manually operated fire alarm box, a water flow alarm, or an alarm from an automatic fire/smoke detection system or device. 
(4)  Fire equipment trouble alarm is an alarm indicating some form of malfunction or trouble with the fire protection or fire detecting system or device being monitored. Such trouble alarm does not indicate the need for emergency fire department response to the site, but only that the person responsible for maintenance of the system being monitored is to be notified of the trouble alarm signal. 
(5)  Police signal is a signal from a manually operated or automatic device which indicates an emergency requiring immediate response by the police department. 
(c)  Connections: No emergency signal other than a fire alarm, burglary and robbery or intrusion alarm, and no trouble alarm other than a fire equipment trouble alarm shall be connected to any alarm signal receiving equipment in the 911 Center. 
(d)  Automatic Dialers: It shall be unlawful to key automatic dialer fire or burglar alarms to the county emergency numbers or to the 911 Center. These types of alarms shall be keyed to a private service that can then notify the 911 Center. 
(e)  Automatic Cutoff System: All audible alarms, sirens, bells or horns shall have an automatic cutoff system so that the alarm shall not operate for more than thirty (30) continuous minutes. 
(f)  Transmission of False Alarms: The transmission of false alarms to the 911 Center of the county, as the case may be, in excess of the allowable alarms as contained in the fee schedule shall authorize the imposition of a false alarm penalty as provided in said fee schedule as set out in subsection (i) of this section. 
(g)  Accounting of False Alarms: The 911 Center shall maintain an accounting of false alarms on a monthly and quarterly basis. Each calendar year shall constitute a new accounting period for determining the imposition of false alarm penalties as established in the fee schedule. 
(h)  Termination of Services: Service will be terminated as provided in the fee schedule. Service will be reinstated only after appropriate action has been taken to correct user deficiencies and the user receives approval from the appropriate chief. 
(i)  Fee Schedule and False Alarm Penalty: The following schedule of penalties shall apply for the purpose of determining the administrative fees to be imposed on a yearly basis for false alarms as established in subsections (a) through (h) of this section: 
(1)  One (1) to four (4) false alarms per year, no penalty. 
(2)  Fifth false alarm, written warning from the director of the 911 Center shall be sent advising the violator that next false alarm will result in the imposition of an administrative fee. 
(3)  Sixth false alarm, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) fee. 
(4)  Seventh false alarm, fifty dollars ($50.00) fee. 
(5)  Eighth false alarm, seventy-five dollars ($75.00) fee. 
(6)  Ninth false alarm and any number thereafter, one hundred dollars ($100.00) fee per false alarm. 
(7)  Tenth false alarm, termination of services after tenth false alarm, if not remedied. 
(Ord. of 3-28-89, §§ I, II) 
Editor's note— Inclusion of the provisions of §§ I, II of an ordinance adopted March 28, 1989, as § 2-7-1 was at the discretion of the editor, the ordinance being nonamendatory of the Code. 
Secs. 2-7-2—2-7-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Note— See also Art. IV of this chapter, § 2-7-80 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-7-20. - Department's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  The water and sewer department, hereinafter referred to as "department," shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed, and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. 
(b)  The department may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render the service. 
(c)  The department may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the department's option, on the customer's property within three (3) feet of the property line. 
(d)  The department reserves the right to refuse service unless the customer's lines or piping are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or backflow. 
(e)  Under normal conditions the customer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service. Failure to notify the customer of service interruptions will not create a liability for the department. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1005; Ord. of 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-7-21. - Customer's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  Water furnished by the department shall be used for consumption by the customer, members of the customer's household and employees only. The customer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use the water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard for this requirement shall be sufficient cause for a refusal or discontinuance of service. 
(b)  Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a customer, a suitable place shall be provided by the customer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. 
(c)  The customer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the customer's side of the meter. 
(d)  The customer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the customer at the customer's expense in a safe and efficient manner. The line or piping shall be installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or backflow. (For more information regarding cross-connections or backflow, see Article IV, section 2-7-80 of the County Code.) 
(e)  In order to be received as a customer and entitled to receive water from the department's water system, all applicants shall offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the county's water system, and all applicants, by becoming customers of the county, covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be customers of the department they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the department's water system. 
(f)  Under Southern Standard Plumbing Code Section 1211, specifically 1211-9-1, the customer is required to install a pressure reducing valve on the customer's side of the meter where water main pressure fluctuates or when the static (no-flow) supply pressure at any fixture would exceed eighty (80) psi. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1006; Ord. of 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-7-22. - Access to premises and extensions of systems. 
(a)  Duly authorized agents of the department shall have access at all hours to the premises of the customer for the purpose of installing or removing department property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service and its facilities, and the sewer service and its facilities. 
(b)  Extensions to the system shall be made only when the customer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the county a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water or sewer lines. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1007) 
Sec. 2-7-23. - Suspension of service. 
The department reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for any of the following additional reasons: 
(1)  To prevent fraud or abuse; 
(2)  Customer's willful disregard of departmental rules; 
(3)  Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the department's control; 
(4)  Emergency repairs; 
(5)  Legal processes; 
(6)  Direction of public authorities; 
(7)  Strike, riot, fire, flood or unavoidable accident. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1010) 
Sec. 2-7-24. - Application for service; deposit. 
The customer shall make application for water and sewer service at the offices of the department. Each customer shall make a deposit as outlined in the Fee Schedule Book; such deposit shall be refunded upon written request, less any sums due for charges, upon discontinuance or termination of service at the location served. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1002; Ord. of 4-23-91) 
Cross reference— Permit to connect, § 2-7-43. 
Sec. 2-7-25. - Charges for initial connections. 
Each customer subscribing to use the water service shall pay at the time of application a deposit and connection fee times the number of connections desired for water service. A proportionately greater charge than the connection fee will be made for a meter of larger dimensions. (Connecting fees can be found in the "Floyd County Water and Sewer Rates Schedule" as provided in section 2-7-26.) 
(Code 1979, § 5-1003; Ord. of 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-7-26. - Rates schedule on file. 
Rates for water and sewer service shall be provided in a document entitled "Floyd County Water and Sewer Rates Schedule" which document is hereby incorporated by reference herein. Copies thereof shall be available for public inspection in the county clerk's office. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1001) 
Sec. 2-7-27. - No free water. 
Under no circumstances shall the county furnish water free of charge to anyone. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1004) 
Sec. 2-7-28. - Billing and nonpayment. 
(a)  Bills to water and sewer service customers shall be mailed on a monthly basis on such dates as determined necessary and convenient by the board of commissioners. Bills shall be paid in person or by mail at the water billing office or in person at any such other location as may be designated for this purpose. 
(b)  Failure to receive a bill shall not prevent such bill from becoming delinquent and shall not relieve the customer from the obligation to pay. The failure to pay a duly imposed bill shall automatically result in the following: 
(1)  Nonpayment by the due date shown on the bill shall result in the imposition of a penalty equal to ten (10) percent of the full amount billed. 
(2)  Nonpayment of the bill, plus the imposed penalty, by the fifteenth day following the due date shall result in the water service being disconnected without further notice. 
(c)  Water service disconnected for nonpayment will be restored only after the bill, plus the imposed penalty, is paid in full and a reconnection fee is paid for each meter requiring reconnection. 
(Amend. of 4-26-94, § 1) 
Editor's note— An amendment adopted April 26, 1994, set out a new § 2-7-28 and repealed the old § 2-7-28, which pertained to "meter reading; billing; delinquent charges; collecting—general" and derived from Code 1979, § 5-1009 and an ordinance adopted April 23, 1991. 
Sec. 2-7-29. - Same—Change of occupancy. 
In the case of water and sewer service provided to rental property, the responsibility for charges for services provided shall be upon the tenant, and the landlord or owner of the property shall not be liable for delinquent bills owed by the tenants. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1008; Ord. of 2-25-92) 
Sec. 2-7-30. - Complaints and adjustments. 
(a)  If the customer believes such customer's bill to be in error, the customer shall present the claim, in person, at the department's business office, before the bill becomes delinquent. The claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The customer may pay the bill under protest and that payment shall not prejudice the claim. 
(b)  The department will make a special water meter reading at the request of a customer. 
(c)  If the seal of a meter is broken, or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the customer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of such customer's previous bills or from any other proper data. 
(d)  In the event of a verified leak in the line on the customer's side of the meter which results in an abnormally high consumption record, the department may make an adjustment to the customer's bill in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The customer's last three (3) consumption readings shall be averaged; and 
(2)  To the average arrived at above shall be added one-half of the difference between the average and the reading reflecting the leak. 
(e)  Following application for service, payment of the required connection fee, and actual installation of the meter, the customer shall be billed the minimum rate for service even if no water is consumed. 
(f)  Where by petition, or otherwise, residents of the county request extension of the water distribution system and the county deems it feasible to make such an extension, the petitioners or others requesting service shall be required to pay one-half of the connection fee prior to the start of construction. Upon completion of construction and being advised that service is available, the balance of the connection fee is due and payable. Whether or not paid, the minimum rate shall become effective, just as if the total connection fee had been paid and the meter installed. The charges so incurred shall be paid before any service is thereafter provided. 
(Code 1979, § 5-1011; Ord. of 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-7-31. - Water conservation, restrictions, rationing and bans—Compliance required. 
(a)  Restriction on outdoor water of landscape. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the unincorporated area may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(5)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(6)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(b)  Required. Whenever the county and the residents thereof are subject to the imposition of any greater or lesser conservation measures, restrictions, rationing or bans, or any combination thereof, concerning the consumption and usage of water, the same having been legally imposed by any governmental authority, whether federal, state or local, and applicable to the county, all residents, persons, corporations, firms, businesses and entities within the county shall comply with all rules, regulations, orders and directions promulgated pursuant to all laws, ordinances and plans pertaining to such consumption and usage of water. 
(c)  Enforcement. 
(1)  No person, corporation, firm, business or other entity shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this section. 
(2)  The Floyd County Police Department shall be the enforcement authority for this section. The county manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(3)  Upon information being made known to the police department that any violation of this section is occurring, there shall cause a citation to be issued requiring the violator to appear before the judge of the magistrate court on a day and time certain then and there to stand trial for violation of this section. 
(4)  Citations issued hereunder shall be pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 15-10-63, and shall be personally served upon the person accused. Each citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial. 
(d)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person violating the terms of this section or rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto may be punished by fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed sixty (60) days, or both. Separate offenses shall be deemed to be committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. A third violation will result in water services being discontinued. 
(2)  In addition to all other provisions hereof, any violation of this section is hereby deemed to be a continuing nuisance and may be abated by an application for injunction in the superior court or other court of competent jurisdiction. 
(3)  Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the magistrate court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. 
(Ord. of 6-28-88, §§ 1—3; Ord. No. 2011-001A, § I, 2-8-11) 
Sec. 2-7-32. - Same—Imposed; exemptions, etc. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Commercial means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. 
Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
(b)  Prohibited residential installations. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the unincorporated areas of the county for any residential building of any type which: 
(1)  Employs a gravity tank-type flushmeter-valve, or flushmeter-tank toilet that uses more than an average of one and six-tenths (1.6) gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; 
(2)  Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of two and one-half (2.5) gallons of water per minute at sixty (60) pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one (1.0) gallon of water per flush; 
(4)  Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two (2.0) gallons of water per minute; or 
(5)  Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two and one-half (2.5) gallons of water per minute. 
(c)  Prohibited commercial installations. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the unincorporated areas of the county for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subsections (b)(1) through (5) above. 
(d)  Applicability. The requirements of subsection (b) above shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. 
(e)  Exemptions. New construction and the renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section when: 
(1)  The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilet, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; or 
(2)  When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this section were installed; or 
(3)  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(4)  Units to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; or 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles. 
The owner or his agent of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsections (2), (3) or (4) of this subsection shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the Rome-Floyd County Building Inspection Department. 
(f)  Enforcement; penalty. 
(1)  This section shall be enforced by the Rome-Floyd County Building Inspection Department. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the building inspection department. 
(2)  Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this section shall be tried before the magistrate court of the county. Upon conviction, a violation of this section may be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or sixty (60) days imprisonment or both and shall not exceed the maximum punishment specified by ordinance (as set out in O.C.G.A. section 15-10-60). 
(Ord. of 3-26-91) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Mar. 26, 1991, not specifically amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 2-7-32 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-7-33—2-7-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE OF SEWERS 

Sec. 2-7-40. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this division shall be as follows: 
Administrator: The person designated as such by the board of commissioners, or a representative of that designee. 
BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
Building drain: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Building sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
Combined sewer: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Industrial wastes: The liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
Natural outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
Properly shredded garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and which is controlled by public authority. 
Sanitary sewer: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted. 
Sewage: A combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface, and storm waters as may inadvertently be present. 
Sewage treatment plant: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
Sewage works: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
Sewer: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flow during normal operation. 
Storm drain (sometimes termed "storm sewer"): A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
Suspended solids: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
(Code 1979, § 5-2001) 
Sec. 2-7-41. - Illegal discharges in other than public sewers; illegal facilities; required connection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit, or permit to be placed or deposited, in any unsanitary manner on public or private property, within any area under the jurisdiction of the county, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet, within any area under the jurisdiction of the county, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the jurisdiction of the county and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer, is hereby required at such owners' expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect the facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, within sixty (60) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within two hundred (200) feet of the property line. 
(Code 1979, § 5-2002) 
Sec. 2-7-42. - Private sewage disposal; permit. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 2-7-41, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the administrator. The application for the permit shall be made on a form furnished by the department, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as is deemed necessary by the administrator. A permit and inspection fee of an amount currently set by the department shall be paid to the department at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the administrator. The administrator shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the administrator when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours of the receipt of notice by the administrator. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, and the county health department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities unless approval of that method has first been obtained from the county health department. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 2-7-41, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this division, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. The connection shall be made within sixty (60) days of the availability of the public sewer. 
(f)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the county, unless arrangements in writing have been made with the department for such operation and maintenance. 
(g)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county health department. 
(h)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to the sewer within sixty (60) days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean back-run gravel or dirt. 
(Code 1979, § 5-2003) 
Sec. 2-7-43. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer, or appurtenance thereof, without first obtaining a written permit from the administrator. 
(b)  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: (1) for residential and commercial service, and (2) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or the owner's agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the department. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the administrator. A permit and inspection fee of an amount currently set by the board of commissioners for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and an amount currently set by the board of commissioners for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the department at the time the application is filed. 
Cross reference— Application for service; deposit, § 2-7-24. 
(c)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the department for any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer will be provided for every building, residence or other facility, designed or used for human occupancy or congregation; except that where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the administrator, to meet all requirements of this division. 
(f)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the county building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the department. 
(g)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged into the building sewer. 
(h)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building, which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(i)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the county building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the department. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the administrator before installation. 
(j)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the administrator when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the administrator or the administrator's representative. 
(k)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the department. 
(Code 1979, § 5-2004) 
Sec. 2-7-44. - Restricted and prohibited discharges to public sewer; testing, etc. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the administrator. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the administrator, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. All cooling waters containing chemicals shall go into the sanitary sewer only after necessary pretreatment as required by the administrator or by this division. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two (2) mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer; 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths (5.5), or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works; 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes and cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(d)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the administrator that the wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property or constitute a nuisance. In forming the opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the administrator will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit sixty-five (65) degrees centigrade); 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) degrees and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit; 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the administrator; 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not; 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such a degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the administrator for such materials; 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste- or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the administrator as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies having jurisdiction over such discharge to the receiving waters; 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the administrator in compliance with the applicable state or federal regulations; 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH that will cause the waste entering the sewage treatment plant, at any time, to be in excess of nine (9.0); 
(9)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, any textile fibers, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions);
