A member of the personnel board shall be eligible to serve multiple terms. No member of the personnel board shall serve or be eligible to serve on any other continuing board or commission of the county during such person's term of service on the personnel board. 
(c)  Each of the five (5) members of the personnel board created by this section shall occupy a position, designated as positions 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5, on the board as follows: 
(1)  The board of county commissioners shall appoint one (1) person as a member of the personnel board for position 1 and one (1) person as a member of the personnel board for position 2; 
(2)  The employees subject to the provisions of the Act shall elect one (1) person as a member of the personnel board for position 3 and one (1) person as a member of the board for position 4. All elections for members for positions 3 and 4 shall be by secret ballot, with the results thereof certified by the county board of elections, and entered upon the minutes of the governing authority; and 
(3)  A member of the personnel board for position 5 shall be elected by majority vote of the county officials, namely the clerk of the superior court, the tax commissioner, the sheriff, the judge of the probate court, the juvenile court judge, the district attorney and the chief judge of the magistrate court. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(E); Mo. of 12-13-88; Amend. of 2-10-98, § 1; Amend. No. 2003-001A, § 1, 1-28-03; Ord. No. 2012-004A, § 1, 5-22-12) 
Sec. 2-14-26. - Same—Removal of members. 
The personnel board shall consist of five (5) members at all times. No member shall be removed from office prior to the expiration of such member's term except for cause and after being served with a written copy of the specific charges against such member and being given an opportunity for a public hearing before the governing authority. Such hearing shall not be held unless the member has been served personally or by registered or certified mail to such member's residence as shown in the files of the governing authority at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing. Cause shall be construed to mean failure to maintain prescribed qualifications; mental or physical incapacity to act; dereliction of duty; misfeasance, nonfeasance or malfeasance in office; and absence from more than two (2) regular meetings of the board without just cause or proper excuse by the board. Upon indictment of any member during such member's term of office by a grand jury for a criminal offense involving moral turpitude, such member shall be suspended from such member's duties as a member of the board until a final disposition of such member's charges. If exonerated, the member may assume such member's duties for the balance of such member's term of office, except a temporary appointment shall be made by the governing authority to fill the vacancy where a conviction is appealed. Such temporary appointment shall continue until final adjudication of the appeal or appeals, or until the expiration of such member's term of office, whichever is sooner. In case the conviction is reversed, the member shall be reinstated for the balance of such member's term, if any. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(F)) 
Sec. 2-14-27. - Same—Meetings. 
The personnel board shall annually in January elect one (1) of its members as chairman and one (1) of its members as vice-chairman. The board shall meet in a county building at such time as shall be specified by call of the chairman. All meetings shall be open to the public, except that hearings on employee appeals shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 14 of Title 50 of O.C.G.A. (Ga. L. 1972, p. 575). Notice of each meeting shall be given in writing to each member. Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. In the absence of the chairman, the vice-chairman shall preside. The personnel director shall act as permanent secretary to the board and shall keep minutes of the official transactions of the board. As secretary, the personnel director shall serve without compensation and shall not be a voting member. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(G)) 
Sec. 2-14-28. - Same—Location. 
The personnel board office shall be located at the seat of county government. All official books and records of the board shall remain in the custody of the personnel director. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(H)) 
Sec. 2-14-29. - Same—Powers, duties, and responsibilities. 
The personnel board shall be responsible for representing the public interest in the carrying out of its duties with respect to the civil service system and personnel administration for the county. The duties and functions of the board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To propose and recommend to the governing authority the approval and adoption of such personnel policies, rules and regulations for the civil service system and personnel administration of the county as authorized by the Act. Such policies, rules and regulations, when approved and adopted by the governing authority, shall have the force and effect of law and shall be binding upon all departments and employees covered by the civil service system. The personnel board shall be authorized to make recommendation as to amendments, additions to, and deletions from the personnel policies from time to time and when such amendments are adopted by the governing authority, they shall have the force of law and be binding on all parties affected by the civil service system. 
(2)  To monitor the personnel policies of the civil service system and to serve as a review board for appeals from employees. The personnel board shall adopt such rules and regulations with reference to hearings and appeals as may ensure a fair and equitable treatment of the employee. The board is empowered to administer oaths; to certify to its official acts under the signature of its chairman or its clerk or other person so designated by it; to issue subpoenas to compel attendance of witnesses and production of papers, books, documents, or tangible things; to keep order in its hearings; and to punish for contempt by fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) or by confinement not to exceed five (5) days in the county jail, or both. 
(3)  To keep and maintain an accurate record of minutes of its official actions, and shall be furnished clerical assistance as deemed necessary by the governing authority. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(I)) 
Sec. 2-14-30. - Same—Finance. 
All costs for salaries, expenses, and supplies for the establishment and operation of the personnel board shall be borne by the county and paid out of the general operating funds of the county as a cost of administration. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § I(J)) 
Sec. 2-14-31. - Establishment of classification plan. 
(a)  In determining which class to assign a position, the specification for each class shall be used as a general description and not as limiting the department head to prescribe or alter the duties of any position. However, the permanent assignment of lower level work requiring assignment to a class of a lower pay grade may be appealed by the incumbent to the personnel board. 
(b)  Necessary and desirable qualifications for the duties and responsibilities assigned to each class are included on class specifications. Knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary to effectively perform the duties of the job are listed as well as training and experience. Minimum levels of training and experience desirable and necessary as evidence of an applicant's ability to qualify for positions of each class are identified. Other training and experience, if evaluated as equivalent, may also qualify an applicant for a position. 
(1)  Assignment of positions. Every existing position and those created hereafter shall be assigned to the appropriate class by the personnel director after consideration of the department head's recommendations and job descriptions. The department head and employees shall be notified of the assignments and shall have the right to appeal the assignment to the personnel board whose decision is final. Position assignments shall be periodically reviewed by the director to maintain the consistency of the classification plan. Those positions requiring substantially similar levels of difficulty, responsibility, supervision, training, experience and pay shall be assigned to the same class. 
(2)  Position descriptions and class specifications. The personnel director shall maintain a file of current individual descriptions of duties and responsibilities assigned to each civil service position. The position descriptions shall be written by the incumbent when possible and reviewed by the department head. The director may request a current position description on a periodic basis or when a change in assigned duties occur. The director shall prepare and maintain current class specifications for all classes in the classification plan. Class specifications are designed to be descriptive, not restrictive. They identify the types of duties and responsibilities which are sufficiently alike for the purpose of personnel administration. They shall not be used to prescribe the duties or responsibilities of any particular position in a department. Class specifications are general descriptions of positions with similar levels of duties, responsibility, supervision and pay. Other duties of similar level may be assigned by the supervisor and may not appear in the class specifications. 
(3)  Allocation of new changes or additional positions. When an additional position is recommended by the department head and approved by the governing authority, the personnel director shall assign the positions in the same manner as original assignments. The director shall reassign positions whose duties are changed by the department head. The department head may request the director to review previous assignments: 
a.  Whenever an assigned position has been vacant for one (1) year or longer, it may be considered that the duties and responsibilities originally assigned to the position have changed and the position may be abolished. If the department head resubmits the same assignment of duties and responsibilities, the personnel director shall classify and assign the position in the same manner as any other new position. 
b.  When a position is reassigned, the incumbent shall not continue in the position unless the incumbent is eligible for competitive appointment, promotion, transfer or demotion to a position of the new class while serving in the position as previously assigned. If ineligible to continue in such a position, the incumbent may be transferred, promoted, or demoted by appropriate action in accordance with the provisions of this article. When the incumbent is eligible to continue in the position, and the incumbent is not transferred, promoted or demoted, the provisions of this article regarding layoffs shall apply. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § II) 
Sec. 2-14-32. - Compensation plan. 
After consulting with department heads, fiscal officers, and other appropriate persons, and considering the rates of pay and benefits for comparable services in public and private employment, the human resources director shall prepare and recommend to the governing authority a comprehensive compensation plan for all classes of positions in the county. When complete, the plan shall provide for pay grade assignment for each class of positions and a salary schedule consisting of range from minimum to maximum rates of pay. The plan shall be based on the following work standards: The standard workweek shall be forty (40) hours. The annual work standard shall be two thousand eighty (2,080) hours. 
(1)  Probationary salary. Upon adoption by the board, the compensation plan shall be the official salary schedule for positions under the civil service system. Salary advancements shall be based upon merit. All new employees shall be subject to a twelve-month probationary/working test period of employment. Employees working under the civil service provision may be considered for salary increases at the end of the twelve-month probationary/working test period of employment. Salary advancement following appointment shall be based upon the employee successfully completing a twelve-month probationary/working test period. 
(2)  Salary regulations. All salary increases are contingent upon satisfactory performance and shall be made effective at the beginning of the next pay period. 
(3)  Entrance salary. The salary of a new county employee shall be at the minimum of the pay grade for his/her appointed class. However, upon a written request from the department head and approval by the county manager, an employee may start at a higher pay step in the pay grade according to the following schedule: 
a.  Pay grade 1 through 10: Entry level salary up to pay step 10 is allowed. 
b.  Pay grade 11 through 20: Entry level salary up to pay step 20 is allowed. 
c.  Pay grade 21 and above: Entry level salary anywhere within the salary range is allowed. Department head salaries must be approved by the board of commissioners. 
(4)  Promotional increases. An employee who is promoted shall have his/her salary established per the guidelines in subsection (3) above or a minimum increase of five (5) percent. Promotional increases shall be in accordance with the county pay table. 
(5)  Transfer and demotions. A transferred employee shall be paid the same salary that he/she received prior to transfer. An employee demoted involuntarily shall have his/her salary reduced to a step of the lower range which will cause at least a one-step salary reduction. An employee demoted voluntarily shall have his/her salary placed at any step in the lower range approved by the human resources director provided that it is not a higher salary. 
(6)  Reappointments. An employee who is reappointed within two (2) years of termination may have his/her salary placed at any step at the range assigned to his/her position provided it is not a higher salary than at the time of separation. 
(7)  Annual increases. 
a.  Annual salary advancements. Annual salary advancements, if awarded, shall be based on individual performance as reflected by the report of performance and the annual salary authorization of the governing authority. Salary advancements due to anniversary reviews shall start accumulating on the employee's respective anniversary dates provided the employee has served twelve (12) months in the class since the last annual increase. 
b.  Cost-of-living increase. Cost-of-living increases are granted when it is determined by the governing authority that inflation and other factors have affected the value of salaries that are being paid. From time to time, the governing authority may authorize an across-the-board increase in salary, in which case, all classified, unclassified and part-time exempted salaries are increased by a percentage set by the governing authority. Other exempt salaries may also be increased at the discretion of the governing authority. 
(8)  Special salary advancements. In special or unusual circumstances, the human resources director, upon request of a department head and with the approval of the governing authority, may authorize the adjustment of an employee's salary to a maximum of three (3) steps more than the employee could have earned normally under the provisions of this article. 
(9)  Longevity. Longevity is a system that provides for the recognition of loyalty to the county on the basis of the following formula: 
a.  Employees shall be paid "longevity" in two (2) installments on July 1st and on December 31st of each year. The payments received on July 1st and December 31st will be one-half of the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) multiplied by the total number of full years completed prior to July 1st and December 1st of each year plus one (1) percent of the employee's gross salary (not including the longevity payment). 
b.  For employees with six (6) or more full years of service prior to July 1st and December 1st, longevity payment shall be increased by an additional one (1) percent of gross salary. 
c.  For employees with eleven (11) or more full years of service, the longevity payment shall be increased by an additional one (1) percent of gross salary. 
In no event shall the longevity payment exceed the total of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each full year of service plus three (3) percent of the employee's salary (not including longevity payment). 
In order to receive a longevity payment, the employee must be employed by the county on the date on which the payment is due (July 1st and December 31st). If an employee retires or terminates between the longevity payment date and December 31st, then the employee will be able to retain their eligibility to receive longevity benefits. 
(10)  Overtime and compensatory time. 
a.  The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) sets minimum wage, overtime pay, equal pay, and record keeping standards for employees (who are covered by the Act) employed in federal, state and local governments. It is a federal law enacted by the United States Congress in 1938 and amended several times since. The department of human resources monitors compliance with the FLSA for Floyd County. At Floyd County, employees are covered, either as exempt or non-exempt employees unless the employee falls into a special category such as elected officials and their personal staff or bona fide volunteers. Fair Labor Standards Act requirements apply to positions and employees, not to job classifications. All individual positions are analyzed to determine whether or not the position is covered, and if covered, whether or not the position is exempt or non-exempt from the overtime and minimum wage requirements. 
b.  Employees that are covered by FLSA (non-exempt). All non-exempt employees who perform overtime work which exceeds the maximum number of hours prescribed for standard work periods which are established in their respective departments shall be entitled to receive either overtime pay at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular salary rates, or compensatory time at one and one-half (1.5) standard hours for each hour worked, whichever is applicable under the Fair Labor Standard Act (FLSA); provided, however, that no department head shall approve, suffer or permit any paid overtime to be worked by an employee which exceeds a maximum of two hundred forty (240) standard hours per calendar year (or compensatory time which exceeds a maximum of standard hours at any time), unless a greater amount is approved by the county manager. Employees who have accrued compensatory time shall, upon their request, be allowed to use some or all of such time within a reasonable period following such accrual, subject to approval of the department heads concerned. 
c.  Public safety personnel. Section 7(k) of the FLSA provides that employees engaged in law enforcement may be paid overtime on a "work period" basis. Law enforcement personnel must receive overtime after eighty-six (86) hours worked during a fourteen-day period. Under certain prescribed conditions, a state or local government agency may give compensatory time at a rate of not less than one and one-half (1.5) hours for each overtime hour worked, in lieu of cash overtime compensation. Employees engaged in law enforcement duties may accrue up to eighty (80) hours of compensatory time. 
d.  Employees that are not covered by FLSA (exempt personnel). Exempt personnel may accumulate compensatory time to a maximum of forty (40) hours. All hours earned will be accumulated at a rate of one-for-one (one (1) hour earned for each hour worked) and are not payable upon termination. All hours over the forty-hour maximum will be lost unless approval is obtained from the county manager to perform emergency work. In which case, compensatory hours shall be paid or banked. 
e.  Emergency call out. When a county employee is called out in an emergency situation such as during a storm, etc., to perform services he/she would be paid a minimum of four (4) hours. In the event that there is an additional call out during the same twenty-four-hour period, the actual time of any additional call out(s) shall be added to regular hours and paid in accordance with current FLSA regulations. 
f.  Beeper pay. When a county employee is required by his/her department head to carry a beeper and is subject to emergency call out, he/she shall be paid a stipend of fifty dollars ($50.00) per week, or the amount set forth in the fee schedule book, whichever is greater. This amount is in addition to any emergency call out pay he/she may receive. The county manager shall approve all departments utilizing beeper pay. Beeper pay may be adjusted at the discretion of the board of commissioners. 
(11)  Certification of payroll. Payment shall not be made to any classified or unclassified employee unless the payroll bears the certification of the human resources director or of the director's authorized agent and that persons named therein have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of the Act and the personnel regulation promulgated thereunder. The human resources director may, for proper cause, withhold certification from an entire payroll or from any specific item or items thereon. There shall be a single omnibus certificate prepared covering the payrolls of each department and all employees therein when all pending transactions have been completed. Such certificate shall be worded as follows: 
CERTIFICATE 
I hereby certify that the records of the human resources department indicate that the employees listed on this payroll were appointed within the provisions of the Civil Service Act; that the positions listed were approved by the county manager and board of commissioners; and the salaries are in accordance with the pay schedule and compensation plan. 
_____ Human Resources Director 
The human resources director may authorize the release of payrolls before final certification in order to avoid undue delays involving pending personnel transactions. Any person appointed or employed in contravention to any provision of this Act or the personnel regulations thereunder who perform services for which he/she is not paid may maintain an action at law to recover the agreed pay for such service. If the human resources director wrongfully withholds certification of the payroll voucher or account of any employee, such employee may maintain an action at law to compel such certification. Practices and procedures not in accordance with this Act or the personnel regulations thereunder shall be forwarded as payroll exceptions to the director of finance who shall treat such exceptions in the same manner as other audit exceptions. 
(12)  Incentive pay. After the probationary period, public safety employees who are covered by the civil service system, are certified by P.O.S.T. (Peace Officer's Standards and Training Act), and are currently actively involved in public safety as designated by the county's personnel records, and who have successfully completed coursework from a regionally accredited college or university are eligible for the following educational pay incentive to be paid on the last payday in June. 

 
(13)  Salary supplement. Any employee who routinely interprets a language, including sign language for any county department is eligible for annual language incentive pay of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or an amount set forth in the fee schedule book, whichever is greater. This supplement will be paid at the same time as educational incentive pay. Annual requests must be submitted by departments for continued participation. 
(14)  Educational assistance. It is the policy of the board of commissioners to encourage career development through approved higher education courses. These are courses completed at a regionally accredited vocational-technical school, junior, senior college, or university. They must be approved by the educational committee and must not interfere with the effective departmental operations. 
a.  Requirements for approval include: 
1.  Education shall be directly related to career development. 
2.  Course of study shall be in line with needs of the department. 
3.  Approval must be obtained from the department head and the education committee prior to enrollment in order to participate in the educational assistance program. 
b.  Reimbursement for educational expenses. The county will reimburse full-time employees in accordance with the following schedule: 
1.  With a grade of "B" or above, one hundred (100) percent of tuition; 
2.  With a grade of "C", eighty (80) percent of tuition; 
3.  With grades below "C", are not eligible for tuition reimbursement. 
The above schedule is for tuition reimbursement only. No other expenses will be reimbursed. Employees receiving educational assistance who separate from employment with the county within two (2) years of receiving such assistance must reimburse the county. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § III; Ord. of 6-14-88; Ord. of 11-11-97(1), §§ 1—4; Amend. of 7-14-98, § 1; Ord. No. 2008-001A, §§ I—VI, XXIII, 1-8-08; Ord. No. 2015-001A-1, § 1, 4-28-15; Ord. No. 2016-002A, § 1, 1-26-16) 
Sec. 2-14-33. - Recruitment and selection. 
(a)  Recruitment. When a vacancy occurs in a classified position, the personnel director and the department head shall develop a recruitment plan to open the position competitively or to open the position promotionally to employees. For those positions which are to be open to all applicants, the personnel director shall determine whether there is to be continuous recruitment or whether applications shall be accepted for a specified period of time only. The director shall prepare public announcements for all competitive examinations at least seven (7) days in advance of the closing date for receipt of applications. Every reasonable effort shall be made to attract qualified applicants to compete for competitive examinations. Public announcements of examinations shall specify the title and salary range of the class of positions, where to apply, information as to rates of pay at which appointments are expected to be made, the duties to be performed, minimum qualifications required, the final date on which applications shall be received, and other conditions of competition. Announcements shall be posted in representative county offices. 
(b)  Applications. 
(1)  All applications shall be made on forms prescribed by the personnel director and, except in continuous recruitment programs, must be filed with the personnel department on or before the closing date specified in the announcement, or postmarked before midnight of that date. The director shall be the custodian of all such applications. The application shall include a statement from the applicant that includes pertinent information regarding the training, experience and any other job-related information that the director, in accordance with the classification plan, may deem necessary. All applications shall be signed and the truth of all statements contained therein certified by such signature. 
(2)  The personnel director may refuse to examine an applicant, or after examination, may disqualify such applicant or remove such applicant's name from a register, or refuse to certify any eligible on a register if the applicant: 
a.  Does not meet any of the requirements established for the examination for the class of position. 
b.  Is so disabled as to be rendered unfit for the performance of the duties of the class. 
c.  Is addicted to the use of narcotics or the habitual use of intoxicating liquors to excess. 
d.  Has made a false statement of material facts in the application. 
e.  Has used or attempted to use political pressure or bribery to secure an advantage in the examination. 
f.  Has directly or indirectly obtained information regarding examinations to which, as an applicant, such applicant was not entitled. 
g.  Has failed to submit such applicant's application correctly or within the prescribed time limits. 
h.  Has taken part in the compilation, administration or correction of the examination for which such applicant is an applicant. 
i.  Has previously been dismissed from a position in the county government for cause or has been separated as unsatisfactory from a position under the civil service system. 
j.  Has been convicted of criminal conduct. 
k.  Has failed to submit appropriate documentation as required by the Immigration Reform and Control Act. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § IV) 
Sec. 2-14-34. - Selection. 
(a)  General. In making appointments under this article the personnel director and the department head shall ensure that applicants receive fair treatment without regard to political affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex, age, physical handicap or religious creed, and that bona fide consideration is given to all eligibles certified with higher scores than the person selected. The department head shall select for each position one (1) of the persons from among those with the five (5) highest scores on the list of eligibles when a numerical score has been assigned as a result of an examination, exclusive of the number of names. If two (2) or more eligibles have identical scores, they shall be collectively considered as one (1) score. When ratings of "highly qualified," "qualified" and "marginally qualified" are assigned, the department head shall select for each position one (1) person from the category "highly qualified" if there are five (5) or more eligibles listed with this rating. If fewer than five (5) eligibles are rated as "highly qualified," the department head may select from among the categories "highly qualified" or "qualified," provided the department head may select among any eligible listed or may request the personnel director to open the position again for additional recruitment. 
(b)  Examination. The personnel director shall, after consultation with the department head, determine an appropriate method of examination for all classes of positions under the civil service system. Every effort shall be made to ensure that examinations are fair and impartially administered and that examinations are job related and do not discriminate against members of a race, sex, or ethnic group. Examination methods may include written tests, performances tests, ratings of training and experience, oral interviews, assessment lab exercises, or any other appropriate methods. 
(c)  All applicants will be subject to a complete background check including references, motor vehicle records, previous employers, and education credentials. In addition, in employment areas such as public safety and finance where the public has a compelling interest in the security of property and life, applicants for employment, promotions, and transfers will be asked to supply additional information, as required for their specific job. A list of these jobs is maintained in the human resources office. 
To comply with federal law under the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA), Floyd County will not hire or promote anyone who may have contact with inmates who: (i) has engaged in sexual abuse in a prison, jail, lockup, community confinement facility, juvenile facility, or other institution (as defined in 42 U.S.C. 1997); (ii) has been convicted of engaging or attempting to engage in sexual activity in the community facilitated by force, overt or implied threats of force, or coercion, or if the victim did not consent or was unable to consent or refuse; or (iii) has been civilly or administratively adjudicated to have engaged in the activity described in (ii). Floyd County will also consider any incidents of sexual harassment in determining whether to hire or promote anyone who may have contact with inmates. 
(d)  Physical examination. All applicants who accept an offer of permanent county employment shall be required to undergo a routine physical profile examination, without charge, to be administered by the county-appointed physician. The bona fide occupational physical requirements for individual positions and classes (if any) shall be stated in the physical demands section of each job description. For those classifications where approved physical requirements exist, the findings of the county-appointed physician shall be final and conclusive. The complete record of all physical profile examinations shall remain confidential and shall become the property of the county. 
(e)  Special requirements. A department head may specify requirements of particular experience, working conditions, education, skill or other factors when such department head deems such requirements necessary for a position. In specifying such requirements, a department head shall submit a statement of justification as to why such requirements are needed. The personnel director may, after determining that such requirements are job related, certify in order of ranking on the register only the names of those persons who possess the qualifications specified. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § V; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § VII, 1-8-08; Ord. of 7-26-16) 
Sec. 2-14-35. - Establishment of register. 
(a)  Establishment. After each competitive examination the personnel director shall prepare a register of qualified persons. In establishing registers, the names shall be arranged as follows: 
(1)  When final numerical scores are determined on open competitive examinations for a class, the name of each eligible shall be placed on the register starting with the highest score. If the scores are identical, the names shall be placed on the register in alphabetical order. Any honorably discharged eligible, who has served in the Armed Forces of the United States during a period of war or armed conflict, shall have five (5) points added to such eligible passing score on each examination, and ten (10) points shall be added if such eligible has at least ten (10) per centum service-connected disability as rated and certified by the Veteran's Administration. The personnel director shall require documentation prior to granting additional points for veterans. 
(2)  If it is impractical to determine a final numerical score, applicants may be evaluated and rated as to the appropriateness of their education and experience and other factors in relation to the minimum qualifications for the class of positions as indicated on the class specification. Every reasonable allowance shall be made for equivalent qualifications when training and experience are desirable. Eligibles shall be listed in alphabetical order in the categories "highly qualified," "qualified" or "marginally qualified." No allowance for veterans status shall be granted under this method. 
(3)  On competitive promotional positions, eligibles may be given an appropriate examination to determine their numerical rankings as described in subsection (a)(1) above, or may be grouped as "highly qualified," "qualified" or "marginally qualified" as described in subsection (a)(2) above. No allowance for veterans status shall be granted for competitive promotional positions. 
(b)  Duration. The life of each register shall normally be one (1) year from the date of its establishment, but this period may be extended or reduced by the personnel director based on the availability of qualified applicants. 
(1)  The life of each register for classes in the continuous recruitment program shall be indefinite but may be terminated by the personnel director. The names of eligibles shall be added to and removed from such register on a continuous basis. Normally, the name of an eligible shall not remain on a register for a class in the continuous program for longer than one (1) year from the date of its entry on the register. 
(2)  Whenever a class is revised so that the qualifying examination, written or unassembled, must be significantly revised, the existing register shall be considered upon the administration of a superseding examination. The personnel director shall send to each eligible remaining on such register a proper notification prior to the administration of a superseding examination. Such notification shall be sent to the eligible at such eligible's last known address and shall clearly state the necessity of such eligible competing in the superseding examination in order to continue such eligible's eligibility for appointment. 
(c)  Removal and reinstatement. The personnel director may remove the name of an eligible from a register for any of the causes stipulated below: 
(1)  On evidence that the eligible cannot be located by postal authorities. (The return of one (1) notice or a returned notice marked no forwarding address shall be considered sufficient evidence.) 
(2)  On receipt of a statement from the eligible that such eligible no longer desires consideration for a position of that class. 
(3)  If two (2) offers of appointment for the probationary period to the class for which the register was established have been declined by the eligible. 
(4)  After an eligible is appointed to any position, such eligible's name may be removed from registers for all positions for which the starting salary is the same or less than that of the class to which such eligible has been appointed. Such an eligible may have such eligible's name reinstated to any such register at any time before its expiration upon such eligible's request. 
(5)  Whenever an eligible's name is removed from the register for cause, the personnel director shall notify the eligible of this action. Such notice shall be by mail to the last-known address of the eligible. An eligible's name may be reinstated to the register upon presentation of reasons satisfactory to the director. 
(6)  A department head may exclude from consideration all eligibles: 
a.  Whose availability cannot be ascertained because of: 
1.  Failure to reply within a period of five (5) days to a written request from a department head for interview; 
2.  Failure to reply within forty-eight (48) hours to a telephone request for interview; 
3.  Inability to report for interview within a reasonable time; 
4.  Failure to report for an arranged interview; 
5.  Inability to report for work at the time the vacancy must be filled; 
6.  Failure to produce the appropriate license or certification required by law, regulatory authority or class specification. 
b.  Who declined appointment or request that they not be considered for appointment. 
c.  Who accepted an appointment and failed to present themselves for duty at the time and place specified without giving reasons for the delay satisfactory to the department head. 
d.  To whom the department head offers an objection in writing because of the applicant's demonstrable unsuitability for the position which is sustained by the personnel director. 
e.  To whom a department head offers an objection in writing because the applicant is a relative of a superior or subordinate of the position and which is sustained by the personnel director. 
f.  To whom a department head offers an objection in writing because employment of the applicant in the position would result in a conflict of interest which is sustained by the personnel director. 
(7)  In selecting persons from among those certified, the department head shall be permitted to examine the applications and reports of investigations and to interview such persons. 
(8)  The final selection by the department head shall be reported in writing to the personnel director. 
(9)  At the same time the department head shall indicate the disposition of other names listed on the certificate and shall forward to the personnel director for permanent record evidence of the nonavailability of any eligible passed over for that reason. 
(d)  Certification. Upon receipt of a requisition, the personnel director shall certify and submit in writing to the department head the names of available persons eligible for the appointment in order of examination scores or rankings. The normal life of the certified list of eligibles shall be one hundred eighty (180) calendar days from date of issue and any appointment or commitment from such certificate shall not be subject to change as a result of a change in the register. The director shall certify only the top scoring applicant who has successfully completed the selection process for police officer or deputy sheriff. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § VI) 
Sec. 2-14-36. - Appointments. 
(a)  Reappointments. A permanent employee who has resigned while in good standing or who has been separated with a satisfactory recommendation shall be eligible for reappointment for a period of two (2) years from the date of termination. Such reappointment may be to any position of the same class in which the employee was employed at the time of separation provided that the employee meets minimum desirable qualifications as to training and experience. A reappointed employee must be employed for one (1) year before becoming eligible for credit of previous service for longevity pay and retirement purposes. Longevity pay and retirement shall include credit for the year served for eligibility. Civil service employees may be appointed to non-civil-service positions. Assurance of reappointment under the civil service system, in such cases, must be negotiated and approved by the board of commissioners prior to appointment to the non-civil-service positions. 
(b)  Regular appointment. If a department head chooses to fill a vacancy by selection of an eligible on the basis of open competition, a requisition shall be submitted by the department head to the personnel director upon a prescribed form. This requisition may be for one (1) or more positions of the same class, and shall indicate the number and identity of positions to be filled and the title of the class to which they have been assigned and specify all other pertinent information which the director deems necessary. 
(c)  Temporary appointment. If a vacancy occurs of a strictly temporary nature, a certification shall be made of the names of those eligible who have indicated willingness to accept temporary employment. Certification and appointments shall be made in the same manner as provided for competitive appointments. The duration of a temporary appointment shall be limited to the period of the need and shall not continue for more than six (6) months in any twelve-month period unless approved by the board of commissioners. The acceptance or refusal of a temporary appointment shall not affect an eligible's standing on a register or such eligible's eligibility for a regular appointment, and the period of temporary work shall not constitute part of a working test period. Successive temporary appointments to the same position shall not be made nor shall an employee receive continued temporary appointments unless approved by the board of commissioners. No temporary appointment shall confer upon the incumbent any privilege or right of promotion, transfer or reinstatement to any position under the civil service system. 
(d)  Emergency appointment. In case of an emergency requiring the immediate services of one (1) or more persons and it is impractical to use any preceding procedure for appointment, the department head may appoint a person or persons without regard to other provisions in this article. Unless approved by the board of commissioners, emergency appointments will not continue more than ninety (90) calendar days during any twelve-month period. Any person granted an emergency appointment shall be exempt from all advantages and benefits under the civil service system including leave, holiday pay and insurance coverage and shall serve at the pleasure of the department head. Emergency appointments must be approved by the personnel director and the county manager. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § VII; Ord. of 7-12-88) 
Sec. 2-14-37. - Working test and permanent status. 
(a)  Duration, nature and purpose. The first twelve (12) months of service in a position to which an employee has been appointed, reappointed or promoted, under this article, exclusive of any time spent in nonpay status, shall constitute a probationary or working test period. Notwithstanding any previous restrictions, the human resources director may fix a different length for the working test as it applies to positions of one (1) or more classes. Such a period shall not be fixed at less than twelve (12) months, nor more than eighteen (18) months. Any change in the length of working period shall apply to all positions in the class or classes affected. The working test shall be an essential part of the examination process, and shall be used to effectively adjust a new employee and eliminate employees whose performance is substandard during the working test period. 
(b)  Extension of probation. Law enforcement offices or other employees not completing mandated certification or licensing within the initial working test period shall have their probationary periods extended. No extension shall be granted unless recommended by the personnel director and authorized by the county manager. 
(c)  Job-related goals and objectives. The department head and/or immediate supervisor shall annually discuss with the employee job-related goals and objectives for successful job performance. 
(d)  Conditions preliminary to permanent status. 
(1)  Notification of personnel director. It shall be the responsibility of the department head to ascertain whether the services of each employee appointed for a working test period have or have not been satisfactory. The department head shall notify the personnel director of such department head's decision. 
(2)  Noncompletion of working test. If it is determined that the services of an employee have been unsatisfactory: 
a.  For an employee serving a working test period as the result of appointment or reappointment, the department head shall notify the employee in writing in advance of the date of such employee's termination. 
b.  For an employee serving a working test period as the result of a promotion, the department head shall place the employee in an equivalent position in a class in which the employee is eligible for transfer, or in a position in the lower class in which the employee last held permanent status or was eligible for transfer. If such a vacancy is not available, reduction in force (lay-off) procedures shall apply. 
(3)  Completion date. Permanent status of an employee shall be effective upon the completion of the working test period. 
(4)  Appeal rights. An employee terminated during the working test does not have appeal rights to the personnel board. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § VIII; Ord. No. 2015-001A-2, § 1, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 2-14-38. - Promotions, transfers and demotions. 
(a)  Promotions in general. A promotion is the filling of a vacancy by the advancement of an employee from a position of a lower class. For this purpose, a lower class means any class of positions with a lower pay grade than the vacant position. Promotions are made on a competitive basis. An employee who is promoted shall be required to serve a working test period in the higher position. While serving a working test period on promotion, the employee retains permanent status in the lower position. 
(b)  Competitive promotions. If a department head chooses to fill a vacancy by selection of a permanent employee on a competitive basis for promotion, request for certification shall be made in the same manner as for a regular appointment except the requisition shall specify that the position is to be filled by a competitive promotion. The personnel director shall prepare a certificate in the same manner as prescribed for regular competitive appointment, but shall list only the names of qualified permanent employees. Selection shall be made by the department head and the final action taken reported to the director in the same manner as prescribed for a regular appointment. The department head in the police and sheriff's office shall select only the top scoring applicant who has successfully completed the promotional process. 
(c)  Transfers. A department head may fill a vacancy by the transfer of a permanent employee from another position of the same class, or of a different class of the same pay grade, provided the employee meets the minimum qualifications of a different class. The status of the employee in the new position shall be the same as in the original position. All transfers must be reported in writing to the personnel director. 
(d)  Demotions. In general, a reduction of a permanent or working test employee to a position of a lower class is a demotion. For this purpose, a lower class means having a lower pay grade than the position in which the individual is employed. A demotion may be made for job-related cause or made on a voluntary basis or involuntary basis. An employee who is demoted shall retain the same step in the lower position which he/she had in the higher, except that a senior officer/deputy's salary shall be determined in accordance with applicable senior officer/deputy position provisions. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § IX; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § XXIV, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-39. - Disciplinary actions. 
(a)  Employment under the civil service system shall be with satisfactory performance of duties. The department head and the personnel director shall make every effort to ensure that all employees understand their duties and are aware of the rules and standards that apply to them. Every effort shall also be made to consistently enforce rules and standards. Fairness, promptness and legal sufficiency shall govern the disciplinary process. These guidelines shall be the only ones applicable to disciplinary actions in the county. Any departmental disciplinary rules which may be at variance thereto shall be subrogated to these regulations. 
(b)  In applying these guidelines, the concept of "progressive discipline" shall be followed. "Progressive discipline" is defined as meaning that when disciplinary actions are necessary, they are gradually increased and applied in terms of ascending severity. Each action is intended to correct unacceptable behavior. With progressive discipline, employees shall be given an opportunity to correct their behavior before a more severe action is applied. The objective is to apply the least severe action which will improve the employee's performance to an acceptable level. 
(c)  The normal order of priority in which progressive discipline shall be applied is as follows, depending upon the seriousness of the offense; provided, however, that certain offenses may require more severe action initially (such as dismissal), depending upon the details and circumstances involved: i. employee counseling; ii. written reprimand; iii. suspension without pay; iv. demotion; v. dismissal. 
(1)  Reprimand. A department head may submit a written reprimand to an employee when oral warnings prove ineffective or when severe initial action is required. A copy shall be filed with the personnel director for the employee's personnel file. Included in the letter shall be a statement of the employee's right to appeal before the civil service board and an outline of the proper appeal procedures. Two (2) reprimands within a twelve-month period for similar offenses may be grounds for dismissal. 
(2)  Suspension. A department head may, for cause, suspend an employee without pay for a period not to exceed thirty (30) calendar days in a twelve-month period. The suspension may be extended for not more than ninety (90) calendar days with approval of the personnel board. The department head shall give the employee a written statement listing specific reasons for suspension. Included in the statement shall be notice of the employee's right to appeal before the board and an outline of the proper appeal procedures. A copy shall be filed with the personnel director for the employee's personnel file. During the period of suspension without pay, no payment for sick leave, vacation nor payable overtime will be made until the period of suspension has concluded except in the event of termination. 
(3)  Demotion or reduction in salary. A department head may, for job-related cause, demote an employee or may reduce the employee's salary to a lower step in the pay grade. The department head shall give the employee a written statement listing specific reasons for the action. Included in the statement shall be notice of the employee's right to appeal before the personnel board and an outline of the proper appeal procedures. A copy shall be filed with the personnel director for the employee's personnel file. 
(4)  Dismissal. Probationary employees shall be separated as provided by conditions primary to permanent status. Permanent employees may be dismissed for cause as outlined below. To dismiss an employee, the department head shall give such employee a written statement specifically setting forth reasons for the action and the proper procedure to appeal the charges to the personnel board within ten (10) days after the notification of the action in question was mailed, or from the effective date of the action, whichever is later. A copy shall be filed with the personnel director for the employee's personnel file. The essential elements and responsibilities of progressive discipline are as follows: 
a.  Department heads and employees shall be mutually responsible for all employees understanding their assigned duties, rules, regulations, policies and procedures which are applicable. 
b.  Department heads shall be responsible for prompt and consistent enforcement of all applicable rules, regulations, policies and procedures, as necessary. 
c.  Department heads and employees shall be mutually responsible for understanding and following the principles of good employee relations. 
d.  Department heads shall be responsible for proper documentation of all disciplinary actions taken. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § X; Ord. of 2-14-89) 
Sec. 2-14-40. - Reasons for disciplinary action—Schedule. 
The following are general causes for disciplinary action, but discipline is not limited to the offenses listed: 
(1)  Felony conviction or a misdemeanor conviction involving moral turpitude; 
(2)  Excessive tardiness or absences; 
(3)  Abuse of sick leave or other categories of leave, or unexcused absences without leave; 
(4)  Inefficiency, negligence or incompetence in the performance of duties; 
(5)  Careless, negligent or improper use or theft of county property or equipment; 
(6)  Violation of civil service rules, county ordinances, policies and procedures, administrative regulations or work rules; 
(7)  Willfully giving false statements to supervisors, officials or the public; 
(8)  Being under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs when reporting for work, or partaking of such things while on duty, except medications taken within limits set by a physician. Any violation of this subsection shall be governed entirely by the provisions of § 2-14-55 which is the drug and alcohol use in workplace policy within the Floyd County Code. 
(9)  Instigation of, participating in, or leadership of strike, work stoppage, slow down or artificial restriction of productive work; 
(10)  Acceptance of bribes or gratuities in conflict with this article; 
(11)  Political activity or outside employment in conflict with this article; 
(12)  Other activities which adversely affect the safety, welfare, efficiency or successful performance of vital services for the county; 
(13)  Creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment; 
(14)  Selling intoxicating liquors or drugs on the premises; 
(15)  Sexual harassment and/or sexual involvement; 
(16)  Failure to report an accident or injury on the job as required by state law and county policy; 
(17)  Violation of administrative policies, procedures or safety rules where safety of persons or property is endangered; 
(18)  Minor violation of traffic laws while operating a county vehicle; 
(19)  Serious violations of traffic laws while operating a county motor vehicle, defined as involving damages of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XI; Ord. of 8-22-17) 
Sec. 2-14-41. - Same—General statement appeal rights. 
An employee who receives disciplinary action shall have the right to appeal to the personnel board. Such appeal shall be conducted in accordance with appeal procedures set forth in this article. 
Any violation relating to drug and/or alcohol use as referenced in subsection 2-14-40(8) and/or section 2-14-55 shall be governed entirely by the provisions within section 2-14-55 and there shall be no right of appeal to the Floyd County Personnel Board. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XI; Ord. of 8-22-17) 
Sec. 2-14-42. - Nondisciplinary separations. 
(a)  Resignations. A civil service employee should present such employee's resignation in writing to the appropriate department head at least fourteen (14) days in advance to allow time to recruit a replacement. The department head shall immediately forward the letter of resignation to the personnel director by prescribed form why the employee has resigned and whether or not reemployment is recommended. 
(b)  Disability. Any department head or the personnel director may direct any civil service employee to be examined by a licensed physician or to produce medical records or other verification of condition when illness or injury impairs or negatively affects the safe and successful performance of the job. The director, considering the specific situation and consulting with a physician if necessary, shall specify the length of time and condition of disability under the following guidelines: 
(1)  Temporary disability. If the disability is correctable, the maximum time allowed shall be not more than twelve (12) months in duration. For each case the employee shall be allowed a specific time of twelve (12) months or less to have the disability corrected as determined by the personnel director after considering the physician's recommendation. If the employee fails to have the disability corrected within the specific time, such employee shall be subject to layoff, retirement or termination. During the period of disability, the employee retains such employee's right to the job upon correction of the condition. A department head may hire a temporary replacement for the disabled employee provided the person hired is advised in writing that the position is temporary and subject to termination when the regular employee returns. 
(2)  Permanent disability. If the disability is not correctable within a twelve-month period, as determined by the personnel director in consultation with a physician, the department head shall attempt to place the employee in another position which such employee can perform, if practical. If this cannot be accomplished successfully, the director shall require the department head to separate the employee through layoff, retirement or termination. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XII) 
Sec. 2-14-43. - Loss of job requirements. 
Any employee who is unable to do such employee's job adequately because of loss of a necessary license or other requirement shall be departed by layoff until such license or requirement is acquired. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XIII) 
Sec. 2-14-44. - Layoff or reduction in force procedure in general. 
A department head layoff of civil service employees may be made whenever necessary due to shortages of work or funds, the abolishment of a position, or other material changes in duties, organization, disability or loss of job requirements. If a permanent employee is subject to layoff, such employee shall be offered a comparable position or a demotion to a lower class if a vacancy exists and such employee is qualified to fill the position. Whenever practical, the employee affected shall be notified in writing by the department head at least fourteen (14) days in advance. If it becomes necessary to reduce departmental work force, the department head shall submit to the personnel director a proposed plan specifying the order of reduction of employees to continue efficient and effective functioning of the department. The proposed order of reduction shall be based on the critical skills of each employee considering the length of service in the class and in county service, the level of performance as reflected by the report of performance, and the needs of the department. The director shall carefully review the proposed plan to ensure that there is no discrimination due to race, sex, religion, national origin, color, age, handicapped status, or political affiliation, and that all considerations are job related. The director may modify the reduction or demotion order for employees as necessary to adhere to civil service principles. When the final plan is approved by the director, the plan may be implemented. Permanent employees who are subject to layoff or reduction in force shall be entitled to reinstatement to their previous status in the reverse order of their reduction for a period of one (1) year from the date of separation, and prior to the appointment of any additional permanent employees in positions of the same class. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XIV) 
Sec. 2-14-45. - Employee ethics and conduct. 
(a)  General. Civil service employees represent county government to the general public they service. Employees shall act in a responsible manner and make every effort to ensure the government business is conducted honestly, free of bias and undue influence, and that no employee uses such employee's office for personal gain. 
(b)  Political activity. 
(1)  Interference with elections. No employee shall use or seek to use, directly or indirectly, such employee's official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of a political election, nomination or referendum; provided, however, that the foregoing shall not be interpreted or construed so as to abrogate or abridge the right of any employee to express such employee's political opinions, vote, seek elective office or otherwise participate in political undertakings in accordance with applicable law or personnel regulations; provided, however, that any employee, classified or unclassified, who qualifies as a candidate for any public office shall be placed on leave without pay under the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Contributions. No employee shall be required, coerced, expected, induced or encouraged as a condition of employment in any form whatsoever to make any contribution, loan, subscription or assessment for any political campaign, candidate or organization or for any other political purpose and no employee shall use, seek or promise to use such employee's official authority or influence, directly or indirectly, in connection with the solicitation or receipt of any such contribution, loan, subscription or assessment. 
(3)  Undue influence. No employee shall use, seek or promise to use, directly or indirectly, such employee's official authority or influence to secure for any person a position, promotion, pay increase or other employment advantage or consideration with respect to the classified service or specialized treatment or consideration with respect to any official function or operation of the county. 
(c)  Acceptance of gifts and gratuities. An employee under the civil service system shall not accept gifts, gratuities or loans from organizations, business concerns or individuals with whom such employee has official business relationships. These limitations are not intended to prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally, nor to prohibit employees from accepting social courtesies which promote good public relations, nor to prohibit employees from obtaining loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that inspectors, contracting officers and enforcement officers guard against relationships which might be construed as evidence of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. Any employee who accepts bribes, gifts, gratuities or other unfair considerations shall be subject to disciplinary action and/or dismissal. 
(d)  Employment other than in county. An employee under the civil service system may not accept employment in addition to county employment if such employment interferes with the performance of the county position, if there is a conflict of interest, if employment occurs during county working hours or if employment involves performing the duties that should be performed during county employment. Failure to comply with this subsection by any covered employee will constitute grounds for dismissal. 
(e)  Nepotism (employment of relatives restricted). To prevent preferential or discriminatory treatment in the workplace based upon family or dating relationships, the following policy will be made upon adoption by the county commission: 
(1)  No person who is a "family member" of the county manager shall be eligible for employment with the county. 
(2)  No employee of the county, shall be allowed to work under the immediate supervision or in the direct line of authority of a "family member" or someone with whom he or she is having a "dating relationship." 
(3)  The term "immediate supervision" includes the responsibility and accountability for assigning work, evaluating performance, hiring, disciplining, or training. 
(4)  The term "direct line of authority" includes an employee's immediate supervisor and each direct level of supervision all the way up to the top supervisory employee. 
(5)  The term "family member" includes a spouse, parent, brother, sister, step-parent, child, step-child, grandparent, grandchild, or the same by relation of the employees' marriage. 
(6)  The term "dating relationship" is defined as an intimate relationship, primarily characterized by the expectation of romantic affection or sexual involvement. The term "dating relationship" does not include a casual relationship or ordinary association between persons in a business or social context. 
(7)  In the event that any two (2) employees, subsequent to their hiring, develop a dating relationship or become family members, the more senior employee (by position, not years of service) has a duty to immediately inform his or her supervisor or another employee in that direct line of authority. Thereafter, either employee may voluntarily apply for a lateral transfer (out of the direct line of authority of the family member/dating partner) within the departments of the county or may resign. If the senior employee fails to inform a supervisor OR if both employees refuse to voluntarily resign or transfer, both employees shall be in violation of this policy and may be subject to immediate dismissal. 
(8)  Also, if an employee applies for a lateral transfer and is either (1) not qualified, (2) denied a position for other legitimate reasons, or (3) no position is available, one (1) of the family members/dating partners must elect to resign or be dismissed. 
(9)  A subsequent "break-up" of a dating or family relationship will be individually evaluated by the personnel director as to whether and how this policy should continue to apply. 
(10)  Notwithstanding the foregoing: 
a.  Those individuals in violation of this nepotism policy at the time of its adoption shall not be subject to this policy with respect to those existing family relationships. 
b.  This policy shall not apply to any elected official of Floyd County, Georgia, nor shall it apply to any employee who is a family member as outlined above to an elected official if said employee is employed with Floyd County, Georgia, at the time the elected official assumes the duties and responsibilities of said office. 
c.  This policy shall also not apply to any employee who is in a dating relationship with an elected official at the time the elected official assumes the duties and responsibilities of said office. 
(f)  Residency. All county department heads not subject to subsection (1) below shall, if at all practical, be residents of the county at the time of their appointment or shall become residents of the county within six (6) months of their appointment. 
(1)  All county employees and/or department heads listed below shall, as a condition to employment with floyd county, be required to live within a twenty-five-mile radius of the employees' assigned work station. All affected personnel shall have one (1) year from the date of the enactment of Ordinance No. 2000-006A (January 9, 2001) to comply with said twenty-five-mile radius requirement. The affected personnel are as follows: (a) county manager, (b) county police chief, (c) county public works director, (d) county utilities administrator, (e) county correctional institute warden, (f) EMA director, (g) 911 director, (h) facilities manager, (i) airport manager, (j) animal control director. 
(2)  The purpose of this section is to make the affected personnel available for prompt emergency response in matters affecting the county. 
(g)  Use of county equipment. No employee of the county shall use any county-owned equipment and/or vehicles outside of the county, except in the following instances: 
(1)  As authorized by the board of commissioners in response to a request from another governmental agency. 
(2)  In response to a mutual aid agreement the board of commissioners has entered into with another governmental agency. 
(3)  During the course of executing a job function essential to county operations (i.e. transporting inmates, hauling supplies such as rock from a location outside of the county, hauling recyclables to a vendor outside the county, transporting equipment to a repair shop outside of the county). 
(4)  Travel to and from seminars, training, conferences, meetings, etc. as authorized by a department head. 
(5)  As part of a statewide or regional task force as authorized by the police chief or sheriff. 
(6)  Escorting athletic teams affiliated with the county school system out of the county if specifically requested to do so. 
(h)  Official Internet and online use policy. 
(1)  Policy and purpose. Officials and employees of the county may be authorized to use the Internet and applicable online services for the support of all county tasks. Use of the Internet is public and a privilege, not a right, which may be revoked at any time for unacceptable use. The county retains the right to keep, retrieve and monitor all access to Internet and online service activity, but only for good cause and when there is a strong likelihood that said access is being abused and/or there is unacceptable use. Restrictions may be placed on the use of the Internet or online services to protect the county and its resources. 
(2)  Definitions. As used in this document, the term: 
a.  Department head means the head of a department or agency, or the department head's designee. 
b.  Home page means the county's information page(s) on the Internet/World Wide Web. The county's home page will contain comprehensive information for the public on county services. 
c.  Malicious code means computer viruses or other programs introduced purposely to disrupt, destroy or damage county information technology. 
d.  Official provider means an Internet service provider officially selected for use by the county departments through a county request for proposal (RFP) or competitive bid process. 
(3)  Standards. 
a.  Official provider. Official county Internet service providers will be selected based on standard purchasing policies. 
1.  Other providers. A department may use a different, free, state agency or university account in lieu of a county account, provided use of those accounts is consistent with county policies and provides a legitimate benefit. 
2.  Reserved. 
b.  Acceptable use. Acceptable uses for the Internet will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
1.  Research/education. Communication with professional associations, other governments, universities, businesses and/or individuals associated with the facilitation of county business, research and education efforts, as authorized by a department head. 
2.  General public. Distribution of information to the general public, whereby such information is made available under county guidelines and policies for the release of information and the Freedom of Information Act. 
3.  Incidental communication. Incidental communication among county employees and professional colleagues which facilitates work assignments and professional discussion in a work-related field of knowledge. 
c.  Unacceptable use. Unacceptable uses for the Internet will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
1.  Personal use. Personal use not related to the conduct of work on behalf of the county or other organizations as set forth in agreements or contracts with the county. 
2.  Unlawful access. Efforts to gain unlawful access to information or computer and communications resources. 
3.  Malicious code. Intentional introduction of, or experimentation with, malicious code such as computer worms or viruses. 
4.  No county affiliation. Illegal, fraudulent or malicious activity; political activity; religious promotion; or activity on behalf of organizations or individuals having no affiliation with the county. 
5.  Copyright/patent violations. Transmission of materials in violation of applicable copyright laws or patents. 
6.  Contractual agreements. Entering into contractual agreements via the Internet or making statements on the Internet that may be interpreted as contractual. 
7.  Work interference. Sending of messages likely to result in the loss of recipients' work or systems, and any other types of use that could cause congestion of the network or otherwise interfere with the work of others. 
8.  Obscene/profane. Generating, receiving, viewing, storing, transmitting or other use of data or other matter which is abusive, profane or offensive to a reasonable person. 
9.  Confidential information. Transmitting confidential information using the Internet. 
10.  Web page. To insure a uniform county web presentation, development of a web or home page for personal or department purposes is not permitted on a county account, unless previously authorized by the county manager. 
d.  Costs. The county will financially support Internet or other online service accounts for employees under the following circumstances: 
1.  Budgeted. Funding must be available within a department's adopted budget. 
2.  Departmental regulation. A department head will monitor all usage and costs. 
3.  Efficient/effective use. Users have selected the Internet or another online service as the most efficient and cost-effective tool in comparison with all other communications tools, such as telephone, mail, e-mail or interoffice memos. 
4.  Additional costs. No additional Internet account costs (e.g., upgrading browsers) may be incurred by a user without consent of the department head. 
e.  Procedures. 
1.  Access. A department will register each of its users' names with the MIS department before any outside service is accessed. 
2.  Usage request. A user and the user's department head must complete and sign an Internet/online services use request and return it to MIS before a user name is assigned and access to the Internet is allowed on a county-owned account. 
3.  Remote access. An employee may access a county account from a remote location other than the site designated for that account, (e.g., telecommuting or checking e-mail while away from the office on business) only with the approval of the employee's supervisor and only for county business. 
4.  Signature line. All users must establish a signature line at the bottom of every message that includes the user's name, department and telephone number. 
5.  Anti-virus scans. Files from outside sources, including the Internet, must be scanned by the user or the user's department with anti-virus software before first use. 
6.  Compliance review. Violations of the Internet policy and procedures will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis by the department head. Violations may result in disciplinary action, and may include referral of a case to the appropriate authorities for civil or criminal prosecution. 
i.  Random audits. MIS may make random internal audits of Internet or online use. 
ii.  County examinations. MIS and/or the county have the right to examine any information sent via the Internet. 
f.  Periodic review. These procedures and standards will be reviewed at least every two (2) years by the MIS department, who will make recommendations to the county manager concerning any changes that need to be made. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XV; Amend. of 4-7-98, § 1; Amend. of 7-28-98 (2), § 1; Amend. of 9-8-98(2), § 1; Amend. of 10-13-98, § 1; Amend. of 3-23-99(2), § 1; Ord. No. 2000-002A, § 3, 6-27-00; Ord. No. 2000-006A, § 1, 1-9-01; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § VIII, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-46. - Abandonment of position. 
An employee who, without valid reasons, fails to report to work for three (3) consecutive workdays without authorized leave shall be separated from the payroll and shall be reported in writing to the personnel director by the department head as having abandoned such employee's position. Such employee shall not be eligible for reemployment. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XVI) 
Sec. 2-14-47. - Retirement. 
When an employee intends to retire, except in cases of emergency, thirty (30) days' notice must be presented to the personnel director by the department head to ensure proper recruitment and training of a replacement. An employee may retire earlier, provided such employee meets the requirements outlined in the approved county retirement plan. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XVII) 
Sec. 2-14-48. - Deaths. 
Deaths. The department head shall report the death of an employee to the director. Payment for accumulated leave and salary shall be made to the estate of the deceased. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XVIII; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § IX, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-49. - Attendance and leave. 
(a)  Attendance and work hours. The established work period for Floyd County is forty (40) hours per week. However, a department head shall establish the hours of attendance for employees under his/her direction subject to the approval of the county manager and may make other regulations in regard to attendance, as necessary. 
(b)  Vacation (annual leave). Employees are encouraged to use their vacation time. No employee shall receive pay in lieu of vacation time taken. Annual leave is accrued on unbroken service per the following schedule: 

 
(c)  Request for leave. A request for annual leave shall be submitted in writing by an employee to such employee's immediate supervisor and/or department head on a form designated by the personnel director. Leave may be taken only after approval by the department head or such department head's authorized representative, and only when an employee's absence will not greatly burden the work schedule of the department. 
(d)  Maximum allowable accumulation. Annual leave may be accumulated to a maximum of four hundred eighty (480) hours. Leave accumulated beyond four hundred eighty (480) hours shall be forfeited with no compensation. 
(e)  Payment of unused leave. When an employee is separated from a civil service position such employee shall be paid for all unused annual leave provided such employee has been cleared of all county property issued to such employee and has no outstanding liabilities or debts to the county. Annual leave with pay shall not be paid or granted to emergency or per diem employees. Permanent part-time employees shall earn leave in proportion to the number of hours worked.
