(f)  Nonworkdays. Employees are charged with annual leave for absence only on days which they would otherwise work and receive pay. No charge is made against annual leave for absences on holidays and nonwork or snow days established by the governing authority. If the county government is officially closed due to snow or inclement weather conditions, employees shall receive regular pay without deductions to vacation or sick leave. Any employee who, by the nature of their work, is required to work a regularly scheduled shift on an official county closing due to inclement weather conditions or snow day shall be credited with a day of annual leave for each such day worked or a portion thereof. In the event that there is an emergency call out, the emergency call out policy would apply. 
(g)  Official business. An employee who is on official business is not on leave and should always conduct himself or herself in a manner becoming to Floyd County Government. 
(h)  Holidays. Civil service employees shall be entitled to the following paid holidays: 

 
(1)  If a holiday falls on Saturday, it will be observed the preceding Friday. If a holiday falls on Sunday, it will be observed the following Monday. If Christmas Day falls on Saturday, it and Christmas Eve will be observed on the previous Thursday and Friday. If Christmas Day falls on Sunday, Christmas Eve will be observed on Friday, and Christmas Day will be observed on Monday. If Christmas Day falls on Monday, Christmas Eve will be observed on Monday and Christmas Day will be observed on Tuesday. 
(2)  Any employee, who by the nature of their work, is required to work a regularly scheduled shift on a county holiday, shall be credited with a day of annual leave for each such holiday worked. Any employee who would ordinarily be off on a holiday, but is required to work as a result of an emergency, shall be paid for the holiday hours worked at the applicable overtime rate. 
(i)  Sick leave and sick leave buy back policy. 
(1)  Rate of accrual. Employees under the civil service shall accrue sick leave at the rate of eight 3.69 hours biweekly. There is no maximum accumulation. 
(2)  Sick leave usage. An employee may use sick leave upon approval of the department head for absence due to illness or injury; for absence necessitated by exposure to contagious disease which would endanger others by such employee's attendance; for absence due to dental treatment; for absence due to preventive medical care; or for absence due to illness, accident, or death of the employee's immediate family requiring the employee's presence. In case of accidental injury or occupational disease where compensation is payable under Georgia Worker's Compensation Act, the employee may utilize sick leave during the period of disability only to the extent of the difference between such compensation and the employee's regular salary as provided in this article. A request shall be submitted before leave usage, when possible, or immediately upon return from illness or injury. 
(3)  Certification by physician. A medical certificate signed by a licensed physician may be required by a department head to substantiate a request for sick leave for the following reasons: 
a.  Any period of absence consisting of three (3) or more consecutive working days. 
b.  To support a request for sick leave during a period when the employee is on vacation leave. 
c.  Leave of any duration, if absence from duty recurs frequently or habitually, provided the employee has been warned that a certificate will be required. 
(4)  Payment of unused leave. Employees in good standing, with ten (10) or more years of service, the last five (5) being continuous, shall be paid in a single payment at termination for unused sick leave according to the following schedule: 
a.  Persons employed after January 1, 1983 shall be paid a maximum of ninety (90) days (seven hundred twenty (720) hours) of unused leave. 
b.  Persons employed before January 1, 1983 with ninety (90) days (seven hundred twenty (720) hours) of unused sick leave or less shall be paid for their unused sick leave to a maximum of ninety (90) days (seven hundred twenty (720) hours). 
c.  Persons employed before January 1, 1983 with more than ninety (90) days (seven hundred twenty (720) hours) of unused sick leave shall be paid for that amount or the amount at termination, whichever is less. Any unused leave days not paid at termination shall be credited as service for the purpose of computing retirement. 
d.  If payment is made to an employee, before termination, who qualifies as provided in subsections 1, 2 and 3 above, such payment will be deducted from the maximum amount payable to the employee at termination. The employee may continue to use accrued leave. 
e.  Persons employed after the effective date of these policies shall not be paid for unused sick leave upon termination. 
(5)  Permanent part-time employees. Sick leave with pay shall not be granted to emergency or per diem employees. Permanent part-time employees shall earn leave in proportion to the number of hours worked. 
(6)  Extended illness. If an absence, because of illness, extends beyond the sick leave accrued to the credit of an employee, such additional time will be charged to accrued annual leave. If all accrued sick and annual leave is used, the employee will be granted leave-without-pay or dismissed. 
(7)  Sick leave buy back policy. 
a.  Term. The sick leave buy back policy will be initiated on November 1, for a twelve-month period each year. Beginning November 1, 2008, employees shall be eligible for sick leave buy back based on the number of sick leave days that the employee used during the preceding twelve-month period. A "day" is defined as any eight-hour period based on the normal operation day of your department in a twenty-four-hour period. Any days taken in a no pay status or as sick time used pursuant to a workers' compensation injury will be counted as sick time usage. 
b.  Eligibility. 
(1)  To be eligible for sick leave buy back policy, the employee must: 
i.  Have accrued at least ninety-six (96) hours of sick leave each program year; and 
ii.  Complete and return the sick leave buy back form after November but prior to December of each year to confirm the employee's incentive pay and request buy back of sick leave. 
(2)  If an employee has used three (3) or more days of sick leave in the previous year, said employee is not eligible for sick leave buy back. 
c.  Employees eligible for sick leave buy back will be paid on the last payday of December. 
d.  Eligible employees shall have the option to sell back unused sick days as follows: 

 
(j)  Military leave. 
(1)  Any permanent employee who joins the military forces of the United States or who is inducted by the Selective Service shall, upon request, be placed on military leave without pay for the initial term of enlistment not to exceed five (5) years maximum. Time limits for returning to work depend on the duration of the orders. The rules are: Service of one (1) to thirty (30) days: The beginning of the first regularly scheduled work period on the first full day following completion of service and expiration of an eight-hour rest period. Service of thirty-one (31) to one hundred eighty (180) days: fourteen (14) days after completion of military duty. Service of one hundred eighty-one (181) days or more: ninety (90) days after completion of military duty. The employee shall be entitled to the same or comparable position, including seniority, status, and pay, if application is made within the appropriate period, as described above. The discharges must be classified as other than dishonorable and the employee must be physically and mentally capable of performing the work of the position. The returning employee shall also be entitled to any increases in salary (including cost-of-living increases) or any advancement in grade which would normally be accorded the incumbent of the position, with exception of any increases or advancement in grade which would normally be dependent on meritorious performance of duties of the position. Re-employment shall not necessitate the laying off of another person who was appointed at an earlier date than the person returning from military leave. 
(2)  Any permanent employee who is a member of the National Guard or Military Reserve of the United States shall be allowed a leave of absence, with full pay and benefits not to exceed eighteen (18) calendar days during any calendar year, to attend training and not to exceed thirty (30) days during any calendar year if activated by the governor. Such leave shall not be charged to any other category of leave. The employee must present proper military orders and/or other documentation to the personnel director in order to receive military leave. 
(k)  Court leave. 
(1)  Jury duty. An employee called for jury duty shall be granted court leave and shall be excused from work upon presentation of a court notice to such employee's department head to that effect. The employee shall be paid such employee's regular pay provided such employee submits evidence of actual days spent in court. The employee must return to work promptly when dismissed or released by the court. Jury duty fees will be kept by the employee. 
(2)  Subpoenas. Employees subpoenaed as a witness for the court shall be excused from work upon presentation of a subpoena to the department head to that effect. The employee may avail such employee of annual leave for the time spent in court, unless the subpoena is for a work-related matter, in which case the employee will be paid such employee's regular pay provided such employee submits evidence of the actual days spent in court. Witness fees will be kept by the employee. 
(l)  Funeral leave. Funeral leave of up to three (3) working days will be granted with pay for an employee absent from duty as a result of death in the immediate family. Funeral leave shall not be charged to sick or annual leave. All funeral leave must be approved by the human resources director. Immediate family is defined as: spouse, son, daughter, parent, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, or step-father, step-mother, step-son, or step-daughter or any relative domiciled in an employee's household. 
(m)  Leave without pay. A department head, upon written request of a permanent employee, may grant a leave of absence without pay for any period of twelve (12) months or less. The department head shall immediately notify the director in writing of the approved leave-without-pay status of the employee and the proposed return date. A department head may refill the position on a temporary basis. 
Leave without pay shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Leave without pay shall be granted only when it will not adversely affect the interest of the department and the county government. 
(2)  Failure of an employee to return to work at the expiration of approved leave shall be considered as absent without leave and grounds for disciplinary action and/or dismissal. 
(3)  An employee granted leave of absence who wishes to return before the leave period has expired shall be required to notify his/her department head immediately. Upon approval of the department head, the employee shall be permitted to return to work. 
(4)  No sick leave, annual leave, longevity, retirement, nor credit toward merit increases will be earned by an employee for the time the employee is on leave without pay. 
(5)  An employee shall return from leave without pay in the same classification and pay status. 
(6)  An employee, while on an authorized leave of absence without pay, shall not obtain either part-time or full-time employment elsewhere without the approval of the department head. 
A department head may grant a working test employee a leave of absence without pay for a period of fourteen (14) days or less. The department head shall immediately notify the director in writing of the approved leave and the return date. An employee's working test shall be extended by the number of days leave without pay status, and no leave shall be earned for any month the employee was in a non-pay status. Valid reason for the leave of absence must be presented to the department head prior to his/her approval. examples of such reasons include maternity, temporary spouse transfer and personal, non-business related problems. 
(n)  Nondisciplinary, administrative leave. 
(1)  Relieving of duty. An employee may be placed in a nondisciplinary, administrative leave status without loss of pay, benefits, seniority or other status when it is necessary to conduct a fact-finding investigation around circumstances requiring clarification of possible wrong doings or possible rule violations. An employee may also be placed on nondisciplinary, administrative leave status to protect such employee's health, welfare or safety because of unfavorable or possible harmful work situations of a temporary nature. A department head shall immediately notify the personnel director when an employee is placed on administrative leave. 
(2)  Employee's status. When an employee is placed on nondisciplinary, administrative leave, every effort shall be made to protect the property and liberty interest of the employee so that there is no loss of pay, benefits, seniority or status. The personnel records of the employee shall reflect only that the employee was placed on administrative leave for period. Such action shall clearly indicate nonprejudicial status implying neither guilt nor innocence, and shall not reflect adversely on the employee's standing with the county government in any future personnel action. 
(3)  Employee's rights during administrative leave. During the investigation to determine facts or to clarify circumstances, the employee placed on nondisciplinary, administrative leave shall be provided with preliminary findings of the investigation. Such employee may be represented or present evidence as circumstances require. 
(4)  Termination of administrative leave status. Following the findings of the investigation or the ending of unfavorable work situations, an employee shall return to duty promptly without penalty, if cleared, or shall be disciplined if the circumstances indicate. When an employee is placed in disciplinary status, such employee shall have full rights to answer charges, to be represented, if necessary, to present evidence, and shall be afforded all appeal rights. Nondisciplinary, administrative leave shall not be charged to annual, sick or other leave categories. 
(5)  Incentive pay. After their probationary period, law enforcement officers with arrest powers who have successfully completed forty-five (45) quarter hours or their equivalent of criminal justice or related courses at a regionally accredited vocational technical school, junior, senior college or university, shall be paid three hundred thirty-six dollars ($336.00) on the last pay period in June of each year. An additional three hundred thirty-six dollars ($336.00) shall be paid for a related degree from a regionally accredited college or university. 
(o)  Maternity leave. 
(1)  The employee concerned shall complete an application for family medical leave and file a written request for maternity leave with her department head at least two (2) weeks prior to the effective date (unless emergency conditions prohibit the filing of such prior notice, in which case, it shall be filed as soon as possible). The request shall be accompanied by a letter from the employee's doctor certifying that she is, in the doctor's opinion, no longer able to carry out the duties and responsibilities of her position. Also included should be an approximate determination by the employee's doctor as to the period of disability due to pregnancy. 
(2)  The employee shall keep such employee's immediate supervisor informed of such employee's status, and shall inform the supervisor as soon as possible as to the date the employee's doctor has indicated such employee can be expected to return to work. 
(3)  If the employee's disability due to pregnancy-related conditions exceeds the sick and annual leaves credited to the employee, the supervisor shall inform the employee as to the proper procedure for applying for leave without pay. 
(4)  The employee shall, upon return to work, present a letter from such employee's doctor certifying that such employee is, in the doctor's opinion, able to resume the duties and responsibilities of such employee's position. 
(p)  Injury leave. Injury leave shall be granted to any county employee who is unable to perform such employee's normal duties because of an occupational illness, injury or disability arising out of or in the course of such employee's employment, as defined by law. An employee who sustains an injury on the job will immediately report the injury to the personnel director who will initiate worker's compensation and other benefits. Employees receiving injury leave (nondebit sick leave) with pay who simultaneously receive compensation under the Worker's Compensation Act shall, for the first six (6) months of their injury, receive their regular salary minus the benefits paid by worker's compensation. Any injury leave extending beyond six (6) months must be approved by the board of commissioners. Only those employees who are unable to perform their regular duties or any modified or alternative duties as authorized by the department head may be granted injury leave. Injury leave shall not accrue and shall be independent of sick and vacation leaves. A physician's certificate must be furnished for all injury leave. 
(q)  Snow days. When winter conditions affect the operations of Floyd County, the following conditions will prevail: 
(1)  All closings must be approved by the county manager; 
(2)  When a county facility is officially closed, no reduction in pay will occur. Employees will receive regular pay without deduction from vacation or sick leave; 
(3)  If the county facility does not officially close and an employee is unable to report to work because of the weather, then the employee may: 
a.  Designate the off day as a paid day of vacation; or 
b.  Designate the off day as a day off without pay. 
Any employee who, by the nature of their work, is required to work a regularly scheduled shift on an official county closing due to inclement weather shall be credited with a day of annual leave for each such day worked or portion thereof. 
(r)  Shared leave program. The shared leave program is a means for a Floyd County employee to donate sick leave or vacation leave to a fellow employee, who is eligible for and requests leave while experiencing a serious health condition as defined, and which has caused, or is likely to cause, the employee to take leave without pay. 
This program applies to all employees of Floyd County who accrue sick leave. 
Definitions: 
(1)  "Employee recipient" - An employee who accrues sick leave and who has had continuous employment for at least six (6) months preceding the serious health condition. The recipient employee must have used all his/her extended sick leave, vacation leave, and compensatory time hours (if applicable) prior to being eligible to receive shared leave. Shared leave is not available for employees in off-work status due to workers' compensation. 
(2)  "Employee donor" - An employee who accrues sick leave and vacation and has a combined balance of at least one hundred twenty hours (120) hours. A donating employee can donate leave at anytime during the budget year up to a maximum of forty (40) hours per year. 
(3)  "Serious health condition" - A serious, extreme, catastrophic, or life-threatening medical condition is a period of incapacity requiring the employee to be medically unable to work for a period of seven (7) days or more. The medical conditions includes continuing treatment or supervision by a health care provider; or continuing treatment of a chronic or long-term health condition. The employee must be suffering from an extraordinary or severe illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition, which has caused, or is likely to cause, the employee to take leave without pay. 
Any medical information forwarded to the human resources office will remain confidential and will not be shared with other employees or elsewhere within Floyd County. 
No employee shall be coerced, threatened, intimidated, or financially induced into donating paid leave for purposes of the shared leave program. 
Application to become a leave recipient. 
An employee may make written application to human resources to become a leave recipient using a shared leave request form provided by the human resources department. 
If an employee is not capable of making application on his/her own behalf, a personal representative, having documented power of attorney for the potential leave recipient, may make written application on behalf of the employee. 
In order for a request to receive donated leave to be approved, the employee must: 
(1)  Have completed the initial probationary period; and 
(2)  Provide certification from a licensed physician that the employee has a life-threatening or emergency medical condition; and, 
(3)  Have exhausted all sick and vacation leave (or provide credible medical evidence that he/she will have exhausted all sick and vacation leave before the medical condition is resolved). 
A potential leave recipient may request up to one hundred sixty (160) hours of leave transfer at one time, and may make up to three (3) applications for leave transfer within a calendar year, for a maximum total of four hundred eighty (480) hours requested per calendar year. 
The estate of an employee, who is awarded shared leave and dies before exhausting the allotment, shall not be entitled to any compensation for unused shared leave from the pool. Upon the death of an employee, the pool administrator shall return any unused shared leave back to the pool. 
Each application must include a complete shared leave request form and physician's certification of medical condition form provided by the human resources department. 
Approval of application to become a leave recipient. 
Each application will be reviewed by the human resources director or by members of a selected shared leave committee. The appointment of these committee members will be decided by the human resources director. 
The director or committee's decision to approve or disapprove a request for shared leave will be by simple majority vote and may be the result of communication by email, telephone, or other means in lieu of meeting together in one location. 
If the application is approved, human resources will notify the leave recipient (or the personal representative who made application on behalf of the leave recipient), within ten (10) working days after the date the application was received that: 
(1)  The application has been approved; and 
(2)  Other employees may request the transfer of annual or sick leave to the account of the leave recipient. 
The leave recipient or his or her representative may then advise potential donors that they may use the shared leave donation form as provided by the human resources department to request transfer of some of their leave to the leave recipient's account. When soliciting leave from other employees, potential leave recipients must be careful to refrain from any activity that might be interpreted as pressuring other employees to donate leave. Potential leave recipients and their representative must refrain from using the county's email to solicit leave by revealing a medical condition, as emailing of medical information may violate HIPAA privacy guidelines. 
If the application is not approved, the committee will notify the applicant (or the personal representative who made application on behalf of the potential leave recipient), within ten (10) working days after the date the application was received that: 
(1)  The application has not been approved; and 
(2)  The reason(s) for its disapproval. 
Requests not approved may be appealed in writing to the human resources director. 
Donation of leave. 
An employee may submit a shared leave donation form to human resources, requesting that a specified number of hours of leave be transferred from his/her vacation or sick leave account to the sick leave account of a specified leave recipient. Requests for leave transfers must be in eight-hour increments. A leave donor must retain a combined total of one hundred twenty (120) hours of leave in his/her own sick leave/vacation account (pro rated for part-time employees). If you wish to donate leave prior to separating from Floyd County (retirement, changing jobs), you may not donate more hours than you could use during the remainder of your employment. For example, if you have ten (10) working days until retirement, you may donate only eighty (80) leave hours (eight (8) hours x ten (10) days). The one hundred-twenty-hour rule still applies (see above). 
The county will not transfer vacation or sick leave to a leave donor's immediate or upper-level supervisor(s) or subordinates. 
Leave donation forms will be accepted until the total amount donated is equal to the amount approved by the shared leave committee. 
Leave donors have the choice of donating leave to an employee of his/her choosing or either donating leave to the shared leave pool, which will be used by future approved employees of the shared leave program. 
If the leave recipient does not use all the donated leave, unused leave in excess of twenty (20) hours will be re-deposited in a shared leave pool that is available to all approved employees in the program. Unused leave less than twenty (20) hours will be kept by the recipient. 
Alleged abuse of shared leave shall be investigated, and if warranted, the participating employee shall repay all sick leave drawn from the pool and may have his/her membership in the pool terminated by decision of the human resources director or by majority vote from an implemented shared leave committee. In addition, the employee may be subject to disciplinary action in accordance with Floyd County's disciplinary procedures. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XIX; Mo. of 2-27-90; Amend. of 8-22-95; Ord. No. 2008-001A, §§ X—XIX, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-50. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)  Policy. It is the policy of county government to foster employee satisfaction and to give careful consideration and attention to any complaint. For the purpose of this article, a grievance shall be considered to be any matter concerning: 
(1)  Employment or productivity that has been adversely affected by unfair treatment; 
(2)  Unsafe or unhealthy working conditions; 
(3)  Erroneous or capricious application of county policies and procedures; or 
(4)  Unlawful discrimination. This definition applies to all classified employees. 
(b)  Informal grievance procedure. An employee who has a problem or complaint should first try to resolve it through discussion with such employee's immediate supervisor without delay. If, after discussion, the employee does not believe the problem has been satisfactorily resolved, such employee shall then have the right to file a formal grievance in writing within five (5) workdays after receiving the informal decision. An informal grievance shall not be taken above the department head. 
(c)  Formal grievance procedure. 
(1)  First level of review. A grievance shall be presented in writing to the employee's immediate supervisor, who shall render such supervisor's decision and comments in writing and return them to the employee within five (5) workdays after receiving the grievance. If the employee does not agree with such employee's supervisor's decision, or if the immediate supervisor fails to provide resolution of the grievance as outlined above, the employee may present the appeal in writing to such employee's supervisor's immediate supervisor. Failure of the employee to take further action within five (5) workdays after receipt of the written decision of such employee's supervisor, or within ten (10) workdays if no decision is rendered, will constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. 
(2)  Further level of review as appropriate. The supervisor receiving the grievance shall review it, render such supervisor's decision and comments in writing, and return them to the employee within five (5) workdays after receiving the appeal. If the employee does not agree with the decision, or if no answer has been received within five (5) workdays after the supervisor receives the grievance, the employee may present the grievance in writing to the department head. Failure of the employee to take further action within five (5) workdays after receipt of the written decision of the supervisor, or within ten (10) workdays if no decision is rendered, will constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. 
(3)  Department review. The department head receiving the grievance, or such department head's designated representative, shall discuss the grievance with the employee, such employee's representative, if any, and with other appropriate persons. The department head shall render such department head's decision and comments in writing, and return them to the employee within five (5) workdays after receiving the grievance. If the employee does not agree with the decision reached, or if the department head fails to provide resolution of the grievance as outlined above, the employee may present such employee's grievance in writing to the county manager. Failure of the employee to take further action within five (5) workdays after receipt of the written decision of the department head, or within ten (10) workdays if no decision is rendered, will constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. Department heads may establish internal review committees as a part of the grievance procedure as long as the employee is afforded the opportunity for higher levels of review. 
(4)  County manager. The county manager, upon receiving the grievance, shall discuss the grievance with the employee, such employee's representative, if any, and with other appropriate persons. The county manager shall render such county manager's decision and comments in writing, and return them to the employee within five (5) workdays after receiving the appeal. Decision of the county manager shall be final. 
(d)  Conduct of grievance procedures. 
(1)  The time limits specified above may be extended to a definite date by mutual agreement of the employee and the reviewer concerned. 
(2)  The employee may request the assistance of another person of such employee's own choosing in preparing and presenting such employee's grievance at any level or review. 
(3)  The employee and such employee's representative may be privileged to use a reasonable amount of work time as determined by the appropriate department head in conferring about and presenting the grievance. 
(4)  The employee shall be assured freedom from reprisal for using the grievance procedure. 
(e)  Nongrievable areas. The following areas are not grievable: 
(1)  Issues which are pending or have been conducted by other administrative or judicial procedures. 
(2)  Work assignments which do not result in a demotion or salary reduction. 
(3)  Budget allocations and expectations, and organizational structure, including the persons or number of persons assigned to particular jobs or units. 
(4)  The content or rating of a performance appraisal except when the employee can show that such employee has been adversely affected by the appraisal. 
(5)  The selection of an individual by the department head to fill a position through appointment, promotion or transfer except when the employee can show that such employee has been adversely affected because of unlawful discrimination. 
(6)  Disciplinary actions other than oral reprimands. 
(7)  Any matter which is not within the jurisdiction or control of the department head. 
(8)  Internal security practices established by the department head or the governing authority. 
(9)  Decisions, policies, practices, resolutions or ordinances made or passed by the governing authority or the department head which are not job- or work-related and which do not contradict this article. 
(f)  Sexual harassment. It is not necessary to follow the grievance procedure for claims of sexual discrimination involving sexual harassment. Claims of sexual harassment may be processed privately by expressing the claim to the personnel director. The following policies outline actions that are prohibited: 
(1)  Kidding or joking about sex, directly or indirectly. 
(2)  Hugs, pats and similar physical contacts between employees (other than handshakes). 
(3)  All cartoons, posters and other materials referring to sex, directly or indirectly. 
(4)  Any forms of behavior which may be perceived as sexual in nature and as creating a hostile or intimidating work environment. 
(g)  Procedure for processing employee harassment complaints. 
(1)  The employee advises the personnel director that such employee wants to discuss a harassment problem. 
(2)  The personnel director meets with the complaining employee to discuss such employee's situation and to solicit facts surrounding the incident. 
(3)  The employee is advised that the county will investigate the complaint, which may include interviewing witnesses. 
(4)  The employee is asked to sign a complaint statement to start the investigation, if the problem appears to be of a serious nature and/or possible disciplinary problem. 
(5)  If formal complaint procedure has been satisfied, the personnel director will review the employee's facts and statements and interview witnesses, if appropriate. 
(6)  If the investigation supports the complaining employee, the appropriate department head will decide appropriate action to be taken. County employees will be advised of action taken after it takes place. 
(7)  If the investigation does not support the employee, then the employee will be advised of the results of the investigation, and that without support, no action can be taken. 
(8)  The employee will be reminded of the policy against harassment. 
(h)  ADA complaint procedure. Floyd County has adopted an internal complaint procedure providing for prompt and equitable resolution of complaints alleging any action prohibited by the U.S. Department of Justice regulations implementing Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. Title II states, in part that "no otherwise qualified disabled individual shall, solely by reason of such disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination" in programs or activities sponsored by a public entity. Complaints should be addressed to: 
Human Resources Director  Floyd County Human Resources  12 East Fourth Avenue  Rome, Georgia 30161  706-291-5156 
(1)  A complaint must be filed in writing, contain the name, address and phone number of the person filing it, be signed by the complainant or the complainant's authorized representative and briefly but specifically describe the alleged discriminatory action or practice and any relevant facts. Complaints must be filed with the human resources director personally or by U.S. mail. 
(2)  If a disability prevents a complainant from writing, the human resources director, at the request of the complainant, shall seek the assistance of an advocate or assistant to assist the complainant in writing the complaint. 
(3)  A complaint should be filed within thirty (30) days after the complainant becomes aware of the alleged violation. (Processing of allegations of discrimination which occurred before this complaint procedure was in place will be considered on a case-by-case basis.) 
(4)  The human resources director shall conduct an investigation, if warranted. These rules contemplate an informal but thorough investigation, affording all affected persons and their representatives, if any, an opportunity to submit evidence relevant to a complaint. This complaint procedure may also be used by complainants of ADA violations from applicants for employment. 
(5)  A written determination as to the validity of the complaint and a description of the resolution, if any, shall be issued by the human resources director and a copy forwarded to the complainant no later than thirty (30) days after its filing. 
(6)  The complainant may request a reconsideration of the case by the county manager in instances where he/she is dissatisfied with the human resources director's written decision. The request for reconsideration should be in writing and be received by the county manager at the above address within thirty (30) days of the date of the human resources director's decision under subsection (h)(4) above. The county manager may affirm the human resource director's decision or may refer the matter back with instructions about further measures to take to reach a fair resolution. 
(7)  The right of a person to a prompt and equitable resolution of the complaint filed hereunder shall not be impaired by the person's pursuit of other remedies, such as the filing of an ADA complaint with a responsible state or federal agency. Use of this grievance procedure is not a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies. 
(8)  The human resources director shall maintain the files and records relating to the complaints filed. 
(9)  The county will not retaliate, coerce, intimidate, or harass an individual who files a complaint against the county alleging discrimination because of a disability. 
(i)  Employee counseling. At any time, an employee who is having job-related problem regarding county employment may seek advice from his or her department head. Should the department head be unable to resolve the problem, the employee shall not be denied the right to discuss the problem with the personnel director. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XX; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § XX, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-51. - Appeal procedures. 
(a)  Any civil service employee who believes that such employee has been terminated without proper cause or disciplined in any way without proper cause may appeal to the personnel board for a hearing after first discussing with the personnel director. Such appeal must be filed in writing with the board not later than ten (10) calendar days after the notification of the action was mailed or from the effective date of the action, whichever is later. 
(b)  When an appeal is received, the personnel director shall notify the personnel board and appropriate department head of the appeal by sending them copies of the appeal. 
(c)  The personnel board shall designate an appropriate time and place to conduct the hearing. The hearing shall be held and determined by the board within forty-five (45) days of the date the appeal is filed with the board. The appellant and the department head concerned shall be notified in writing at least ten (10) working days in advance of the time and place designated for hearing the appeal, and shall have the right to present witnesses, to give evidence and to have legal representation. The hearing may be held in closed session as necessary to protect individual rights or the board may limit those in attendance or separate witnesses. If the appellant chooses, the hearing may be held in open session. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XXI; Ord. of 12-12-17) 
Sec. 2-14-52. - Hearing procedure. 
In the hearing of an appeal before the personnel board, the following procedure shall prevail, and the proceedings shall be as informal as is compatible with justice: 
(1)  The chairman of the board shall read or cause to be read the charges and specifications as filed with the personnel director. The chairman shall then read or cause to be read the letter of appeal as filed with the director. 
(2)  The personnel board shall hear the evidence upon the charges and specifications as filed by the department head, and shall not consider evidence beyond the scope of the charges, and may exclude evidence which is purely cumulative. 
(3)  The order of proof shall be as follows: The department head shall present evidence in support of the charges; the appellant shall then present evidence in support of such appellant's appeal. The evidence of each party may be supported by the submission of pertinent documents. The personnel board will allow each party to present rebuttal evidence. 
(4)  The employee and department head may be represented by counsel, and may present, examine and cross-examine witnesses. In addition, the personnel board and the personnel director may interrogate both parties and all witnesses to obtain necessary information. 
(5)  The personnel board, after arriving at a final decision on an appeal, shall cause an order to be prepared within thirty (30) calendar days setting forth its decision and directing appropriate remedies, if any, to resolve the appeal. The decision of the board in such cases shall be final and conclusive, in the absence of an appellate review in the courts. Copies of the board order shall be made a matter of official record and shall be furnished to all parties at interest in the matter. 
(6)  The personnel board may, within thirty (30) days from the date of order, on its own motion or on the motion of any party at interest, reopen an appeal case and vacate, modify or revise its former order so as to lessen but not increase the penalty imposed; but after the end of such thirty (30) days, the board shall not have the authority to reopen a case for any reason. 
(7)  If the personnel board disaffirms the department head on a suspension or dismissal, the appealing employee shall return to work on the workday immediately following the announcement of the decision. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XXII) 
Sec. 2-14-53. - Records and reports. 
(a)  Records. 
(1)  Written notice of personnel actions. All personnel actions regarding appointments or changes in status or pay shall be made on forms prescribed by the personnel director. The department head shall forward all personnel action forms to the director. Appointments shall not become effective until approved by the director. 
(2)  Employee records. The personnel director shall maintain an individual file for each employee under the civil service system which shall contain application forms, examinations, personnel action for, reports of performance, records of promotion, records of reclassification and changes in pay, and other pertinent documents and information. 
(3)  Applicant records. The personnel director shall maintain applicant records for employment including application forms, correspondence, examinations and other pertinent documents and information. 
(4)  Retention and destruction of records. Employee records shall be kept in their original form for an indefinite period of time after termination. Applicant records, including correspondence, applications and examinations, may be destroyed after two (2) years or in accordance with approved retention schedules. 
(5)  Public inspection of records. All personnel records of employees under the civil service system and all other documents, examinations and materials related to personnel administration shall be considered confidential and the property of the personnel director. Information which is obtained in the course of the official duties shall not be released by any person other than those charged with this responsibility as part of official duties. Personnel records shall be accessible only to the department heads and the designated supervisors concerned, the civil service board and staff, and the employee concerned. The following information relative to employees and former employees shall be made available by the director for public inspection at reasonable times and in accordance with procedures as the board may prescribe: name, classification, salary range and length of service. Other information may be made available for official purposes at the discretion of the director. 
(b)  Minutes and records of the personnel board. The personnel director shall prepare and maintain minutes and records of meetings of the personnel board. 
(c)  Employee evaluations (reports of performance). The director shall administer a fair and objective system to evaluate employee job performance. Such evaluation shall be job related and shall be implemented by the various department heads on forms prescribed by the director. Department heads shall ensure that permanent employees are evaluated at least every twelve (12) months and immediately prior to any proposed salary advancement or promotion. Probationary employees shall be evaluated once, just prior to the expiration of the probationary period. When an employee is separated from employment, the department head shall indicate whether or not he/she would recommend that employee for re-employment. All salary advancements and promotions depend upon successful and satisfactory performance as indicated by the report of performance. In the event of lay-off or reduction in force, the report of performance will be considered for each employee affected as described in these rules. An employee may appeal a report of performance to the board within ten (10) days of the effective date as prescribed in the appeals procedures. 
(d)  Amendments to rules. If, and when, it is desirable in the interest of good administration, the personnel board may recommend amendments, additions to, or changes in this article to the governing authority. Such amendments, additions to or changes, when approved by the governing authority, shall become a part of this article. All amendments shall be numbered and dated. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XXIII; Ord. No. 2008-001A, § XXI, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 2-14-54. - Accident, injury, safety violation review policy and procedures. 
(a)  General policy. The county considers the prevention of accidents essential to the well-being of its employees and the general public. Employees are expected to use the highest degree of care in the exercise of their duties, to abide by all safety rules and procedures, and to attend safety training programs as requested. Department heads will be responsible for enforcement of safety rules and procedures. Firm but equitable disciplinary measures will be established for rule violations and employee negligence. Periodic safety inspections will be made of county vehicles, equipment and facilities. All accidents will be investigated and appropriate actions taken to prevent recurrence. 
(b)  Reporting procedures. 
(1)  All accidents or incidents resulting in property damage or bodily injury will be reported immediately by all employees to their supervisors. Supervisors will immediately notify the county manager and the personnel department. Employees involved with the accident or incident may be required to submit to drug and alcohol tests. Within twenty-four (24) hours of the accident or incident, each employee involved will complete a report using an approved form and submit it to his or her supervisor for review. If the employee is injured, the supervisor will obtain the facts and complete the report. Within forty-eight (48) hours, the report will be signed by the supervisor and department head and delivered to the secretary of the accident review board. Copies of the report will also be sent to the county manager and the personnel department. 
(2)  The police will be called to investigate all vehicular accidents. Except as required by law, in the case of all accidents or incidents, the employee shall not move the county vehicle from the points at which such vehicle came to rest until proper investigative law enforcement officers order the moving of such vehicle. The employee shall request photographs be taken by his immediate supervisor or the investigative officer on the scene. Photographs shall be taken of every accident or incident. 
(c)  Accident review board. 
(1)  Composition. The accident review board will have five (5) regular members plus one (1) ex-officio member. The department heads for county police, sheriff's department, prison, water and public works will each select one (1) person from their respective departments to be a member of the board. The personnel director will select a person from his department to be an ex-officio member of the board. 
(2)  Terms. The board will select three (3) members to serve initial one-year terms and three (3) to serve initial two-year terms. After the first year, all members will serve two-year terms with three (3) new members being selected annually. 
(3)  Officers. Each year the board will select one (1) of its members to serve as chairperson. The board will also designate an individual to serve as secretary. 
(4)  Duties. The board will review all reported accidents and incidents. When requested by the county manager, it will make a determination of the county's liability for damages or injuries. Employees involved with accidents will be notified of their right to present evidence to the board, and may be required to appear before the board for the purpose of answering questions. Where the damage or injury was caused by the negligence or intent of the employee, it will be declared to be a "chargeable accident." The board will furnish the county manager and the personnel department with a copy of the minutes of all meetings. 
(5)  Meetings. The board will meet regularly twice a month. An initial review of all reported accidents will be done at the first meeting each month. All accidents found to be chargeable at the first meeting will be referred to the second meeting for a final review. At the request of the county manager or in the event of an accident involving a serious injury or property loss, the chairperson may call for a special meeting. Each accident review board shall set the days of its monthly meetings but will only be required to meet twice each month. The regular meeting dates shall be posted and each affected party shall receive a written notice of said hearing date. 
(d)  Disciplinary action. 
(1)  When the accident review board has found an accident to be chargeable, the following progressive disciplinary policy becomes effective: 

 
However, certain chargeable accidents involving gross negligence or a total disregard for one's safety or the safety of others may require more severe action initially, including dismissal. 
(2)  After the personnel department has been notified of a "chargeable accident," it will review the personnel file of the employee to determine whether there have been other chargeable accidents within the preceding twelve (12) months. The personnel department will then make a recommendation to the employee's department head based on the county's progressive disciplinary policy. The department head will review the recommendation of the personnel department and the particular facts and circumstances involved and will take disciplinary action against the employee in accordance with county policy. If appropriate, the department head may also require the employee to have an eye and/or medical examination and attend a defensive driving course. 
(3)  Civil service employees who believe that they have been unfairly discriminated against as a result of disciplinary action taken under these policies may appeal to the personnel board by following the procedures described in Section XXI of the personnel policies. 
(Ord. of 4-5-88, § XXIV; Ord. of 3-9-93, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 11-11-97(2), § 1; Amend. of 6-22-99, §§ 1—3) 
Sec. 2-14-55. - County drug and alcohol use in workplace policy. 
Floyd County aims to provide a drug and alcohol-free, healthful, and safe workplace. Employees are required to report to work in mental and physical condition that allows them to perform their jobs in a safe and satisfactory manner. Any level of use of controlled substances, drugs, or alcohol on the job may pose serious safety and health risks as well as impairing job performance. 
For the purposes of these rules and regulations, "drugs" and "controlled substances" are synonymous and include illegal drugs and legal drugs taken without medical approval or other than prescribed. Illegal drugs or controlled substances includes, without limitation, marijuana, cocaine, opiates, phencyclidine (PCP), amphetamines, derivatives and other related drugs, natural or synthetic hallucinogens, "look alike" or designer drugs, inhalants, methadone, methaqualone, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, propoxyphene, or other drugs made unlawful under federal or state laws or a metabolite of any such substances, and unauthorized prescription drugs. 
This policy applies to all county employees, volunteers, interns, and any other individuals performing services on the county's behalf, whether paid or unpaid; all of whom will be referred to in this policy as "employees". Visitors, vendors, and contractors are governed by this policy when on county property or in county vehicles and will not be permitted to conduct business with Floyd County if found to be in violation of this policy. 
Any employee who is disciplined and/or terminated pursuant to the provisions of the drug and alcohol policy shall not have a right to appeal to the Floyd County Personnel Board. 
(1)  Drug-free workplace. Floyd County complies will all provisions of the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988 in that: 
a.  No employee shall store or allow storage of controlled substances, illegal drugs, or alcohol on any land or within any building owned, rented, or leased by or under the control of Floyd County. No employee shall transport any form of illegal drugs, alcohol, or controlled substances in any county vehicle, equipment, or machine or in personal vehicles while on county business. The necessity for storing and or transporting controlled substances, illegal drugs, or alcohol on county property when these constitute evidence in criminal proceedings can be an exception to these policies. 
b.  While on Floyd County premises and while conducting business related activities or representing Floyd County off Floyd County premises, or during lunch breaks or when an employee is scheduled to return to work, the employee's use, possession, sale, distribution, or the presence in the employee's body of alcohol, drugs or a controlled substance are strictly prohibited. Violators shall be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
c.  The unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession or use of illegal drugs, controlled substances, or alcohol in the workplace are strictly prohibited. Employees must notify the director of human resources of a violation in the workplace of any criminal drug or alcohol statute that results in arrest, conviction, or a charge indictment within five (5) days of such arrest, conviction, or indictment. 
d.  The legitimate use of prescribed drugs, taken as prescribed by a qualified medical practitioner, is permitted on the job if it does not impair an employee's ability to perform the essential functions of the job effectively and safely. Each employee must notify his or her supervisor immediately of the use of any medication, prescribed or over-the-counter, which may have an effect on the employee's safe and effective performance of job duties. The taking of drugs prescribed to another person is strictly prohibited. 
e.  To assure a safe and effective workplace, Floyd County has established a drug and alcohol testing program as described in detail elsewhere in these rules and regulations. 
1.  Job applicants for safety sensitive positions, whether full-time, part-time, or temporary will be required to pass a post-offer drug and alcohol screen before hire. An applicant's refusal to submit to testing will disqualify that applicant from consideration for employment in the relevant position. Safety sensitive applicants covered by department of transportation rules will be tested in compliance with those rules. An applicant's refusal to submit to testing will disqualify that applicant from employment in the relevant position. 
2.  Employees in safety sensitive positions are subject to random testing. All other employees will be asked to provide urine, blood, saliva and/or hair samples to determine the illegal use of drugs and/or alcohol in the workplace under certain circumstances as described in the drug and alcohol testing section of these rules and regulations. An employee's refusal to submit to test will result in termination. 
f.  Education and training program. 
1.  Floyd County's Drug and Alcohol Policy and Drug and Alcohol Testing Policy are included in the handbook. Each employee shall receive a copy of the handbook and shall acknowledge receipt of such by signing a form acknowledging that he or she has read the handbook and understands and agrees to abide by its provisions. 
2.  Floyd County's Drug and Alcohol Policy and Drug and Alcohol Testing Policy will be reviewed with each new employee at orientation. 
3.  Floyd County will provide periodic mandatory training to management about the effects of drugs and alcohol and how to detect signs that an employee is under the influence of drugs and/or alcohol in the workplace. 
4.  Information about drugs, controlled substances, and alcohol including the effects of each and the availability of counseling and treatment, shall be available through human resources. 
5.  Human resources will assist department directors with presentations about Floyd County's Drug and Alcohol and Testing Policies and presentations about the effects of drugs, controlled substances, and alcohol on the employee and the workplace. 
g.  Employee assistance program. 
1.  The employee assistance program (EAP) provides confidential counseling and referral services to employees who need assistance with drug and/or alcohol abuse or addiction. It is the employee's responsibility to seek assistance from the EAP prior to reaching a point where he or she may be subject to disciplinary action for drug or alcohol use in the workplace. Participation in the EAP after a disciplinary process has begun will not preclude disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Floyd County reserves the right to require employee participation in the EAP as a condition of continued employment. 
2.  Employees may contact the employee assistance program (EAP) directly if they desire confidential counseling and or referral services for drug and or alcohol issues. No employee will suffer retaliation for seeking assistance from the EAP. 
(2)  Drug and alcohol testing program. 
Floyd County recognizes its obligation to maintain a drug and alcohol free workplace. In an effort to detect and discourage drug and/or alcohol use in the workplace, Floyd County has established a drug and alcohol testing program that applies to applicants for safety sensitive positions who have received an offer of employment conditioned on passing the drug and alcohol screen; to all employees in safety sensitive positions, and to all employees under certain circumstances as described in these policies. 
Test for drugs or controlled substances will test at a minimum for marijuana, cocaine, opiates, phencyclidine (PCP), amphetamines, derivatives, and other related drugs. The county reserves the right to test for additional controlled substances should there be a legitimate reason, such as reasonable suspicion of use on the job or on county property. Testing for positions subject to department of transportation guidelines will be for those controlled substances listed in those guidelines. 
A urine or hair test shall be used to detect the use of drugs and/or controlled substances. All tests shall be conducted at a private medical laboratory that has been approved by the department of health and human services. Test results shall be reviewed by a medical review officer who is a licensed physician trained in analyzing drug tests. A positive test result shall be followed by a more detailed confirmation test and disciplinary action will be taken only if the confirmation test result is also positive. The medical review officer who reviews the test results shall report the findings directly to the Floyd County Human Resources Director. 
Tests for alcohol shall be by a scientifically and federally approved evidential breath-testing device or the use of a swab/saliva test performed by authorized personnel including, but not limited to, a trained law enforcement officer or qualified medical personnel. If it is not reasonable to conduct the alcohol test based on breathalyzer or swab/saliva test, the county reserves the right to test for drugs or alcohol by a blood test. The employee may request that a blood test by performed, at the employee's expense, at the same time to confirm the result of the breathalyzer test. If the employee or the county elects to have a blood test performed, the employee shall be required to sign a consent form permitting the lab to promptly obtain a blood sample and report the results to the human resources director. 
An employee whose confirmed drug test result is positive will be terminated. An employee with a confirmed alcohol level of .04 or higher will be terminated. An employee with a confirmed alcohol level of at least .02 but less than .04 will be removed from duty and subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. A probationary employee whose drug and/or alcohol test result is positive will be terminated. 
County employees who are terminated because of a positive test for drugs or alcohol may be disqualified for unemployment compensation benefits. A positive test or refusal to test following a workplace injury may disqualify an employee for worker's compensation. An employee who refuses to submit to a drug and/or alcohol test will be terminated. 
Refusal to test includes: 
•  Failure to appear for any test within a reasonable time, as determined by Floyd County, after being directed to do so. 
•  Failure to remain in the testing site until the testing procedure is complete. 
•  Failure to provide a urine specimen for any drug test. 
•  Refusal to submit to observation of providing a urine specimen after instruction to do so. 
•  Failure to provide a urine sample that meets required standards. 
•  Failure to provide a sufficient amount of urine, when directed, and it has been determined through a required medical evaluation that there is no adequate medical explanation for the failure. 
•  Failure to undergo a medical evaluation as directed by the medical review officer as part of the verification process. 
•  Failure to cooperate with or disruption of any part of the test process. 
•  Refusal to sign required documents. 
•  Production of a verified adulterated or substitute urine specimen. 
If any county employee, other than a probationary employee who shall not have this option, receives a positive result on a urine drug test which results in a termination, said employee shall have the right to request that a hair follicle test be performed in order to confirm the positive urine drug test result. The employee shall make the request for a hair follicle test at the time they receive notification of the positive urine drug test result. The employee shall provide the hair follicle sample in the same manner, at the same facility and/or a facility of Floyd County's choosing, under the same terms and conditions as referenced within this policy within twenty-four (24) hours of the request. 
If the employee requests a hair follicle test, they shall be placed on administrative leave without pay. If said hair follicle sample has not been provided within twenty-four (24) hours by the employee, they shall be deemed to have waived their right to a hair follicle test and shall be terminated pursuant to the provisions of this policy. If the hair follicle test results in a confirming positive drug test result, the employee shall be terminated pursuant to the provisions of this policy. If the hair follicle drug test is negative, the results of both tests shall be placed in employee's personnel file and employee shall be placed back in their position of employment and shall continue to be subject to the drug and alcohol policies of Floyd County during the remaining tenure of their employment with Floyd County. 
(3)  Pre-employment testing. 
a.  All applicants for safety sensitive positions, whether the position is full-time, part-time, or temporary, who have received an offer of employment with Floyd County will be required to complete a drug and alcohol screening with negative results prior to being hired. 
b.  Applicants for safety-sensitive positions who have received an offer of employment conditioned upon completing a drug and alcohol screening with negative results must consent to testing by signing a "consent form" authorizing appropriate testing for drug and alcohol and authorizing release of test results to the Floyd County Human Resources Director. 
c.  An applicant for a safety sensitive position with Floyd County who tests positive for drugs and/or alcohol or who refuses a drug and alcohol test shall relinquish the right to be considered for the position for which he or she applied. 
(4)  Reasonable cause testing. 
a.  When a member of management observes what is believed to be observations of reasonable cause, said member of management shall have said observations of reasonable cause confirmed by a second member of management and upon such confirmation may require that the affected employee be tested. Examples of reasonable cause include: 
•  Direct observation of drug use; 
•  Employee's admission that he or she has ingested alcohol or used drugs; 
•  Evidence that an employee has tampered with his or her drug test results; 
•  Physical symptoms of drug or alcohol use such as slurred speech, uncoordinated movement, dilated or pinpoint pupils, or an unsteady gait; 
•  Disoriented, confused, hostile or aggressive behavior; 
•  Trouble staying awake and focused; 
•  An obvious and significant decline in job performance and/or adherence to safety standards; 
•  Evidence that the employee has used, possessed, sold, solicited, or transferred drugs while at work; or 
•  A report from a reliable source that an employee is using drugs or alcohol on the job. 
b.  Upon determination that there is reasonable cause to test an employee the manager who made or confirmed the observation shall: 
1.  Notify the department director, if possible, and remove the employee to a private setting. 
2.  Document the reasonable cause in writing at the time of the observation or as soon as possible after observation and sign the documentation. 
3.  Assure the employee is not left unattended. 
4.  Express his or her observations to the employee. 
5.  Require the employee to submit to a drug and alcohol test. 
6.  Prohibit the employee from performing any job functions. 
7.  Transport the employee to and from the approved testing site as soon as possible. 
8.  If the employee tests positive, inform the employee that he or she will be placed on administrative leave immediately and will be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
9.  If the employee tests positive, provide county transport or arrange safe transport for the employee to his home. 
(5)  Post-accident testing. All county employees, whether full-time, part-time, or temporary, who are involved in a work related accident or a vehicle accident, whether county or personal vehicle, while conducting county business are subject to post-accident drug and alcohol testing. 
a.  An employee involved in a work related accident or a vehicle accident as described above must notify his or her supervisor immediately or another supervisor if his or her supervisor is not available. 
b.  The notified supervisor must go to the scene of the accident as soon as possible and insure that the employee receives drug and alcohol testing in accordance with this policy. 
c.  The employee must receive the test for alcohol as soon as possible but no later than eight (8) hours following the accident. The employee must receive the post accident drug screen as soon as possible but no later than thirty-two (32) hours following the accident. 
d.  Supervisors of employees whose positions require a commercial driver's license (CDC) and who are operating CDC equipment at the time of the accident will insure that such employees are tested in compliance with department of transportation (DOT) requirements. 
e.  Supervisors do not have discretion to waive post-accident testing. A supervisor who waives post-accident testing will be subject to disciplinary action. 
f.  Any employee who is subject to post-accident testing who leaves the scene of the accident, except to report the accident or to obtain aid for the injured, or who fails to remain readily available for drug and alcohol testing will be considered to have refused to submit to testing. 
(6)  Random testing. 
a.  All safety sensitive employees, whether full-time, part-time, or temporary shall be subject to random, unannounced drug and/or alcohol testing. A safety sensitive employee is: 
•  One who occupies a position in which an employee who is under the influence of drugs or alcohol may cause injury or death to the employee, other employees, or members of the public; or may cause damage to county, public and/or private property. 
•  One whose job duties may require direct contact with drugs and/or alcohol. 
b.  For purposes of these rules and regulations, positions whose duties are described below are considered safety sensitive: 
•  Operating any vehicle or equipment, regularly or as needed, that must be operated by a holder of a CDL (drug and alcohol testing must follow DOT guidelines). 
•  Performing work as a POST (Peace Officer Standards and Training Council) certified law enforcement officer. 
•  Performing work that requires interacting with prison work details. 
•  Performing work as a guard in a jail, detention center, or correctional institution. 
•  Carrying a firearm for security or law enforcement purposes. 
•  Performing duties essential for drug interdiction. 
•  Performing duties which directly affect public safety. 
•  Operating a county vehicle, motorized equipment or machinery in the normal course of job duties. 
•  Performing maintenance functions on motorized vehicles or equipment that may require test driving the vehicle or equipment. 
•  Performing maintenance functions on facilities or equipment whose operations affect the health and well-being of the public. 
•  Working with confidential documents pertaining to criminal investigations. 
•  Performing duties that involve capturing, detaining, and caring for animals. 
1.  The human resources director will identify all positions whose duties include performing work as described in the list above. The county manager will review and approve the list after which the human resources director will distribute the list to relevant department directors. The department directors shall post the list in a place accessible to all department employees and affected employees will be notified of the designation of his or her position as safety sensitive. Employees whose positions are designated as safety sensitive shall be informed that because they occupy a safety sensitive position, they are subject to random drug and alcohol testing under the guidelines described in these rules and regulations and shall be required to sign an acknowledgment that they have been so informed. 
2.  Newly hired safety sensitive employees and employees performing safety sensitive duties because of promotion, transfer, demotion, or assignment to a safety sensitive position will be required to sign the acknowledgment and to submit to a drug and alcohol test with negative results before performing any duties in the safety sensitive position. 
3.  The human resources director will review the list of safety sensitive positions on a continuous basis to assure newly classified or newly created positions that require performance of safety sensitive positions are added. Following approval by the county manager, revised lists will be distributed to relevant department directors and affected employees will be informed and sign an acknowledgment of such. 
4.  No less than the minimum number of employees in safety sensitive positions mandated pursuant to federal and/or Georgia Law shall be randomly selected for drug and alcohol testing each calendar year by randomly generating an employee identifier from a pool of all safety sensitive employees. An employee in violation of this drug and alcohol and/or terminated because of a violation of the drug and alcohol use policy in the workplace shall not have appeal rights to the personnel board. 
5.  Drug and alcohol tests will be unannounced and spread throughout the calendar year. 
6.  Employees will remain in the pool and be subject to selection, whether or not the employee was tested previously. 
7.  Each safety sensitive employee will have an equal chance of being drawn each time selections are made. 
8.  When notified of his or her selection to be tested, the employee is required to proceed to the collection site immediately and must complete testing within two (2) hours of notification. 
9.  If the results of a test are inconclusive, a re-test will be ordered, and upon notification, a supervisor will accompany the employee to the testing site. 
(7)  Return to duty testing. 
All county employees in safety-sensitive positions who are absent from work for more than thirty (30) days for any reason shall be tested for drugs and alcohol immediately upon return to work and before performing any job duties. 
Employees in safety-sensitive positions who return to work from an approved treatment program for drug or alcohol abuse may be subject to unannounced testing at the discretion of the director of human resources for a period of one (1) year following the employee's return to work. 
(8)  Rehabilitation. 
Floyd County offers employees the use of counseling and rehabilitation services pursuant to coverage limitations and in accordance with the terms of the benefits programs. Employees are personally responsible for seeking treatment for alcohol and or drug dependency. Any voluntary request by an employee for assistance with his or her own alcohol and/or drug dependency will remain as confidential as possible and shall not, on its own, be used as a basis for disciplinary action. 
This section will not apply to an employee who tests positive through the testing program. The employee must voluntarily seek treatment prior to being notified of a random drug and/or alcohol test or being involved in a situation that requires a reasonable cause or post-accident drug and/or alcohol test. The employee cannot, after being notified of a pending test, self-identify to avoid testing. 
(9)  Searches. 
Employees have no right of privacy with respect to county facilities and equipment. The county reserves the right to conduct search of property, including county vehicles or equipment owned or being operated by Floyd County at any time or place. 
The county also reserves the right to search an employee's personal property and possession kept in county offices, vehicles, desks or lockers when there is reasonable suspicion that an employee is buying, selling, or otherwise in possession of controlled substances or alcohol on county property and/or during work time. 
A refusal to submit to or cooperate with a search may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
The county police department shall be notified immediately if drugs or alcohol are found on county property. The sheriff or chief deputy shall be notified if drugs or alcohol are found on jail property. 
(10)  Records retention and access. 
Floyd County will maintain records of the drug and alcohol testing programs as required in federal rules and regulations. The records will be maintained in a secure location with controlled access. 
The human resources department will keep testing records. All reports of drug and alcohol test results, searches, or referrals to treatment or the employee assistance program will be maintained in strict confident to the extent allowed by law. The county will not release employee information except as allowed in compliance with federal and state laws and DOT regulations. 
An employee may obtain copies of records of his or her drug testing results with a written request to the human resources director. 
(11)  Conditions of re-employment. 
a.  An employee who has been terminated for violation of the drug-free workplace policy and/or the alcohol and drug testing policy may be considered for rehire provided the following conditions are met: 
1.  At least twelve (12) months have passed since termination. 
2.  The previous work history, attendance record and performance were favorable. 
3.  The former employee receives a recommendation from his or her previous Floyd County Supervisor. 
4.  The former employee tests negative on a pre-employment drug and alcohol screen. 
b.  The former employee may be required to produce a rehabilitation/assessment certification at his or her expense prior to employment. 
c.  If rehired, the employee may be drug and alcohol tested upon request at any time for a period of two (2) years in addition to participation in the random pool. 
(12)  Non-discrimination. 
Nothing in this policy is intended to discriminate against any person on the basis of addiction to drugs or alcohol, or on the basis of an individual's medical history of addiction to drugs or alcohol as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. However, the county reserves the right to consider, for purposes of employment and disciplinary action, any history of criminal activity related to such use to the extent that it may lead to disqualification for employment. 
(Amend. of 1-23-96(2); Ord. of 8-22-17) 
Sec. 2-14-56. - Motor vehicle report policy for county drivers. 
(a)  Definition of "driver". For purposes of this policy, a "driver" is defined as any employee of Floyd County who regularly or frequently operates a motor vehicle which is owned or leased by Floyd County (hereinafter referred to as a "county" vehicle). Operators of private vehicles, or employees who only occasionally operate county vehicles, are exempt from the provisions of this policy. An employee is deemed to be a regular or frequent driver of county vehicles if he/she drives a county vehicle more than once a week on an ongoing basis or whose job description requires a valid driver's license. 
(b)  Obtaining MVR reports. 
(1)  Initial MVR checks. 
a.  Employee applications: If they are applying for positions requiring frequent driving of county vehicles, applicants shall be required to provide at their own expense, and prior to being hired, a copy of a MVR from the state or states in which they have been licensed covering the last seven (7) years. In addition, they shall be required to disclose on forms approved by the human resources department their complete driving history, and authorize annual MVR checks to be performed by Floyd County. If the information on the forms or MVR indicates that the applicant would be an "ineligible" or "high risk" driver as defined herein, the applicant shall be ineligible for employment in such positions. 
b.  Existing employees: If an existing employee desires to transfer into a position requiring frequent driving of county vehicles, the employee must disclose on forms approved by the human resources department his/her complete driving history, and authorize annual MVR checks to be performed by Floyd County. The human resources department shall use said forms to obtain a MVR.
