If the information on the forms or MVR indicates that the applicant would be an "ineligible" or "high risk" driver as defined herein, the applicant shall not be acceptable for such transfer. 
(2)  Periodic MVR checks: 
a.  Employees who frequently drive county vehicles, shall be required annually to disclose on forms approved by the human resources department their complete driving history, and authorize annual MVR checks to be performed by Floyd County. Failure to complete said forms, or knowingly providing false, inaccurate, or misleading information, may be grounds for disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal. 
b.  Floyd County reserves the right to obtain an MVR on any such driver at any time in its discretion. 
c.  Ineligible drivers. 
1.  Ineligible drivers shall include all of the following: 
i.  Any driver without a valid driver's license. To be valid, the license must meet the following standards: the license may not be a provisional license limiting operating hours or restricting numbers or types of passengers; nor may the license limit operation to motorcycles or motor driven cycles; nor may the license be limited to an instructional or learners' permit. (The following classes of Georgia driver's licenses shall be deemed valid: Classes A, B, and C.) 
ii.  Any driver with the following violations regardless of the time period: 
A.  Homicide involving a vehicle; 
B.  Using a vehicle to elude an officer; 
C.  Hit and run; 
D.  Manslaughter with a vehicle; 
E.  False report to police; or, 
F.  Permitting an unlicensed driver to drive. 
iii.  Any driver convicted of any of the following violations within the last three (3) years: 
A.  Any alcohol or drug related offense including, but not limited to, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs; 
B.  Refusal to submit to a blood alcohol content test or drug screen; 
C.  Reckless driving; 
D.  Negligent driving; or 
E.  License suspension or revocation. 
2.  Applicants who would be ineligible drivers shall not be hired or transferred into any position requiring the employee to drive a county vehicle. Existing employees who become ineligible drivers will cease all driving of county vehicles immediately, and if driving a county vehicle is a requirement of their position, must be transferred to another county position not requiring such driving, if such a position exists and is vacant, or be subject to dismissal. 
d.  High risk drivers. "High risk" drivers shall include all drivers whose driving history indicates any of the following: 
1.  Conviction for an alcohol and/or drug related driving offense within the past seven (7) years, or refusal to submit to a blood alcohol content test within the past seven (7) years; 
2.  Conviction for reckless driving within the past seven (7) years; 
3.  Any combination of three (3) or more moving violations, at-fault accidents, or preventable accidents within the most recent two (2) years; 
4.  Suspension, revocation or administrative restriction of driver's license within the last four (4) years; 
5.  Leaving the scene of an accident as defined by state laws; 
6.  Being at fault in a fatal accident within the last three (3) years; 
7.  Felony conviction involving a motor vehicle within the last seven (7) years; or 
8.  Any physical restrictions on driving as documented by a physician. 
e.  Management controls for high risk drivers. 
1.  If an employee is identified as a "high risk" driver, the employee's department head must choose to either: 
i.  Put the employee on probation in the manner described below; or, 
ii.  Suspend the employee's driving privileges in the manner described below. 
2.  Probation of high risk drivers. When an employee is placed on probation as a "high risk" driver, the department head shall do all of the following: 
i.  Place the "high risk" driver on probation until he/she re-qualifies for normal driving privileges under the terms of this policy. While on such probation, the employee may continue to drive county vehicles, but subject to any conditions imposed by the department head. 
ii.  Obtain a MVR from the human resources department every six (6) months for the duration of the probationary period when required by the human resources director. 
iii.  Confer with the human resources director concerning additional stipulations or limitations which may be made conditions of the probation, such as: 
A.  Loss of driving privileges for county owned or leased vehicles between work and home; and/or 
B.  Additional driver training. 
iv.  Notify the employee in writing of the terms of the probation and require the employee to sign an acknowledgement of same, and send this document to the human resources director to be made a part of the employee's personnel file. 
v.  Notify the human resources director if the employee has any additional moving violations, at-fault accidents; commits any additional act described in subsection c. (definition of ineligible drivers) or subsection d. (definition of high risk drivers); or violates any of the terms of his/her probation. Upon the occurrence of any of these events while on probation, the probation shall be revoked, and the employee shall immediately have his/her driving privileges of county vehicles suspended. 
vi.  Notify the human resources director when the probationary period has ended, and prior to restoring normal driving privileges. 
(3)  Suspension of driving privileges for high risk drivers. 
a.  When a department head chooses not to put a "high risk" driver on probation, or after an employee has had his/her probation revoked, the "high risk" driver shall be suspended from operating any county vehicle. If driving a county vehicle is a requirement of the employee's position, this action may result in the employee being transferred to a position which does not require such driving, if such a position exists and is vacant, or the employee may be dismissed. 
b.  Any employee driving a county vehicle while such driving privileges are suspended shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal. 
c.  An employee may apply to have his/her driving privileges of county vehicles restored after he/she re-qualifies under the terms of this policy. 
(Ord. No. 2008-001A, § XXII, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 2-14-57—2-14-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RETIREMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Retirement, § 1-5-20 et seq. 

Sec. 2-14-66. - Plan adopted. 
(a)  The county hereby adopts the retirement program for its employees in accordance with the plan approved by the board of managers of the Association County Commissioners of Georgia. That plan, entitled "Retirement Plan for Employees of Participating Counties", is hereby incorporated by reference herein and copies thereof shall be available for public inspection in the office of the county clerk. 
(b)  The county manager is authorized and directed to take such steps as proper to terminate the present plan and transfer the assets to the new plan, and such other action as needful and necessary to carry out this section. 
(Code 1979, § 1-4091) 
Editor's note— In the 1979 Code, a note stated that the "present plan" referred to above was adopted by a trust agreement approved Feb. 8, 1973. 
Sec. 2-14-67. - Mandatory retirement age. 
All employees of the county, except elected officials, and members of appointive or elective boards, who shall have reached their sixty-fifth (65th) birthday shall be compelled to retire at the end of the month in which the sixty-fifth (65th) birthday of the employee is reached; provided, however, that any employee who does not wish to retire at age sixty-five (65) shall give written notice to the board of commissioners, at least ten (10) days prior to the employee's sixty-fifth (65th) birthday informing the board of commissioners that the employee desires to continue to be employed by the county for an additional year. The employee shall, at the time of giving written notice to the board of commissioners, submit evidence of such employee's good health and ability to discharge the duties required by such employee's employment. If a majority of the board of commissioners in its discretion shall determine that it would be in the best interest of the county to retain the individual as an employee of the county, the board of commissioners shall notify the employee of its decision and the employee shall be allowed to continue in the employ of the county until the next birthday of the employee at which time the same procedure shall apply if the employee does not wish to retire. The procedure shall apply for each succeeding birthday of an affected employee up to attaining the age of seventy (70). All employees, except elected officials, and members of appointive or elective board, who shall have reached their seventieth birthday shall be compelled to retire at the end of the month immediately following their seventieth (70th) birthday and such retirement shall be mandatory. 
(Code 1979, § 1-4092) 
State Law reference— Mandatory retirement, O.C.G.A. § 47-2-110. 
Chapter 2-15 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Rome-Floyd County Development Authority authorized, § 1-4-20; Unified Land Development Code, App. B. 
State Law reference— Planning authority, Const. 1983, Art. II, § 2, ¶ 4. 

Sec. 2-15-1. - Rome-Floyd County Planning Commission—Created. 
It is hereby resolved that there is hereby created a joint municipal-county planning commission of and for the City of Rome and County of Floyd under the provisions of and with all the functions, duties, powers and authority provided for such commissions in the act of the general assembly, approved March 13, 1957 (Ga. Laws. 1957, p. 420 et seq.) as amended, such commission to have the official title "Rome-Floyd County Planning Commission." 
(Ord. of 8-7-58; Ord. of 4-21-59; Code 1979, § 3-610) 
State Law reference— Such Act no longer exists, but see the zoning procedures law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-15-2. - Same—Composition; terms of members; appointment of successors; filling of vacancies; removal; service without compensation. 
(a)  The Rome-Floyd County Planning Com]mission shall consist of ten (10) voting members, none of whom are members of either the Rome City Commission or the Floyd County Board of Commissioners, and two (2) nonvoting ex officio members, one (1) of whom shall be a member of the Rome City Commission, appointed by that body, and the other shall be a member of the Floyd County Board of Commissioners, appointed by that body. Five (5) of the voting members shall be appointed by the Rome City Commission and five (5) of the voting members shall be appointed by the Floyd County Board of Commissioners. 
(b)  The terms of the members shall be for five (5) years, and they shall serve until their successors are appointed as herein provided for. In the initial appointment under the terms of this section, two (2) of the planning commission's voting members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, two (2) for a term of four (4) years, and one (1) for a term of five (5) years, for each governing body respectively. 
(c)  Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing body which originally appointed that member. The appointing governing body shall also have the authority to remove its appointed members for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1979, § 3-611; Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 2-15-3. - Same—Organization; rules; staff and finances. 
(a)  The Rome-Floyd County Planning Commission shall elect its chairman and vice chairman from among its appointed members. The term of the chairman and vice chairman shall be one (1) year, or until they are reelected or their successors are elected. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the municipality, the county, or the planning commission. The planning commission shall determine its time of meetings and shall make its own rules of procedure, including any rule providing for termination of membership by reason of nonattendance at meetings. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the planning commission shall be of public record. 
(b)  The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for such work and may cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from, federal, state or local, public or semi-public agencies or private individuals or corporations; may expend such funds; and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts and contract receipts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing bodies of the city and the county. 
(Code 1979, § 3-612; Ord. of 6-10-80) 
Sec. 2-15-4. - Same—Powers and duties. 
From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then said planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (Act No. 358), as amended. 
(Code 1979, § 3-613; Ord. of 6-10-80) 
State Law reference— Such Act no longer exists, but see the zoning procedures law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-15-5. - Development authority. 
(a)  There is hereby determined and declared a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority (as more fully described and defined in the Development Authorities Law, Ga. Laws 1969, p. 137) (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.) to function in the county for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare, trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the county, thereby promoting the general welfare of the citizenry and, in the futherance of that purpose, to finance projects permitted thereby including projects for air and water pollution control facilities by industries. 
(b)  There is hereby activated in the county, the public body corporate and politic known as the "Development Authority of Floyd County," which was created upon the adoption and approval of the development authorities law and particularly section 2 thereof. 
(c)  There are hereby elected as members of the first board of directors of the development authority the following named persons, each of whom is a taxpayer of the county and none of whom are officers or employees of the county: 
(1)  Burgett Mooney, two (2) years; 
(2)  H.E. Mize, two (2) years; 
(3)  Wesley Jonson, four (4) years; 
(4)  Elwood Hunt, four (4) years; 
(5)  Lloyd Summer, six (6) years; 
(6)  Richard McCullough, six (6) years; and 
(7)  Mather Payne, six (6) years. 
(d)  Each of the persons named as directors above shall serve in that capacity for the number of years set forth opposite such persons' respective names, and if at the end of any term of office of any director, a successor thereto shall not have been elected, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until a successor shall be so elected by this board. 
(e)  The board of directors hereinbefore elected shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and preogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the development authorities law as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. 
(f)  The action taken by the board of commissioners as hereinbefore specified is not intended in any way to affect any public corporation, industrial development or payroll authority heretofore created by legislative act or constitutional amendment including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization, powers or function. 
(Code 1979, § 1-5021) 
Sec. 2-15-6. - Surface mining and soft material extraction ordinance. 
(a)  Mining means any activity constituting all or part of a process for the removal of minerals, ores or other solid matter from on or in the earth for sale of for processing or for consumption in the regular operation of a business. Quarries and quarrying are included in this definition. "Removal" means the actual process of digging or otherwise removing the substance being mined. Mining shall not include "soft material extraction" as hereinafter defined. 
(b)  Borrow pits are exempted from this section where less than 1.1 acres of land will be disturbed. This section does not prohibit the removal of earth and rock and filling and grading in any district done for land development purposes, upon issuance of a development permit in accordance with this development code. 
(c)  Mining is permitted only in the H-I district and only with the grant of a special use permit under section 2.2 as set forth in the Unified Land Development Code of Floyd County and the City of Rome, Georgia ("ULDC"). Mining is permitted only on sites of greater than two hundred (200) acres. In addition to the requirements of that section, the application for the special use permit related to mining must contain: 
(1)  Specific site plan and time schedule for completion of mining activities. 
(2)  Information on hours of operation and procedures (on-site and off-site) related to any on-site blasting that might occur. 
(3)  A transportation plan detailing routes to be used by vehicles serving the site, weight limits and traffic volumes. 
(4)  A plan for stormwater and runoff management, pursuant to the provisions of section 6.15 of the ULDC and the requirements of this section. 
(5)  A buffer plan pursuant to section 6.16 of the ULDC and the requirements of this section. 
(6)  Plans for the control of dust pollution, noise pollution and light pollution, consistent with the requirements of this section. 
(7)  A survey of the underground geology on the property and for all areas within one thousand (1,000) feet of the property, including showing water flows, aquifers and groundwater recharge areas. 
(8)  Application related to mining shall be made on such special forms, if any, as may be required by the Rome-Floyd County Planning Director or designated county agent and shall contain such additional information as the planning director or designated county agent may reasonably require. Assuming the application is complete, it shall be processed upon payment of a five hundred dollar ($500.00) application fee and shall be either granted or denied (with specific reasons for denial) within sixty (60) days after filing. And in the event of denial, the applicant shall be given the opportunity to resubmit the application without payment of an additional application fee until the fourth resubmission; whereupon a two hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) extension fee shall be payable; and the same extension fee shall be payable upon every fourth resubmission thereafter. 
(d)  Where the lot of record on which mining is conducted abuts a zoning district other than H-I, or where any point of the lot of record is within four hundred (400) feet of another zoning district other than H-I, a one thousand-foot natural buffer shall be provided. The natural buffer may be reduced to six hundred (600) feet if an earthen berm at least twelve (12) feet high is erected along the inner perimeter of the natural buffer, and otherwise complies with the design standards of section 6-16 of the ULDC. The natural buffer may be reduced to three hundred (300) feet if an earthen berm at least twenty (20) feet high is erected along the inner perimeter of the natural buffer, and otherwise complies with the design standards of section 6-16 of the ULDC. 
(e)  The removal area for mining shall be completely enclosed with a fence not less than six (6) feet in height. 
(f)  A plan for the redevelopment of the mining site when the removal is completed shall be submitted with the application for a development permit. Adequate provision shall be made to prevent excessive erosion or runoff. 
(g)  Concrete and asphalt plants are not accessory uses to mining and are not permitted. 
(h)  Blasting shall only be permitted between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. All lights on the property shall be shielded, as necessary, to minimize light pollution and prevent interference with surrounding land uses. Dust must be controlled so that no visible amount escapes past the natural buffer. 
(i)  Removal is not permitted within two hundred (200) feet of any river, stream or lake exceeding five (5) acres. Mining is not permitted in wetlands. Removal is not permitted within one hundred (100) feet of any lake or pond under five (5) acres, unless entirely contained in the mining tract, in which case removal is not permitted within fifty (50) feet. 
(j)  Stormwater and runoff must be detained for sufficient time for sediment to settle. Downstream contamination, or off-site contamination, or contamination of any body of water by sediment is not permitted. Any removal occurring within five hundred (500) feet of a stream, river or lake of any size must have and demonstrate special measures to insure no contamination of those bodies of water. The stormwater and runoff management plan shall show all such bodies of water and shall show the proposed design to prevent any contamination of those bodies of water. 
(k)  Mining existing at the time of enactment of this section shall be subject to the requirements of this section. Existing mining shall not be required to obtain special approval, but shall submit the plans in subsections (c) and (f) of this section for review within ninety (90) days of a written request by the county, unless an extension for compliance is granted by the county. However, if compliance with all requirements of this section is not possible because of the size, shape or topography of the existing mining property, existing mining uses shall not be prohibited. Such mining instead shall be considered a nonconforming use. The mining operator in such cases shall apply for and be entitled to a variance or variances from the existing requirement(s) it cannot meet, such variance(s) to grant the minimum possible reduction in the specified requirement(s) to permit continued operation of the existing mine. 
(l)  After the adoption of this section, any surface extension or enlargement of an area being mined across a lot line existing as of the date of the adoption of this section shall be considered a new mining operation subject to all the provisions of this section, including, but not limited to, an application for a special use permit. 
(m)  "Soft material extraction" is the removal of soft materials wherein: 
(1)  Blasting and the use of explosives is not employed in the mining operation; 
(2)  Groundwater aquifers will not be encountered; 
(3)  Removal does not take place below the water table; 
(4)  Such soft materials are limited to common clay and shale, ball clay, china clay, kaolin, umber, ochre, fullers earth, bentonite, barite, bauxite, sericite, sand and gravel. 
(n)  In addition to the requirements of the ULDC, the application for the special use permit related to soft material extraction must contain: 
(1)  Specific site plan and time schedule for the completion of the soft material extraction. 
(2)  A transportation plan detailing routes to be used by vehicles serving the site, weight limits and traffic volumes. 
(3)  A plan for stormwater and runoff management, pursuant to the provisions of section 6.15 of the ULDC. 
(4)  A buffer plan pursuant to section 6.16 of the ULDC. 
(5)  Plans for the control of dust pollution, noise pollution and light pollution. 
(6)  Application related to soft material extraction shall be made on such special forms, if any, as may be required by the Rome-Floyd County Planning Director or designated county agent and shall contain such additional information as the planning director or designated county agent may reasonably require. Assuming the application is complete, it shall be processed upon payment of a five hundred dollar ($500.00) application fee and shall be either granted or denied (with specific reasons for denial) within sixty (60) days after filing. And in the event of denial the applicant shall be given the opportunity to resubmit the application without payment of an additional application fee until the fourth resubmission; whereupon a two hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) extension fee shall be payable; and the same extension fee shall be payable upon every fourth resubmission thereafter. 
(o)  The board of commissioners shall also have the following powers, if appeals are made in writing to the county clerk within fifteen (15) days of the action or decision appealed from, or if a request for a variance is made setting forth the specific variance sought and justification for same in writing to the county clerk: 
(1)  To hear and decide the question where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this section of the Code. 
a.  In exercising the above powers, the board of commissioners may, in conformity with the provisions of this section, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue or direct the issuance of a permit. 
b.  An appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the officer from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of commissioners, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with the officer, that by reason of fact stated in the certificate a stay would, in such officer's opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such cases, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the board of commissioners or by a court of record on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken, and on due cause shown. 
(2)  To authorize, upon appeal in specific cases, such variance from the terms of this section as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this section will, in any individual case, result in unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of the section shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted to the individual case of unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of commissioners that: 
a.  There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape or topography; 
b.  The application of the section to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship; 
c.  There are conditions that are peculiar to the property which adversely affects its reasonable use or usability as currently zoned; and 
d.  Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purpose and intent of this section. 
(p)  Process for granting appeals or variances in relation to section 2-15-6: 
(1)  An application for an appeal or variance in relation to this section shall include such descriptions, maps or drawings as needed to clearly illustrate the action requested. The county manager or his designee may request such additional information from the appellant as necessary to provide a full understanding of the appellant's request. 
(2)  Once the record has been assembled, the county clerk shall schedule the appeal or variance for consideration at the next scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners for which adequate public notice can be given. 
(3)  Public notice. 
a.  Notification to the general public: 
1.  At least fifteen (15) days, but not more than forty-five (45) days prior to the public hearing, notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the county. The county clerk or the clerk's designee shall prepare such notice, which shall state the time, place and purpose of the hearing. 
2.  A request for an appeal or variance shall be heard at a public hearing only upon: 
(i)  The published notice, in addition to the requirement above, shall include the location of the property, the present zoning classification of the property, and the nature of the requested action; and 
(ii)  At least fifteen (15) days prior to the public hearing, the county clerk, the county manager or their designee shall post a sign or signs of not less than six (6) square feet stating the date, time and place for the public hearing, the present zoning classification of the property, and the nature of the requested action. One (1) such sign shall be placed in a conspicuous location along each street frontage of the subject property. If the property has no street frontage, a sign shall be placed on each street in which access will be gained to the property. 
b.  Notice to surrounding property owners. If the request is for an appeal or variance, notice shall be given to surrounding property owners as follows: 
1.  At least five (5) days prior to the public hearing, either the county clerk, the county manager or their designee shall cause a notice to be mailed to all persons on property located adjacent to or across the street from the property that is the subject matter of the request. 
2.  The notice shall state the time, place and purpose of the hearing by the board of commissioners. The written notice shall be mailed to the property as such names and addresses appear on the county's ad valorem tax records. 
(4)  Any appellant wishing to withdraw an appeal or request for variance prior to the meeting of the board of commissioners shall file a written request for such withdrawal with the county clerk. The appeal or request for variance shall therefore be removed from the board of commissioner's agenda and this request shall have no further effect. 
(5)  Board of commissioners and public hearing. 
a.  The chairman, vice chairman or board designee shall act as the presiding official and shall convene the public hearing at a scheduled time and place. 
b.  The presiding official may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. 
c.  The county clerk, county manager or their designee shall submit the assembled record of the appeal or request for variance to the board of commissioners. The county clerk, county manager or their designee, or other appropriate party if the appeal is taken from an administrative action or interpretation, shall provide such information or explanation as appropriate to the circumstances of the appeal or request for variance. 
d.  At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. No person in attendance shall speak unless first recognized by the presiding official. Upon rising to speak each person recognized shall state his or her name and home address. The presiding official may place reasonable limits on the number of persons who may speak for or against a request, on the time allowed for each speaker, and on the total time allowed for presentation of the request. No less than ten (10) minutes shall be provided for all of those speaking in support of the request and no less than ten (10) minutes shall be provided for all of those speaking against, unless such proponents or opponents take less time than allowed. If reasonable time limitations permit, any member of the general public may speak at a hearing. However, the appellant and nearby property owners shall be afforded the first opportunity to speak. 
e.  The appellant shall be allowed to speak first in order to present the request. Others in support of the request may then speak, followed by those in opposition to the request. The appellant will then be allowed time for rebuttal. Rebuttal must be limited to points or issues raised by opponents to the request at the hearing. 
f.  During the public hearing, the members of the board of commissioners may ask questions at any time. Time devoted to questions and answers will not be counted against time limitations that have been imposed on presentations. 
g.  At the meeting, following presentation of the appeal, action shall be taken by vote of the board of commissioners. 
1.  A motion to approve or deny an appeal or request for variance must be approved by an affirmative vote of at least three (3) members in order for the motion to be approved. 
2.  If a motion to approve an appeal or request for variance fails, the appeal or request for variance is automatically denied. If a motion to deny an appeal or request for variance fails, another motion would be in order. 
3.  A tie vote on a motion for approval of an appeal or request for variance shall be deemed a denial of the appeal or request for variance. A tie vote on any other motion shall be deemed to be no action, and other motion would be order. 
4.  If no action is taken on an appeal or request for variance, it shall be considered tabled and action deferred to the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners. 
h.  In taking action on an appeal or request for variance, the board of commissioners may: 
1.  Approve, approve with changes, or deny the request; 
2.  Table the appeal or request for variance for consideration at its next scheduled meeting; or 
3.  Allow withdrawal of the appeal or request for variance at the request of the appellant. 
(Ord. No. 2001-006A, § I, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 2007-007A, § I, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 2007-007A, § II, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 2007-007A, § III, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 2014-004A, § 1, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 2-15-7. - Enforcement of left-hand turn only provision. 
(a)  History. A zoning request was made to the Floyd County Planning Commission on File #43-2016Z to rezone the property from agricultural residential (A-R) to light industrial (L-I) for a trucking company located on the property on what is commonly known as Booze Mountain Road. It is specifically identified as tax map #117X and parcels #045 and #046. The request for rezoning was approved by the planning commission on condition that all trucks exiting the property must turn left toward US Highway 27. 
(1)  The Floyd County Police Department and/or the Floyd County Magistrate Court shall be empowered to enforce the provisions of the ordinance change and the specific provision of a "left-hand turn only" toward US Highway 27 off the property site. 
(2)  A first violation of this section shall be a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine and a second violation shall be a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. As indicated, this fine shall be enforced by the Floyd County Police Department through the Floyd County Magistrate Court. 
(3)  The sole purpose of the ordinance codified in this section is to enforce the ordinance change as outlined above and the fact that the sole reason for the ordinance change was to include a "left-hand turn only" provision. 
(Ord. No. 2016-004A, 6-28-16) 
Chapter 2-16 - ROADS, STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— State transportation code, county road system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq. 

Sec. 2-16-1. - Road and street classifications and limitation of maintenance. 
(a)  All roads and streets on the county road system and on county maintenance, as of the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived, shall have been classified as one (1) of the five (5) classifications of roads and streets established herein. All roads and streets accepted in the future on the county road system shall be designated as either a Class I, Class II, Class III, Class IV, or Class V road or street and the maintenance to be provided by the county shall be as defined and limited by this section according to the classification of each road and street. 
(b)  The minimum acceptable design standards for roads and streets shall be determined by the board of commissioners and filed in the office of the county manager. The procedures for property owners or residents of the county to petition to request the county to accept a road or street on the county road system shall also be determined by the board of commissioners and shall be filed in the office of the county manager. 
(c)  Because of the duty of fiscal responsibility and management imposed by law upon the board of commissioners, nothing contained in this section shall be construed so as to require the board of commissioners to accept any road or street for Class III, Class IV or Class V on the county road system for maintenance even after compliance by the owners or residents of the county with the established procedures. 
(d)  The road and street classifications are as follows: 
Class I: Over three hundred (300) vehicles per day. All major county thoroughfares meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  Eighty-foot right-of-way; 
(2)  Twenty-four-foot (thirty-six-foot with curb and gutter) asphalt plant mix surface; 
(3)  Eight-foot shoulders; 
(4)  Adequate drainage structures and ditches to control stormwater; 
(5)  Grassed slopes; 
are eligible for full maintenance such as: 
a.  Widening, resurfacing, or repairs as needed; 
b.  Shoulder stabilization and maintenance; 
c.  Vegetation control within right-of-way; 
d.  Litter control within right-of-way; 
e.  Drainage structures and ditch maintenance. 
Class II: All subdivision streets as described in the uniform subdivision regulations, (Chapter 17). At the time of acceptance the streets should meet the minimum standards and specifications of the subdivision regulations: 
(1)  Fifty-foot to sixty-foot right-of-way; 
(2)  Twenty-two-foot to twenty-four-foot (twenty-six-foot to thirty-six-foot with curb and gutter) asphalt plant mix surface; 
(3)  Six-foot shoulders; 
(4)  Adequate drainage structures and ditches to control stormwater; 
(5)  Grassed slopes; 
are eligible for full maintenance and upgrading to Class I at county expense as transportation needs of the county may require: 
a.  Widening, resurfacing, or repairs as needed; 
b.  Shoulder stabilization and maintenance; 
c.  Vegetation control within right-of-way; 
d.  Litter control within right-of-way; 
e.  Drainage structures and ditch maintenance. 
Class III: One hundred (100) to three hundred (300) vehicles per day. All minor county roads meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  Fifty-foot right-of-way; 
(2)  Twenty-two-foot (twenty-six-foot with curb and gutter) asphalt plant mix or surface treatment pavement; 
(3)  Six-foot shoulders; 
(4)  Adequate drainage structures and ditches to control stormwater; 
(5)  Grassed slopes; 
are eligible for full maintenance and upgrading to Class I road at county expense as transportation needs of the county may require: 
a.  Widening, resurfacing, or repairs as needed; 
b.  Shoulder stabilization and maintenance; 
c.  Vegetation control within right-of-way; 
d.  Litter control within right-of-way; 
e.  Drainage structures and ditch maintenance. 
Class IV: Fifty (50) to ninety-nine (99) vehicles per day, roads meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  Thirty-foot right-of-way; 
(2)  Twenty-two-foot gravel surface; 
(3)  Adequate drainage structures and ditches to control stormwater; 
are eligible for limited maintenance and upgrading to a higher road classification at the abutting property owners' expense. 
a.  Surface maintenance limited to leveling and grading the gravel surface; 
b.  Vegetation control will be to the back of the roadway ditches only; 
c.  All existing drainage structures and ditches will be maintained and cleaned (no new or improved drainage system will be provided). 
Class V: Under fifty (50) vehicles per day, roads which the county will not improve and meet the following specifications: 
(1)  Thirty-foot right-of-way; 
(2)  Gravel or dirt surface with varying widths; 
are eligible for limited maintenance and upgrading to a higher road classification at the abutting property owners' expense. 
a.  The existing roadway surface will be leveled and graded to a passable condi]tion; 
b.  Vegetation control will be limited to roadway surface only; 
c.  The county will not provide or maintain any drainage structures or ditches. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1005) 
Sec. 2-16-2. - Repairs and construction. 
The county public works department shall construct and repair the streets and sidewalks of the county, or direct the same, as may be ordered by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1001) 
Sec. 2-16-3. - Excavations. 
(a)  No county road shall be cut or excavated in any way except on written permission of the county manager after written request has been made, accurately describing the excavation to be done and its location. 
(b)  The county police department shall be notified before any excavation is begun. 
(c)  Any road excavated hereunder shall be replaced and restored to reasonably the same condition as prior to the excavation, including the regrassing of the easement, if damaged thereby, within thirty (30) days of the completion of the excavation work for each area. 
(d)  Notice of the completion of the excavation restoration work required in subsection (c) above shall be made to the public works department and the superintendent, or a designee thereof, shall inspect the restoration to ensure its proper completion. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1002) 
Sec. 2-16-4. - Residential street lighting—Procedures for obtaining or continuing. 
(a)  Existing residential street lighting shall be discontinued not later than December 31, 1974 unless the affected residents, property owners, and/or legal title holders of the property agree to pay for this service at their own cost as delineated in this chapter and so indicate to the board of commissioners. Notwithstanding, incandescent lights shall be discontinued or replaced with vapor lights by that date. 
(b)  Subdivisions, for which a final plat under county subdivision regulations has not been approved, shall require certification that street lighting is provided and that any deeds therefrom shall contain a covenant to require any future owner to pay the appropriate assessment. Subdivisions are defined as those so defined by the county subdivision regulations. 
(c)  Existing residential and subdivision streets may have street lighting provided by petitioning the board of commissioners. The petitions shall: 
(1)  Be signed by the owners of more than sixty-five (65) percent of the front footage of the streetlight district of the petition; 
(2)  Be properly notarized by a notary public; 
(3)  Be submitted to the superintendent of public works for review and submission to the board of commissioners; 
(4)  Be valid for a period of ninety (90) days from the date the petition form is provided to prospective petitioners. 
(d)  The board of commissioners may, at its discretion, hold a public hearing to further determine the desires and objections of the citizens of a streetlight district. 
(e)  The board of commissioners shall act upon presented petitions by resolution in open meetings. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1003; Ord. of 2-28-17) 
Sec. 2-16-5. - Same—Assessment of charges. 
(a)  The cost of street lighting shall be assessed to, and be entirely the responsibility of, the residents, property owners, and/or legal title holders of the property within a street light district. 
(b)  The appropriate charge to residents, property owners, and/or legal title holders of property within a street light district shall be added to their annual tax assessments by the county tax assessor. 
(c)  Residents, property owners, and/or legal title holders of property within a street light district shall be assessed on the basis of the front footage owned. 
(d)  Corner lots, which shall be lighted on at least two (2) sides, shall be assessed on the basis of the total front footage along the longest side. 
(e)  In the event of any unusual factors, such as unusual spacing by request, the superintendent of public works shall recommend to the board of commissioners such judgment of an equitable assessment not covered in this chapter for residential street lighting. 
(f)  Assessments for street lighting shall begin at the beginning of the next calendar quarter following installation. 
(g)  The board of commissioners shall hear any request for relief in extraordinary cases and determine if those assessments should be adjusted. 
(h)  The board of commissioners may authorize a change in assessments from time to time as required. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1004; Ord. of 2-28-17) 
Sec. 2-16-6. - Same—Responsibilities and authority therefor. 
(a)  The superintendent of public works shall have the responsibility of the administration of residential street lighting. The authority necessary to carry out this responsibility is hereby delegated. 
(b)  The county tax assessor shall have the responsibility of assessing charges authorized by the board of commissioners. The authority to carry out this responsibility is hereby delegated. 
(c)  The superintendent of public works or the superintendent's representative shall: 
(1)  Administer the residential street lighting program in accordance with the 1963 edition of the American Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting of the Illuminating Engineering Society, as approved by the American National Standards Institute, and recognized good engineering practices. Copies of the standard shall be maintained in the offices of the county clerk and the superintendent of public works for public inspection; 
(2)  Survey existing residential street lighting in the county and recommend appropriate action to the board of commissioners; 
(3)  Advise any prospective petitioners for streetlight districts of the procedures required by this chapter; 
(4)  Determine appropriate tax district limits for prospective petitioners; 
(5)  Advise petition originators of the approximate costs to property owners; 
(6)  Provide standard petition forms for prospective petitioners; 
(7)  Check petitions submitted for accuracy and conformance with this chapter; 
(8)  Notify residents of the streetlight district of the date and time the petition is to be considered by the board of commissioners; 
(9)  Submit recommended petitions to the board of commissioners, with accurate costs to property owners, for approval, with any recommendations required; 
(10)  Coordinate the installation of streetlights when authorized; and 
(11)  Perform any other duties necessary to carry out the street lighting activities, including proposing desirable amendments to this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1005) 
Sec. 2-16-7. - Driveway construction standards. 
(a)  No curb shall be changed or removed, and no driveway on or across a public street or a public right-of-way or public property shall be repaired or installed without first having a written permit from the county. 
(b)  Applications may be made at the building inspector's office in person, or by mail. 
(c)  A permit shall expire for work not started within ninety (90) days or completed within six (6) months after issuance of a permit, and a new permit shall be required before beginning or completing the work. 
(d)  All work shall conform to the following specifications and standards. These standards are implemented by the county for the purpose of assuring safe entrance and exit of vehicles from private driveways into the county road system. These regulations therefore set forth certain standards with regard to driveway width, angle of entry, percent grade, minimum piping for ditches, and restrictions on minimum sight distance. All of these standards must be applied at the time when a proposed development is initially being considered so that the builder or property owner can accurately and properly assure that this feature of the overall building process is handled correctly at the beginning to avoid future problems for county property owners and taxpayers. The following are the general requirements which must be met by a private driveway prior to issuance of a building permit by the building inspection office. 
(1)  Residential driveways: 
a.  Maximum driveway width shall be thirty (30) feet at the ditchline or point of intersection with the road right-of-way. 
b.  Angle of driveway into the county road right-of-way must be between sixty (60) and ninety (90) degrees. 
c.  Maximum grade which shall be permitted is fifteen (15) percent within the right-of-way. 
d.  The driveway surface connecting with the county road must have a minimum of a five (5) percent slope down and away from the county road to the center line of the ditch or at least six (6) feet from the edge of pavement to preclude ordinary surface water drainage from the driveway flowing onto the county road surface. 
e.  The driveway shall not obstruct or impair drainage in roadside ditches or roadside areas. The driveway piping shall be adequate for surface water drainage along the roadway and in no case less than fifteen-inch-diameter pipe. Reinforced concrete, galvanized corrugated metal or corrugated high-density plastic will be acceptable pipe materials. 
f.  No landscaping, fences, terraces, or other natural or artificial features adjacent to the driveway shall impair visibility from approaching vehicular traffic where that visibility is a threat to safety. 
g.  The driveway shall be located on the property so as to provide proper sight distance. Minimum sight distance requirements are: 
400 feet—Minor arterial roads.  300 feet—Local roads.  200 feet—Subdivision roads. 
i.  The building inspection office shall issue driveway permits separate from other building permits. 
1.  When the driveway permit is requested by the builder, the builder will be given two (2) stakes to mark the proposed driveway location at the site. 
2.  The public works department will inspect the location and state the required pipe size and other special notes on the location of the driveway. 
(2)  Commercial driveways: A drawing of the proposed driveway and parking lot shall be submitted to the building inspection office for approval before a permit is issued. 
(3)  Variances: 
a.  A variance may be requested in cases where these requirements might create an undue hardship. 
b.  Before a variance can be considered, a letter must be submitted to the public works director stating the reasons for requesting a variance. 
c.  Within five (5) working days, a decision on granting the variance will be made by the director of public works. The party requesting the variance will be notified by letter if the variance is to be granted or not. Any special conditions attached to the variance will also be stated in this letter. 
d.  The decision of the public works director may be appealed to the county manager, who shall have the authority to reverse the decision. An appeal to the county manager shall be decided in a timely manner. 
e.  If the decision of the public works director is upheld by the county manager, the applicant may further appeal to the board of commissioners by submitting a written notice of appeal. Appeals to the board of commissioners shall be considered and decided within thirty (30) days of the date of written notice of appeal. 
(4)  Maintenance of driveway: The department of public works will be responsible for the maintenance of the drainage pipe under the driveway and will also be responsible for providing a smooth transition from the county road to the driveway within the road right-of-way. The property owner is responsible for maintaining the surface of the driveway and any associated improvements to the property which has encroached upon the county right-of-way such as landscaping, fences, etc. If any improvements encroaching on the county right-of-way are found to be in violation of this section or are a safety hazard, the property owner will be notified in writing to remove such improvement. If the property owner does not comply within a reasonable period of time, the county will remove such improvement. 
(e)  Before the grading, paving, construction and repair of any driveway, the building inspector must be notified and must make, or cause to be made, an inspection thereof; and the proposed improvements must receive approval of the building official that the proposed improvements shall meet the standards herein set forth. 
(Ord. of 7-24-90, §§ 1—5) 
Chapter 2-17 - TRAFFIC[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicle regulation at airport, § 2-3-16; vehicles in recreation areas, § 2-13-17 et seq.; moving of buildings along streets, § 2-6-4 et seq.; road and street classification, § 2-16-1; wreckers as authorized emergency vehicles, § 2-18-25; solid waste collection vehicles, § 2-7-58. 

Sec. 2-17-1. - Uniform rules of the road adopted. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372, §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395 of that title known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, definitions, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this county with like effect as if recited herein. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1002) 
Sec. 2-17-2. - Traffic engineering. 
The public works department shall direct or perform all traffic engineering studies which may be necessary for the safe and efficient operation of the county road system. The department shall also maintain all traffic-control signs, markings and devices in the county system established pursuant to section 2-16-1. 
Sec. 2-17-3. - Traffic-control devices. 
(a)  Upon approval of the board of commissioners, the county engineer, or a designee thereof, is authorized to designate and maintain by appropriate traffic-control devices: 
(1)  Crosswalks at intersections where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway; 
(2)  Other safety zones for pedestrians; 
(3)  Traffic lanes; 
(4)  Speed, parking, or other traffic-control zones; 
(5)  Stop, yield, one-way and other directional devices; and 
(6)  Any other device necessary for orderly and safe conditions on the roads and streets of the county. 
(b)  All traffic-control devices shall conform to specifications in the manual on uniform traffic-control devices adopted by the state transportation board. All such devices required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the county. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this Code shall be official traffic-control devices of the county. 
(c)  The county engineer shall keep and maintain an accurate official map or maps with descriptions of all traffic-control devices. The map or maps and any amendments or changes thereto shall be adopted by resolution of the board of commissioners. An official copy thereof shall be kept in the office of the county clerk; shall be available to the public; and copies certified by the county clerk shall be admissible in court as proof of the location of any traffic-control device. 
(d)  No person shall be charged with violating a traffic-control device unless appropriate devices are in fact operating or in existence on the streets involved. 
(e)  Any violation of any traffic-control device established hereunder shall be a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1003) 
State Law reference— See O.C.G.A. §§ 32-6-50, 40-6-20. 
Sec. 2-17-4. - Speed limits. 
Speed limits for county roads are hereby adopted and posted accordingly with the proper authorities notified of said limits. A complete listing of county road speed limits is available for public inspection in the county clerk's office. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1003.1) 
Sec. 2-17-5. - Load limits generally, trucks. 
(a)  Under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 32-4-42(10), which provides that: "In addition to the power specifically delegated to it in that title, a county shall have the authority to adopt and enforce rules and regulations or ordinances to require permits and to perform all other acts which are necessary, proper or incidental to the efficient operation and development of the county road system, and the provisions of that title are to be liberally construed to that end. Any power vested in or duly placed on a county, but not implemented by specific provisions for the exercise thereof, may be executed and carried out by a county in a reasonable manner, subject to such limitations as may be provided by law." 
(b)  The superintendent of public works shall study the roads of the county, and in such superintendent's discretion, without impeding the flow of necessary commercial traffic, make and determine proper load limits for those roads which are being damaged and destroyed by overweight traffic, and having determined a proper load limit, shall report the same to the board of commissioners for its approval, and recordation in the official minutes of the board, and shall post both ends of the road, with the standard state-designed sign, notifying the travelling public of the load limits, and after the signs have been in place for a period of one (1) week, the county police shall be instructed to enforce the same, under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 32-1-10, which make it a misdemeanor to violate that title of the code. 
(c)  In the event it is necessary for trucks carrying a greater weight to use the road for any purpose, the superintendent of public works shall have discretion upon application to permit the usage for the specific purpose requested, and on the terms and conditions which will protect the road, as determined by such superintendent. 
(d)  A copy of this section shall be published once a week for two (2) weeks in the Rome News Tribune, posted on the bulletin board, and information as to the same be disseminated by the superintendent of public works in any other reasonable manner, so as to enable the citizens to become aware of this section, and to understand the meaning of the signs, after the superintendent of public works has determined proper and reasonable load limits, and has posted the road and reported the same to the board of commissioners, and has the load limits, the name of the road and the limits of the same duly entered in the minutes of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1004) 
State Law reference— Weight of vehicle and load, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-26. 
Sec. 2-17-6. - Truck routes. 
(a)  All motor vehicles having a gross weight in excess of thirty-six thousand (36,000) pounds, including the load thereon, or having an overall length in excess of thirty (30) feet, except vehicles designed to carry passengers, are prohibited from using any public road within the county that is maintained by the county, except those herein designated as truck routes, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Motor vehicles, whose terminal, parking lot, repair garage or headquarters which are not on a designated truck route, shall have ingress to, and egress from, such places by the most direct route available between the terminal, parking lot, repair garage or headquarters and nearest designated truck route; and 
(2)  Motor vehicles engaged in making a specific pickup or delivery on a public road not designated a truck route. On those road designated as county-maintained truck routes, the maximum gross weight for any motor vehicle shall be fifty-five thousand (55,000) pounds, except bridge limits indicated, and the maximum length shall be seventy-five (75) feet and the maximum width shall be ninety-six (96) inches. 
(b)  Any person driving or in charge or control of any restricted vehicle as defined in subsection (a) of this section, when upon a public road other than those designated as truck routes, shall be prepared to present for the inspection of police officers such person's log book, weight slips, delivery slips or other written evidence of such person's destination and point of origin, to justify the presence of the restricted vehicle on a street other than a designated truck route. 
(c)  If any designated truck route, or portion thereof, shall be under repair or otherwise temporarily out of use, restricted vehicles, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, shall use other temporary truck routes as may be designated by the county. 
(d)  Violation of this section, or any part hereof, shall be punishable by the judge of the probate court by a minimum fine of four hundred dollars ($400.00) for up to ten thousand (10,000) pounds over the maximum allowable load of four hundred dollars ($400.00) plus five dollars ($5.00) for each one hundred (100) pounds over ten thousand (10,000) pounds exceeding the maximum allowable load. 
(e)  The county shall coordinate with the City of Rome in establishing truck routes that are reasonable, that provide for continuous vehicular passage in and out of the city, and that serve the interest of the general public. 
(f)  The following routes are hereby designated as truck routes:

(Code 1979, § 8-1004.1; Res. of 6-11-85; Ord. of 2-22-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-28-17(2)) 
Sec. 2-17-7. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them as below: 
County property parking zone means: 
(1)  The public parking spaces located at the 3 Government Plaza Court House. 
(2)  The public parking spaces located at 12 E. 4 th Street, Rome, Ga, adjacent to the Floyd County Administration Building. 
(3)  Any and all public parking under the authority of, or managed by, the Floyd County Government. 
Handicap parking means: 
(1)  Handicap parking place means any area on Floyd County property which has been designated as reserved for the use of handicapped persons by any sign or pavement marking bearing the word "handicapped", or a symbol representing a person in a wheelchair. 
(2)  Handicap person means a person who by reason of illness, injury, age, congenital malfunction, or other incapacity or disability has a significant loss or impairment of mobility. 
Reserved or permit parking zone means: 
(1)  Reserved parking means any area on or within Floyd County property which has been designated by sign or pavement marking bearing the word "Reserved". 
(2)  Permit parking means any area on or within Floyd County property which has been designated by county authority, to be within an area where permits may be or are issued allowing employees or other persons to park. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-003A, adopted Feb. 9, 2016, deleted the former § 2-17-7, and enacted a new § 2-17-7 as set out herein. The §2-17-7 was entitled "Parking on county property—Rules and regulations," and derived from: Amends. of Jan. 24, 1995, § 1; Nov. 14, 1995; and Corr. of Feb. 29, 1996. 
Sec. 2-17-7(a). - Parking prohibited in handicap parking without permit or license plate. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, or park any vehicle in a handicapped parking place unless there is displayed on the dashboard or hung from the rear view mirror of the parked vehicle a valid, unexpired handicapped parking permit or unless there is attached to the vehicle a specially designated license plate for disabled persons authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-222(d). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, or park any vehicle in a handicapped parking place except for the purpose of allowing a handicapped person to enter or get out of such vehicle while in such parking place. However nothing in this subsection shall prevent an ambulance or other emergency vehicle from stopping in a handicapped parking place. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person or institution, other than the one to whom the handicapped parking permit or license plate for the disabled person is issued, to make use of the handicapped parking permit or license plate for disabled person. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a handicapped parking permit for any institutional vehicle other than the vehicle for which the permit has been issued. 
(d)  No person shall park a vehicle so as to block any entrance or egress ramp used by handicapped persons on public or private property. 
(e)  Authorities of the county shall honor visitors out of state handicapped license tags or similar special parking permits on the same basis as tags and permits issued within this state. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(b). - Parking violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place a vehicle, whether attended or unattended, in any parking place or area governed by Floyd County, for a time period in excess of the posted time limitations. The time limitations for each area shall be visibly posted either by sign or pavement marking within this zone. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place a vehicle, whether attended or unattended, in any area governed by Floyd County, which is designated as "Reserved", without said person is assigned that parking space by the authority of the county. This designation shall be marked either by sign or pavement marking within this zone. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally remove the tire marking placed on a parked vehicle in an attempt to gain more time while in a time restricted parking zone. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is an employee of Floyd County, to park their vehicle in the designated employee parking area without having displayed on their vehicle, an authorized permit or decal issued to them by the county. In addition it shall also be unlawful for any employee of this county to park their vehicle in a non-designated employee parking zone for a time period of more than thirty (30) minutes, i.e., court house parking area. 
(e)  Vehicles must be parked within the designated lines marking the parking space to be utilized by the vehicle. 
(f)  The violater can pay the fee for the parking violation as per the fee schedule adopted by the governing authority if the citation is paid within fourteen (14) days. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(c). - Notice on illegally parked vehicle. 
Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this county or by state law, the officer or duly authorized agent finding such vehicle shall take it's registration number and any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify it's user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the county, for the driver to answer to the charge against him/her within fourteen (14) days during the hours and at a place specified in the notice. The officer or duly authorized agent will then forward a copy of the notice to the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(d). - Failure to comply with notice attached to vehicle. 
If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing, or parking under the traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to a notice affixed to such motor vehicle within the fourteen-day period following the violation, the Floyd County Magistrate Court shall mail a court notice to the defendant. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(e). - Presumption in reference to vehicle ownership. 
In any prosecution charging in any law or ordinance governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or ordinance, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of the parking the registered owner of the vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima-facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked or placed the vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(f). - Penalties and fines. 
In the event the required fee for a parking violation is not paid within fourteen (14) days the fine for said offense shall be in an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2016-003A, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 2-17-7(g). - Towing and removal of improperly parked vehicles. 
(a)  Vehicles that are parked in violation of this section, including but not limited to, any vehicle left in a handicapped parking space, may be removed and towed to a garage in the County of Floyd, Georgia, as directed by the parking authorities. Said vehicle to remain there until such time as all court fines have been paid; and, the fees due to the towing company, including removal, towing and storage fees, have been paid by the legal owner, the registered owner, a person determined and verified by the towing company to have permission of the registered owner, or someone who has purchased the vehicle from the registered owner who produces proof of ownership or written authorization; and, such individual signs a receipt for the return of the vehicle. 
(b)  Floyd County shall not be liable or responsible in any manner whatsoever, for any damage or loss when an offending vehicle, or a vehicle reasonably considered to be offending at the time enforcement action was taken, is removed, towed, seized, held or stored. 
(Ord. of 12-13-16) 
Sec. 2-17-8 - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Fire lane means any area on public or private property which has been designated as a fire lane or prohibited zone by any sign or pavement markings bearing "Fire Lane" or "Prohibited Zone" and shall apply at all times. 
(b)  Application. The provisions of this section shall apply to all vehicles operated at shopping centers or parking lots or similar areas customarily used by the public. It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle within any fire lane or prohibited area which would prohibit access to the structure by any fire truck or fire apparatus, police, ambulance or other emergency equipment. 
(c)  Exceptions. Any vehicle designated as an emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency or fire alarm may park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the police department and/or the fire marshal, or his designee, to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Penalty for violations. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision under this section shall be punished as provided in section 2-1-8. 
(Ord. No. 2012-002A, § 1, 2-28-12) 
Chapter 2-18 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-18-1—2-18-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WRECKER AND TOWING SERVICES FOR POLICE-INITIATED TOWS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-001A, adopted June 8, 2010, deleted the former Art. II, §§ 2-18-20—2-18-27, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to wrecker and towing services. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
State Law reference— Removal of junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; local ordinances, etc., relating to wrecker services. 

Sec. 2-18-20. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Passenger cars, light trucks and similar vehicles means any vehicle weight up to ten thousand (10,000) pounds of GVW. 
Vehicle means unless otherwise indicated, a vehicle to be towed shall be: (1) a vehicle damaged to such an extent that it is unable to be moved safely under its own power; (2) a vehicle abandoned by its owner, driver or other person; (3) a vehicle impounded or under the control of a Floyd County police officer or other lawfully empowered officer of the city, county, or state; (4) a vehicle, the owner or operator or person in possession of which is under arrest or in the custody of the Floyd County police or other lawfully empowered officer of the city, county, or state; (5) a vehicle, the owner or operator or person in possession of which is not in physical or mental condition to operate a vehicle. 
Wrecker means an automotive vehicle with hoisting apparatus and equipment for towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. The term "wrecker" also includes any vehicle otherwise equipped and used for the purpose of towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. This definition includes "rollback" or "slide back" wreckers. 
Wrecker service means any partnership, individual person, corporation, limited liability company or other business entity, either as principal, agent or employee, in the business of removing, towing and/or storing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles by the use of a wrecker or other towing device within the city or county. 
(Ord. No. 2010-001A, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 2-18-21. - Procedures for county police officers and employees. 
(a)  A schedule shall be set up by the chief of police on a rotating basis for all qualified wrecker service companies, which have qualified under this article, which wrecker service companies shall be used as hereinafter provided, except in an extreme emergency, where persons are trapped or pinned in or under vehicles, or in burning vehicles, or in danger of drowning by submersion, or where traffic is blocked to prevent normal flow in which event, and only in which event, a police officer or other lawfully authorized officer shall be authorized to call the nearest, most qualified company to prevent serious injury or death. 
(b)  The police officer or other lawfully authorized officer, shall first determine whether or not a wrecker is needed, and if a wrecker is needed, shall ascertain whether the owner or operator is in condition to make a preference known, what wrecker service company the owner or operator desires to be called, and shall then call the preferred company desired by the owner or operator of the vehicle if the wrecker service can respond within a reasonable time. 
(c)  In the event the owner or operator is unable, due to injury or due to a physical or mental impairment, to make a choice, or does not have any preference, then said police officer or other authorized officer shall call the wrecker service company on schedule for that week. 
(d)  In the event the dispatcher is unable to reach the wrecker service company on call, then the backup wrecker service company, which shall be the company that was on the previous week's schedule, shall be called to provide the needed wrecker service. In the event that the on call wrecker service is reached but cannot respond to the scene then the on call wrecker service shall be responsible for sending another county approved list wrecker service in their stead. In this case the original on call wrecker service shall immediately notify Floyd County 911 as to which wrecker service will be responding to the scene. In this event, it is the sole responsibility of the on call wrecker service to insure that an approved wrecker service respond to the scene. 
(e)  Except in extreme emergencies, the police officer or other authorized officer, shall await the arrival of the wrecker and shall in the meantime, try to make the scene of the accident safe for other automobiles, using the road in the vicinity thereof, giving warnings and directing traffic. 
(f)  The police officer or other authorized officer shall make out a tow-in report, which shall contain the information and details prescribed by the county (especially the name of operator and owner), on a form made up for that purpose. The police officer shall have wrecker operator sign tow-in report and provide copy to the wrecker operator before leaving scene. The officer shall retain the original for department records. 
(g)  A thorough inventory shall be made, by the officer on the scene, of personal articles and equipment in the vehicle to be towed, such inventory to be written upon a form provided by the police department. 
(h)  If an officer requests that a vehicle be towed to the police department, the wrecker operator shall have the officer sign the tow-in bill. The officer will assume the responsibility for said vehicle, and indicate where said vehicle is to be placed. The officer shall forward the tow bill and make notification to person/persons responsible for follow-up regarding the vehicle. 
(i)  Officers are to insure that department personnel mail an owner/operator copy of the tow-in report to the registered owner of an abandoned vehicle. 
(j)  The public safety committee of Floyd County may also promulgate additional operating procedures not in conflict with this article. Such procedures shall be posted and filed in the same manner as the fee schedule referred to in section 2-18-25. 
(k)  Officers will give the 911 dispatch center as much information as possible about size of the vehicle and circumstances surrounding the tow. This information will be passed on to wrecker service that will make the determination of what equipment to respond. 
(Ord. No. 2010-001A, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 2-18-22. - Qualification of wrecker service companies. 
(a)  Any wrecker service company desiring to be qualified to be placed on the rotating schedule for use by Floyd County, under the conditions set out herein, shall file an application before October 1, with the chief of police. After the creation of the initial schedule, all wrecker services seeking to be placed on the rotating wrecker schedule shall if qualified be placed on the rotating list beginning the next calendar year following receipt of a pre-October acceptable application. A continuing responsibility for eligibility shall include an adequate and reasonable response time to calls made to the scheduled wrecker service company to assure efficient service on a 24-hour basis, and compliance with all sections of this article entitled wrecker and towing services for police initiated tows. 
(b)  Wrecker service companies desiring to be qualified on the rotating schedule shall agree to waive all charges to Floyd County on cases of innocent false arrests. 
(c)  Wrecker service companies desiring to be qualified on the rotating schedule shall agree to a schedule for calls determined by the chief of police. Wrecker service companies desiring to be qualified on rotating schedule shall agree to charge its on-call customers according to the fee schedule for towing service charges established pursuant to section 2-1-12. Where an owner or driver requests a specific wrecker service, the wrecker service shall not be required to follow the fee schedule. 
(d)  The fee schedule which is made a part of this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the place of business by each wrecker service company qualified, and each wrecker of the company shall carry a copy of the schedule, for the purpose of furnishing the same for vehicle owners or operators. 
(e)  Not withstanding anything contained in the article to the contrary, any wrecker service that has an owner or operator that has been convicted of a felony within five (5) years will not be allowed to be on the county rotating schedule for police/county initiated tows. All wrecker services desiring to be placed or remain on said rotating schedule agree to provide the Floyd County Police at the time of seeking qualification under this article and thereafter annually with a release executed by all owners of each wrecker service and all operators for each wrecker service which authorizes the Floyd County Police to conduct a criminal records search of said individuals.
